reviewText:
i've been playing doom since i was four years old in 1994 when my brother showed me the shareware version that came with our new computer. i've been hooked ever since.

at first, i was very cynical of this game, pre-release. why wouldn't i be? doom has had a hellish (heh) dev cycle with multiple versions canned for a variety of reasons, numerous instances of staff leaving id and overall a super bad scene from all evidence that was given. the e3 demo helped a lot to dissuade me from writing this off, but even then i felt uneasy. what if it's super rote? what if there is no soul?

i'm not sure how they did it, but id was able to bring back doom in the best way possible. this is a game that oozes confidence and knows exactly what it wants to be. it's not as groundbreaking for FPS as doom was back in 1993, but as it stands, this is my favorite FPS of 2016. now, it's important to note that this review is based entirely on the singleplayer campaign. i touched snapmap briefly and was left disappointed and the multiplayer felt very...standard and I wasen't impressed. so if you are comfortable with spending $60 on an extremely good single player campaign that lasts for around 10 hours, read on!

now, why is a remake of doom in 2016 possibly my FPS GOTY? let me count the ways:

1. the combat: while a fair chunk of the combat is regulated to closed-off arenas, the gameplay never feels anything less then super good and empowering as hell. doom approaches platinium games-level of fluidity and mobility, and the guns are super satisfying to use and have a, frankly astonishing, level of depth to them. i finished the game not even touching the rocket launcher, for example, only for a friend to tell me how much they used it and the scenarios it was super helpful in, and other friends have told me about other combat strategies they employ and each one of them is super different.

2. the personality and story: if you had told me that doom in 2016 would have lore and story that was legitmately interesting, i would have laughed in your face. but, again, i was proven wrong. while the story is nowhere near as good as something like The New Order was, it's an extremely entertaining and goofy story. i won't spoil anything, but there were moments where i caught myself laughing out loud at how bizarre, terrifying and ludicrous the UAC facility gets the deeper you go. also, the doomguy himself has an astonishing amount of personality just in the way he performs certain actions in the game. he never speaks, but we get a very clear sense of who he is and what he stands for, which is something that i never thought would be an element of a doom game.

3. the music and sound design: mick gordon returns from TNO and Killer Instinct to compose the soundtrack from doom and it is amazing. atmospheric and unsettling during quiet moments, loud and violent during not-so-quiet moments. the moment the soundtrack is released, i'll be getting it immediately. the sound design is also very well done, with super satisfying weapon discharges, grotesque demonic noises and the disturbing ambient hum of the UAC facility itself.

there is also an astonishing amount of replay value, with my 10 hour campaign not even scratching the surface of all the challenges, unlockables and secrets hidden in the game. this is absolutely a game to play through more then once!

this is a game that is worth every penny.

also, this was played on a i5 4670k with a GTX 970 4GB card and 8GB of ram and it was silky smooth on ultra settings except for the occasional hiccup every now and then from the crappy mechanical drive i had it installed on. i encountered very few issues, except for some annoying silent CTD's in Titan's Realm that I'm sure will be patched sooner rather then later.

it brings me great pleasure to tell you that doom in 2016 is extremely good.

reviewText:
DOOM:
~~~~~~

The UAC (Union Aerospace Corporation) created a state of the art research facility on Mars. Unfortunately, this superb establishment has been overrun by an army of ferocious demons! You are the only marine left on the red planet and the UAC has no other option but to activate you with the sole mission to eradicate all demons from the site. Let’s face it, this mission is suicidal . . . it is DOOM!

Doom is an action/first person shooter game where you take control of the last marine on the UAC research centre on Mars. You will wake up chained to what looks like an operating table, and within a few seconds you will realise that you are not the only one in the room. Menacing sounds are coming from your left, your right - actually from all around you! You free yourself, grab a gun on the floor and eliminate all enemies with sheer ferocity. Your next step is to find and equip yourself with a Preator suit - you will need it - it is going to be a brutal ride!

In the campaign mode, you will go through stunning and well-designed levels with plenty of demons to kill. I personally enjoy killing them when they are in the stunned state (glowing orange) with your bare hands - absolutely marvellous!  Each level has secret areas, items to find (check your map for hints) and challenges to meet. If you manage to locate a ruin, you will be able to activate a new challenge to succeed and keep a piece of the ruin.  Make sure to look everywhere, as there are a number of objects to collect:  Preator tokens (which can be found on fallen marines) so you can upgrade your suit, ammunition crates, shield plates (well, that’s what I call them), health icons and, of course, weapons. A little harder to find are the agent cells which can upgrade your character’s following skills – health, armour or ammunition.  The fun really starts when you find a “Gore Nest”- rip its heart out and a wave of demons will appear in the area. Sometimes you might notice an orb - pick it up and you will receive an extra boost in battle. I really like the Berserk Orb - just great to clear the area! If you succeed in eliminating all these nasty creatures you will receive an upgrade point; accumulate enough of these points and you can upgrade your weapons.

The multiplayer mode is also available in DOOM, but I find it really hard to get into a match, which is a bit disappointing. There is good character customization, however.

Graphically the game is superb, with a great voice over as well as a great soundtrack and sound effects. In regards to the controls, I strongly recommend the mouse and keyboard - I find it easier, but it’s always a personal choice.

There are a couple of issues that you might encounter while playing DOOM. The first one is setting your video resolution (bear in mind, I have the latest Nvidia driver installed). The game keeps launching in a window mode for some reason, even after applying full screen on the setting. Then I have to lower the resolution to get back to my full screen and re-apply to a higher resolution. The second issue is the crashes to desktop. You might be able to play for 3 hours without an issue but then the game will crash for no apparent reason. It seems that people have been experiencing the same issue with a wide range of PC setups (crashes).

Positives:
~~~~~~~

-	Stunning graphics
-	Gore violence (it is DOOM, after all)
-	Well-designed levels with plenty of hidden objects and secret areas
-	Great range of demons and arsenal
-	Fun and fast gameplay
-	Good soundtrack and voice over
-	Achievements and trading cards

Negatives:
~~~~~~~~

-	Hard to get into a multiplayer game
-	Frequent crashes to desktop
-	Resolution bug is a pain in the D…

Overall, I really enjoyed the game and all fans of DOOM and FPS should have this game in their library.

8/10

reviewText: I think people werent sure what to expect with Doom. Many including myself had doubts they could capture or compare to the original or quake. The multiplayer beta even hurt everyones expectations further. But as it turns out multiplayer is quite fun actually and single player is absolutely one of the best Doom experiences since the original doom. I remember when Doom 1 and 2 came out. The feeling of amazement and thinking This has never been done"... that feeling of awe. This Doom not only lives up to the expectation but it recaptured the essence of Doom and gave it new life. That feeling of awe is back. Doom (2016) is a great game and there isnt anything like it out there. Its a fine mix of new and old but its alive and it feels fresh and theres no other experience like it. Dont miss it."

reviewText:
Surprisingly good, played through the whole campaign on nightmare and hunted every secret. While it isn't 100% true to the originals it still manages to remain Doom-esque in level design and enemy/weapon interactions (Preferring to use some weapons against certain enemies but not others, etc). The melee kill animations can fairly safely be ignored (Enemies drop health, but on nightmare the guaranteed health from a melee kill is negligible at 5 points, and the large health drops from kills happen if you're low on health and still happen from ranged kills too) or even smoothed into the gameplay with the rune system, which lets you speed the animations up to practically the point of the Doom 1 and 2 punch animation.

The multiplayer isn't the worst thing ever made but it isn't particularly good or noteworthy. Since you pick which weapons you start with all the weapons have been equalized for balance, there's no frantically running around the map to grab the rocket launcher when everyone can spawn with one and it does piddly damage since it has to be equivalent to everything else.

Snapmap has some cool potential, but since it's based around the MP rather than the SP there's a 2 weapon limit and the players can't pick a difficulty level, the map designer has to specifically set enemy HP, damage, etc. It also has a god-awful search system to try to find maps, so you'll have a hell of a time finding ones that look interesting. Not nearly as powerful as a full editor but some good may come of it at some point.

Overall really damn good. I still enjoyed Doom 3, but this is far closer to Doom 1 and 2 than 3 was. Not really going to be a landmark shooter still regularly played and modded 20+ years later, but what is?

First impressions.... this is F**KING AWESOME!!!!

G3258 stock speed

Played more and this is summary so far :
Doom marine does looks like Doom marine.... updated :)

very good and not maze like. It really feels like a facility/R&D thingy

Gameplay :

Overall up to now... 4.5 out of 5 :)

reviewText:
I won't say too much that's already been said, just throwing out a few things that I like.  Been a DOOM fan since 1994, played the exhaustive releases and rereleases, and was very excited for this.  Wolfenstein: The New Order was my favorite game of 2014, and I hoped DOOM would get a similar treatment.

I play this with an i5 3570k, 8GB of RAM, and a 970 G1.  With Ultra settings, I'm getting 80-100FPS, not a constant framerate, but no noticeable drops either.  The campaign feels like a DOOM game, don't even know how to say it better.  The movement is fast, enemies are plentiful, and the graphics and music are exactly what I feel should be in this game.  The glory kills were something I was afraid would kill the fast pace, but they don't.  If the flashing of an enemy takes you out of the game, remove the highlighting and just shoot them.

Now, multiplayer.  I hated the beta.  Thought it looked and played poorly.  I'm not sure if things changed, but I'm loving it now.  Maybe it's because I'm good at it.  Has an Unreal/Quakeish feel, while not being as good as those.  The game modes for the most part are fun, and while most people tend to use the chaingun or super shotgun, I can still get plenty of kills and doesn't feel unbalanced.  All of the hate I see towards this game is based on multi, give it a shot.  It can really be fun.  I haven't messed with Snapmap yet, so won't comment on that.

reviewText:
In a word, Fantastic! They have managed to capture the essence of what made Doom great all those years ago, but now with incredible visuals, an amazing soundtrack that fits so well, gameplay upgrades that allow you to customise your character, suit and weapons, and new mechanics that force you to get in close to your enemies to give you back health or ammo.  On top of that there are plenty of heart-racing, frantic, gore-filled sections with tougher enemies progressively getting introduced, many of which are familiar from Doom 1 & 2.

I took about 20 hours to complete the campaign, but that included spending a fair amount of time trying to find all the secrets and additional challenges.  I still have a couple of secrets to find, plus weapon challenges to complete and will definitely be going back in to complete those.

I have only tried the multiplayer deathmatch experience in beta so far, I wasn't that impressed by it and isn't something that I will be spending much time in, as I prefer a more tactical team-based fps such as Counter-Strike or Battlefield.  I will give it another go and try out the new modes and maps however.

I had a quick look at SnapMap which allows you to create your own content for the game, and will be interested to see what the community comes up with which may give extra replayability to come.

To summarise, if you are interested in a heart-pounding, fast-paced single player experience without too much in the way of a storyline, then I would definitely recommend getting this.

reviewText:
aaaahhhh... Doom. The game that made me a PC Gamer for life. There is NOTHING i can say about this game that has not already been said. The single player campaign is for sure the best game that has come out this year, and to be honest its probably the best FPS in recent years hands down. The pace is breakneck, the graphics are astounding, the soundtrack is phenomonal. Nearly everything you remember about Doom is here.

I want to say this now. This review does not reflect my feelings of the multiplayer portion of the game. It feels tacked on, it feels like its a seperate game and to me it doesnt feel like Doom. Two staples of Doom are completely missing from the multiplayer portion of Doom, and if it were a seperate game it is bad enough that i would not buy it. Co-op and free for all deathmatch are completely missing from this game. Doom multiplayer was built on these two modes and them both being missing is a travesty.

That being said, the SP mode is where this game shines, and oh boy does it shine! The story is a bit lacking for sure, but Doom never really had a whole lot of story anyways, so nothing really missing in this catagory. The gameplay is fast and frantic. On harder difficulties if you stop moving you are DEAD. There is a great variety of demons, both old and new, and the models for them all are spectacular. All your favorite Doom weapons have returned, and most of them are upgradeable. The weapon models themselves (like all other models in the game) are fantastic. Though i have not played through the entire game, what i have seen so far of the backgrounds are beautiful, and the textures have alot of variety.

All in all this game is a must purchase for any fan of Doom, any fan of arena shooters or honestly any fan of FPS games in general. There is nothing on the market that compares, and i feel it will be quite awhile before something does compare.

reviewText: The game itself is amazeballs, pure no-nonsense fps hell-gore galore, and quite possibly the best Doom game. But after a dozen or so freezes requiring hard reboots and CTDS happening within a few hours in the latter part of the game, I can't recommend it in this state. It's absolutely unacceptable that this has not been addressed and patched properly almost a month after launch. It's happening to many customers, and it's about time we let our complaints affect the ratings negatively. Everybody's slamming Homefront: The Revolution for being a trainwreck of a buggy mess, so it's only fair that somebody speaks truth to power about how having to do hard reboots because load screens freezes, or suddenly suffering a CTD right before you would've killed the last Baron of Hell very much indeed detracts from the experience. I didn't buy this game to fool around with debugging all possible variables that might be causing crashes. It's also a damn shame, considering how incredibly well optimized this game is when it's actually running.

reviewText:
Genre - FPS shooter with some character progression

About me - I was not a massive fan of the original DOOM games. Ifound single player repetitive and was never good enough to compete.

So I purchased this game after reading through various reviews. I have now finished the single player camapign on the easiest mode, attempted to make a snap map but failed, and also been pwned on multiplayer.

I actually think this is the first DOOM game I can say I enjoyed for any length of time. The campaign is simplistic in style. You fight waves of enemies with the resources available and a few puzzles are thrown in along the way (only a few are irritating as I am not a fan of timed jumping). The story is as good as the source material allows and actually had me thinking back to Dead Space, which was a great game.

It looks great and the combat is fluid with finishing moves added for extra coolness. The weapons are what you would expect, but this time around you can upgrade your alternate fire and also pick up a few perks and armour upgrades. I think this sort of stuff is required to add re-playability, and also to allow some degree of customisation depending on your play style. This reminded me of Shadow Warrior, which was another re-boot that was also done very well.

People have complained about the length of the campaign. It took me about 12 hours on the easiest mode and I have been back a bit to look for secrets and missed upgrades.

However, this is only one part of the game. The snap maps have been criticised for being too simplistic. However, I think this is good as levels will be designed within a specific framework. They could maybe add more features if there is high demand though. I did attempt it but realised that I need to read up or watch some videos before doing this properly.

The multiplayer deathmatch seemed fun although I was clearly awful at it. You can choose weapons at the strat and customise your look. You unlock things as you play more. Again this is needed to bring players back for more, even though some purists like a good whinge.

I think the game is another great example like Shadow Warrior before it of how to re-boot early FPS games for the current generation, and those of us from the previous generation who found them a bit dull after a while.

reviewText:
Very first impression review, more in depth one will come in the future... maybe...
After the MP beta I was ready to scrap DooM from my wishlist - good thing I did not do that! They did it. They actually pulled it off - the Doom is mostly black with even more gore and speed! Single player content is intense, and its really close to what you would expect from DooM title. Forget story, who needs a story - its about you killing tons of demons and shooting cool looking guns! The new doom guy even acts like he is angry that there is some story in his way!
But lets start from the beginning - game looks really great (no washed out, bright graphics that we gets these days with AAA games) - looks sharp, colourful and sometimes even dark with high contrast. And you can alter your FoV beyond 100 - big plus!
For me performance is fantastic, game runs smoother than anything that recently came out and I had zero bugs or glitches so far.
Gameplay - its fast, really fast. M+K controls are tight and responsive - aiming and shooting feels awesome. One thing that I dont like its the verticality - way way too many platforming/jumping parts - I died to those way more than from npc`s.
Great bosses, they will have some surprises for you once you think you figured them out - very good fights.
Yes the game can feel easy - mobs will drop health at your convince (glory kills) and if you short on ammo - just use chainsaw - ammo drop rain incoming. (did not tried highest difficulty yet).
Still you can just ignore those mechanics and make game more challenging for yourself.
Despite that it really feels different from today's shooters - in a good way. It has this old vibe that you get when playing original DooM.
Shame is - there is no coop for main campaign - I think it would work just fine and would be great fun.
Snap map editor - yes it is there and you can create something cool form the blocks that ID gave us. Still its very limited and we have just few basic interiors and props to choose from - I hope it will improve because this is what will keep new DooM alive for many years - player created levels - and people are already showing great creativity with the maps.
I wont comment on MP because I have zero interest in it.
Its absolute worth getting even with the asking price. I was ready to tear this game to shreds - game proved me wrong.
DooM is back baby.

reviewText: When it came to gameplay, I absolutely loved the short time I spent playing Doom.  The gfx were wonderful, the gameplay happened at a rapid pace, and I was starting to get involved in the SP story line. Unfortunately, I happened to be a victim of the developer mode bug.  In a nutshell, out of blue I received a notification that I was put into developer mode, and as a result certain features of the game were disabled.  According to the dev message, the solution is to delete my SP Game save and start from scratch.  Unfortunately, this did not work. Even deleting the files and folders in C:\Users\me\Saved Games\id Software\ did not solve the problem (there are a few more steps that I followed to try and resolve this problem, but I digress).  When I first open the game after deleting the files I can play just fine. However, as soon as I quit Doom and then re-launch, I get the you are in Dev mode" error.\nFortunately
date: I had played the game for less than 2 hours so I just ended up requesting and receiving a refund from Steam.\nIf it wasn't for this absolutely horrible bug
recommended: I would definitely recommend this game. In the end
hoursPlayed: I simply cannot recommend purchasing at this time until Bethesda releases a fix (as of 06-02 this bug has been met with silence).\nHonestly
voteText: I have no idea how many people its affecting; for all I know it could be less than 1%. That being said
helpfulPercent: there is currently a 500+ post thread on Steam regarding this issue.  Ironically
votesHelpful: the thread was started by a Bethesda Developer.\nLong story short
votesTotal: if the Dev Mode bug gets resolved
votesFunny: I will definitely purchase the game again. Otherwise
commentsCount: I am happy with my refund!\nJust FYI
column16: I strongly recommend any new purchasers test out their Doom install as soon as possible to determine whether or not you are affected by this bug (If you play the game for more than 2 hours
column17: Steam will not give you a refund).  Based on my experience
column18: the best way to determine if you are affected is to simply exit out of the game and then re-launch it. If you receive a message about network services being disabled and dev mode being enabled
column19: you are most likely affected by this bug.  Honestly
column20: you should perform the exit/relaunch process as many times as possible. Some people don't run into this issue until they are hours into the game. IMO there is simply nothing you can do to fix it at this time.\nHopefully Bethesda will at least post an update as to whether or not they are planning on fixing this."

reviewText:
DOOM is a really legendary franchise, perfecting the First Person Shooter formula back in 1993 when it was released. Being a huge part of my childhood, when the new DOOM game was announced I was bouncing left and right, trying to contain my excitement. When I saw the first trailers and gameplay mechanics, I was kind of skeptical about how the new game will work off with health and ammo drops when you kill enemies, but to my surprise it works amazingly. Let me explain a little bit more.

So the new DOOM is what it tries to be, a new DOOM game for the new gaming generation. Based off the first two games of the franchise, DOOM and DOOM II: Hell on Earth it brings itself to the modern day really well. Gameplay is fast paced and full of action just like its predecessors. You can carry all the guns you pick up along the way and upgrade them through fighting hordes of demons or finding secrets to make your demon slaying even more gorey and effective.

Introduced new into the gameplay is the Glory Kill system, which will allow you to make a gorey kill move against any demon that you have done enough damage to and rip off their head, guts, heart or legs! There's multiple animations for these actions so you won't be seeing the same kill animation over and over again too often. Performing these kill moves on the demons makes them drop health and ammo for you to pick up making the killing smooth and fun with your guns or fists alike.

New enemies are introduced as well and I must say they fit to the DOOM franchise amazingly well and are a welcomed add to the bunch of the old foes that we meet along the way and God, don't get me started on the graphics. The environments in the game look really believable and beautiful to look at. I was in awe of the detail and beauty of the scenery wanting to explore everything you see along the way.

Which brings me to the secrets. They're scattered all over the game for you to find and they usually reward you really well from weapons to powerups, so exploration is always rewarded in multiple ways.

The game is challenging and fun to go through. Every difficulty from the old games are present and a new hardest difficulty Ultra-Nightmare is introduced as well. Never beat nightmare mode on the originals and I bet I won't beat them on this game either!

Even if I give this game a lot of praise, couple of things did bother me.

First off the Cyberdemon's design since the first trailer didn't leave a huge impact on me for being the most iconic DOOM monster in the series. The new redesign of the character makes him look cool, but not intimidating like he was in the originals. Even in DOOM 3 I felt intimidated by him. He was a rewarding boss in the old games, but for some reason I didn't get the same feeling when I beat him in the new DOOM. This is of course a personal opinion and I don't expect people to agree with me, but to me the big badass demon from the old games should have intimidated me and make me feel threatened at least once. This Cyberdemon didn't do it for me.

I love most of the music in the game, but some of the industrial metal setting does get a bit repetetive. There's some nice easter eggs in the music having snips of old DOOM songs here and there, but the industrial sound doesn't bring them out too well. It feels too much like Quake and that is not what DOOM's about. Quake is a great game series, but industrial metal in my opinion doesn't belong in DOOM. Good old rock 'n' roll and old school metal does. Again, my opinion and no one needs to agree with me.

Otherwise I'd say DOOM is a must pick for any DOOM fan out there and I personally would give the game about 8.5/10 rating myself. It's a great reboot of an old classic bringing the good old FPS action to the new gaming generation and who knows, get interested the old games as well.

reviewText:
The game is fun to play, but is affected by a game breaking bug.

If your game randomly crashes to desktop (it will), if you have more than one steam account playing via amily sharin), or if you accidentally activate console during a game, your savegame gets flagged and you are barred from any and all online content. In order to restore access you must delete your save and lose all progress. If you chose to continue playing through on the corrupt save while barred from online content, you cannot earn any achievements.

I have restarted the game three times in an attempt to be able to access all of the content I paid for (campaign, online multiplayer, and snap mode) There is no fix and the official line from Bethesda support is to delete your save (which does not guarantee it won't happen again)

reviewText:
#### WARNING, LONG REVIEW ####

Title: DOOM
Genre: Action
Developer: id Software
Publisher: Bethesda Softworks
Release Date: 13 May, 2016

Copy was purchased.

---------------------------------------------------------

DOOM is back with all the action and gore that we love, and on a brand new engine!

You had me worried for a second there Bethesda. Not giving out review copies prior to a game's release is normally a sign of a publisher trying to cover up that their game maybe isn't all that great, and they would like to get as many people purchasing before reviews are out. Thankfully, DOOM is everything that I hoped it would be, even if I did doubt that it would be.

DOOM is on a new engine, id Tech 6 and it runs very well. I managed to get a consistent frame rate, and the game looked amazing. id Tech 6 also doesn't have that texture pop-in annoyance that id Tech 5 had, which is always great.

Within seconds of starting the game up, you are straight into the action and shooting hell monsters right in their skulls. DOOM knows it is not a game that will have an award-winning story, and id Software play that to their strengths by making this 100% awesome gameplay. This shows heavily when there are scenes where characters are clearly trying to give the game a story with more in-depth character development, but the protagonist, Doomguy, just doesn't care.  Instead, Doomguy will just choose to ignore character/story progression and conversation by smashing computers giving messages, or by smashing communication units from people telling him what to do. You don't tell Doomguy what to do, his only job is destruction.

Aside from the starting pistol, all weapons feel like they pack a punch. You are given the pistol when you first start the game, and that may lead some people to think negatively of the game as the pistol doesn't feel good to use at all. However, before you can even begin to rage, you  will be given the shotgun. The shotgun feels and sounds wonderful. Weapon customising is big in DOOM, each weapon has two trees that you can unlock and it's not an 'either or choice', you can pick both and all of the upgrades, and even swap between the changes with ease. Want your machine gun to fire rockets? Sure thing. Want to turn your Chaingun into a mobile turret? Of course! As well as giving benefits that change what the gun can do, you also unlock benefits that can improve the stats, e.g. reload faster or decrease ammo cost. To unlock the last upgrade for each weapon, you will need to complete a challenge. The challenge will depend on the gun and the upgrade, but they are generally things such as 'Hit 4 enemies with Micro Missiles in 5 seconds'. This will then unlock the ability to be able to fire as many missiles as you have the ammo for.

The main problem with creating a game like this is that you want it to be modern and fresh, but you also don't want to ♥♥♥♥ off the core players that loved the original game. The enemy design in DOOM (2016) pays homage to the original in a lovely way, they have been heavily updated, changed and modernised, but you still look at them and know exactly what they looked like in the original game. The enemies still look like hell demons, and that is what you want in a DOOM game. They are also all squishy and full of blood, so when you shoot or rip them apart, lots of blood and gibs will splash out like a fountain.

That still doesn't change the fact that lots has been changed in this new version of the game when compared to the original. You can look up and down, you can jump and even double jump! The main issue I had before the game was released was that I was worried that the 'Glory Kills' feature would spoil the 'DOOM-esque' vibe and make it too much like every other FPS we currently have on the market. Luckily, that isn't the case. For all those not familiar with DOOM's 'Glory Kills', this is when an enemy is on low health, you can melee them brutal way with a quick animation. The enemy will then drop more ammo and health. When games generally add animations to things like this, once you have seen it a couple of times then you cannot be bothered to keep seeing them again. For me, I have not grown tired of them. They are extremely quick animations that does not slow down the gameplay or leave you vulnerable to an attack. Even though you will continue seeing the same animation again and again, they still always look great. For those that do not want to see these glory kill animations, you do have the option for turning them off.

Level design has always been a major part of the old school FPS games. Remember that joke picture that showed level design in old FPS games and it being an intricate maze, and then it showed modern FPS games and it was a single corridor filled with cut scenes? DOOM is most definitely the former. The levels have been wonderfully designed, full of secrets and easter eggs such as the ability to jump into and play the original doom but with the new weapons (Like in Wolfenstein The New Order). I hunted high and low for secrets as I was playing, but there were still plenty that I have missed and will need to go back and try to find them. There were also times that I found switches that I turned and I didn't have a clue where the door was that must have opened. Fans of exploration will love the little hidden things you can do and find, and people who do not like this can just choose to run right past it all and continue killing.

Campaign length always comes into question. DOOM took me around 10 hours to complete on 'Hurt me plenty' difficulty, this was with many secrets and other items missed that I will go back and see if I can collect them all. Once the game has been completed once, this will unlock 'Nightmare' and 'Ultra-nightmare' difficulty. Nobody at id Software has completed the game at 'Ultra Nightmare', this is because the enemies pack a serious punch, and I mean that one enemy can easily kill you quicker than you can turn around to say hello. Is that all? No of course not. Once you die, sorry, game over. Yep, this is permadeath, once you die you have to start from the very beginning again. A marker will be placed in the area you died, so you can wave to where you previously died. I tried this difficulty mode. I failed this difficulty mode. I'm not generally one for re-playing games again, but with DOOM, I definitely will. I enjoyed all 10 hours that I put into the campaign that I will not be replaying it dreading a certain part of the game (except for maybe some of the boss fights when at a harder difficulty).

Multiplayer was the part that seemed to have been focused on prior to the release of DOOM. The beta was a multiplayer only beta, that frankly I just didn't really enjoy that much. Now that the full game is out and I put more time into the multiplayer, it is starting to grow on me. I mainly play 'Freeze tag' as I loved that in Quake II, but there is a variety of game modes to suit everyone....

##### Review is too long for Steam, to read the rest, please go to https://www.ordinarygamer.co.uk/2016/05/15/doom-review/ #####

reviewText:
In short, they absolutely nailed it.

I was quite pessimistic over this game. Then I got to play it and holy crap yes! Doom doesn't shove down some BS story down your throat, you wake up and imediately start shooting demons around you. Combat feels quick, you never stand in one place because that get's you killed pretty fast. From first level onwards I found myself running around the level, shooting anything that moves, jumping on higher ground while grabbing health/ammo/armor desperately trying to stay alive.

What was probably the most positive surprise is the level design. You are not just thrown into a linear corridor after linear corridor like in Doom 3, instead you get open large levels quite similar to original games. Also yes, there are numerous secrets to be found, I think I missed 6 in second level alone.

What I thought I would hate were the glory kills, however they are quite quick to pull off and keep the pace up by giving you some extra health (which you will need on higher difficulties). Perhaps the game relies too much on this system, them again whenever you take damage it is 100% your own fault, almost any source of damage can be avoided by a skillfull player. This doesn't make the game easy though, UV is definitely giving me a run for my money.

This is probably the best shooter I've played since Half Life. It's insanely polished. The graphics are the best to date, the AI is by far the best I've ever played against (!), the weapons and upgrades are all exciting and makes you feel like a total boss. The variety of enemies is very creative and well done; some enemies make you feel powerful and some enemies tear you to pieces (literally). Map designs are made by geniuses. I almost feel bad for the staff cause must have worked their asses off!!

BUY THIS GAME! But you must seriously have turned 16+. Seriously. And play on the hardest possible difficulty!

reviewText:
I regard this new DOOM as a faithful return to the original franchise. Obviously it’s not going to be exactly the same, as the original game is far from perfect. With a lot of reboot franchises, the core of the game is usually lost, but this isn’t the case with DOOM.

Id Software have really poured their heart and soul into making this reboot as amazing as it could be, and then some. It reminds me of the original games, yet introduces new and interesting gameplay features that keep it up to date with modern games. It’s a perfect blend of old school meets new school. The new Id Tech 6 engine is one of the most impressive engines I’ve seen. Both in terms of graphics and performance. Granted my PC is above the recommended specs, but I’ve heard it performs well on a variety of systems. The performance was “unchained” essentially, and my computer could be fully utilized to give the best experience possible. Id clearly haven’t forgotten their roots.

The shooting is enjoyable and punchy. Each gun has 2 distinctly different weapon mods to unlock, which add a decent amount of variety to the combat. 2 weapon mods per gun doesn’t seem like much, but they change the way a weapon behaves in such drastic ways. Each stand out on their own, and by the end of the game I had unlocked all of them, and felt comfortable no matter which I was using.

Glory kills are another new gameplay feature. Fast and fluid melee executions that add serious variety to traditional fps gameplay. Originally I thought these would slow down the pace of the combat, but I can safely say I was wrong. They add brutality and enjoyment to an already brutal and enjoyable game :P

The multiplayer is satisfying to an extent. At first glance people assume it was a tack on, but looking into it further you can tell Id have really put some effort into this area. The amount of customization is insane. From acquiring different armour types, to changing the material and colours of your weapons. The gameplay is pure old-school Quake III, slightly slowed down and missing a few features though. Definitely worth your time if you have any interest in faster paced multiplayer.

The integrated SnapMap tool (used for building your own levels and sharing with others), offers a lot more on top of the single player and multiplayer, but sadly the limitations are far too obvious. Clearly it was a tool built with consoles in mind, hence the limited objects, and options. You can only have 10 demons spawned at once, and the building space is far too small. I really wish they would have removed these limitations on the PC version, but sadly I don’t see it happening any time soon. Still, SnapMap is a fun extra, to an already great game.

Buy DOOM, it’s worth every penny.

reviewText:
Jesus H Christ is this game amazing. Easily the greatest FPS I've ever played. Fast and fluid combat mechanics, super tense encounters, and wildly satisfying gibs. Hopefully this game marks the end of the uninspired cover shooter, the forced-narrative driven games, and the 10 year long fetish for the Marine Corps.

Onto the details, the difficulty curve is one of the absolutely most linear (that's good) I've ever seen in a game. It's a gradual increase and the game manages to foreshadow the next enemy to be introudced in a very natural way. And speaking of the enemies, they're as well designed as they ever have been. Each enemy has its own unique set of mechanics and weaknesses. They all have special ways of being disembowled as well, so that's a plus.

Encounters usually come in three flavors: hallways, multiplayer-esque arenas, and boss fights, and they all manage to hold their own and be memorable. The boss fights are particularly fantastic though, sporting WoW-like boss mechanics that require you to really be paying attention to the environment as well as shooting the big bad guy in the head.

Any negatives this game has are HEAVILY overcompensated by the positives. If I were to list a few though, it would be that it still indulges in the occassional slightly long cutscene or scripted sequence, the talent trees are neat but kinda boring (armor talents in particular), fairly lengthy load times, and lack of blast beats in the death metal/electronic score.

Note that you do need a pretty good rig to run this properly (this game REALLY needs to be played at 60+ fps) and I had to turn everything to low to keep it around 60 when the ♥♥♥♥ hit the fan. I'm on a GTX760, i7-3400 and 8gigs of RAM for reference.

So if you can run it, you need this game. This ♥♥♥♥ should be as ubiquitous on Steam as Portal and Half-Life 2.

PROS:- Beautiful Graphics (id Tech)

- SnapMap Limitations
- Title changed from DOOM® 4 to DOOM®
- No Campaign or SnapMap content in the Season Pass
- Checkpoints and Autosave instead of Manual Saves
- No Mod Support
- No Co-op in the Campaign
- No in-game Triple Buffering for Vsync

- No Simple Crosshair option in SnapMap? (hitmarkers)


REVIEW SCORE:8.9 out of 10

Content updates to SnapMap may increase review score (I hope), because what mostly hurts the score is limited SnapMap content, SnapMap limitations, and not developing the competitive multiplayer in-house. At the very least, SnapMap needs a bunch of more modules that are varied with different themes (hell, Mars, outer space, stone, wood, medieval, outdoors, etc.). There should also be items to place that go with those different modules.

reviewText: Dev mode.  It needs fixing.  Existing saves need to be un-flagged.  Bethesda and id need to release a patch for this, rather than brazenly advising people to delete their saves and start all over again in the off chance that this will resolve the issue.  Most likely it won't, since the game is also crashing to desktop for a lot of players, leading to corrupted files which apparently are triggering this developer mode without the player doing anything (as if pressing ` should justifiably wreck people's save files, considering it's kind of an id game standby — let alone F12, which is the default screenshot key for players on Steam).  They need to understand that nobody wants to pay $60 for a video game only to waste their own time on this nonsense.  UNTIL THEN, well, I have to give this game a thumbs down — if only to contribute to gaining their attention and ensuring that THEY understand the onus is on them to fix their game.  It is not the responsibility of their customers.\n\nThat said, the single player campaign itself is AMAZING and far better than I had hoped it would be, so this whole fiasco renders it all bittersweet.  If/when these problems are patched up, I'll delete or edit this review and switch to very much recommending Doom 4.  If you're only concerned with playing through the fantastic single player campaign and don't care about the rest (and you shouldn't, really) I would recommend that you DO NOT PAY FOR IT until id and Bethesda show some sign that they're paying attention.  Buyer beware, in any case.

reviewText:
HINT: If you want an even more authentic experience, disable HUD and turn off glowing for stunned enemies in the Game Options

Is this DOOM 1 with an HD reskin? absolutely not. Does that mean this doesn't feel like DOOM? Absolutely not. From the strafing, to the exploring, to the power ups, to the music, this is DOOM. This is coming from someone who just replayed DOOM I, II, and III in the week leading up to this release. This is more original DOOM than DOOM 3.

This game has a lot of exploration and lot of wide open spaces that you can't pass until you complete certain objectives and find certain items (like in the original). If you liked the claustrophobic, survival horror, F.E.A.R. feel of DOOM 3, this is not what you're looking for. The campaign is fully fleshed out, with Ultra Nightmare difficulty living up to its name (you die = you start the whole campaign over, with saving only at the end of each level). The multiplayer, if it gets enough players, fully capable of overshadowing the next CoD. SnapMap, which people have used to create anything from Harvest Moon in Doom to remaking the missions from the original games, is sure to give this game a long life span as long as the community keeps it alive.

tl;dr if you like strafey doom then buy, if you like locker-code jump-scare doom, hopefully you also like strafey doom

reviewText:
It's Doom.

Fast, gory, fluid action. Jammed with secrets and bonuses. The upgrade system isn't over-complicated like in so many games, and does what it is supposed to - it adds variety to the combat.

Classic Doom, at it's most exhilarating and particularly most exercised in the more excellent community maps over the years, is about overwhelming odds being handled with grace, a combination of movement, awareness and weapon management. Doom 2016 taps into this well, with chaotic set pieces that are breathlessly paced and require the most capable reflexes. It's a modern FPS that is challenging but not excruciating.

The monster design sits somewhere between the colourful aesthetic of the original games and the more contemporary iD tech style of recent years (Doom 3 onwards). The Baron of Hell is very much a beefy, slightly silly looking pink behemoth that leaps around and smashes the ground as if it's having a tantrum. The Hell Knight is a faster, angrier take on the design seen in Doom 3 (which was pretty scary in that incarnation). Imps are fast like in Doom 3, but with added movement dynamics, as they scurry, climb and crawl, throwing fireballs behind them as they run for cover. Catching them  mid-leap is very satisfying.

I'm still playing the game, and haven't played the multiplayer as of yet (beyond the BETA anyway, which I enjoyed), but I have sampled snapmap and I am looking forward to really experimenting with it. There is clearly a lot of potential within the logic system to create some great maps and scenarios. I hope more snappable areas are made available in the future.

reviewText:
I apologize to any of you that were exposed to the hack 1st year grad student review that was posted by me earlier.  I always write my reviews in Word and then cut and paste the finished piece into whatever medium I am working in, well this time I have no idea what happened but what was posted was missing paragraphs, punctuation, and all formatting.  I have corrected the review accordingly and hope it helps you during your deliberation if you should buy this game or not.

I played so much of the original game Doom, that I could run levels entirely in reverse without touching any walls or hazards. I would deathmatch friends for hours at a time and got so good at the game that we used play where I would only use my fist but they could use any of the other weapons in the game.  So all of this being said, I am what you would consider a doom professional.

So my Doom professionalism was a bit skeptical with the newly released 2016 Doom. I got flash backs of Doom3 which was horrible and was not Doom at all but more of a Fear meets Quake. Well I can tell you that Bethesda (whom acquired id Software), did a spectacular job of capturing the essence of the original Doom and did the original coders some justice.

This endorsement is not made as a Doom/id fan boi but as someone who played the original so much that I could almost play by sound alone and remember the emotions and energy the game created in a player and this new Doom has that. I think we have all said this before if the game developer would only upgrade the graphics and sound to todays standards but leave the game play the way it was in the past

Anyone who has played the original Doom or Doom II

reviewText:
So after the whole fiasco with the multiplayer beta, I admit I was feeling a little worried that ID may have dropped the ball with this game and it was going to be one of the biggest dissappointments of the year. But after getting my hands on it and playing through the campaign, I've never been happier to say I was wrong. This is Doom the way it should be: Light on story, very heavy on action, gore and challenging difficulty. Even if you only get it for the single player (like I did), you won't be dissapointed at all. Not only is it insanely fun, it's highly replayable with plenty of secrets to find, upgrades to unlock and loads of demons for you to kill. I especially love all the nods to the original games they've tossed in throughout the campaign.

This is also one of the most well optimized games I've ever played. I was somewhat worried my 970 wouldn't allow me to really push this game's graphics (especially after seeing the gameplay previews) but I was pleasantly surprised when I was able to turn all the settings up to ultra and still achieve a smooth, stable framerate even during seriously intense battles. It's good to see a developer who still cares about their PC players and isn't just giving us a shoddy console port.

So if you loved the original Doom games and wanna get back to killing hordes of demons, quit reading this and just buy the game already.

reviewText:
TL;DR for those in a hurry. Few edits after finishing SP and playing some MP.
PROS:
+Looks good and runs good
+Combat fairly quickly ramps up into fast paced action reminiscent of older style FPS games
+Movement is fast and feels good
+The boss fights are all pretty fun and, more importantly, varied
+All the weapons feel unique and have their uses/quirks
+The soundtrack when in a big fight gets you pumped, has a very Djent sound to it mixed with some techno (which I could've done without but what can you do)
+All the old school enemies are back and they've been revamped to (in general) be much more dangerous. ♥♥♥♥ pinkie demons.
+There's a decent number of callbacks to the original games
+They expand on the lore of the Doom Marine and his origins which I found interesting
+The environments are all stylized and quite nice
+Lots of discoverable secrets
+Mu♥♥♥♥ing Super Shotty
+SP DLC maybe? Sequel? Too early to tell

Cons
-No offense to Bethesda, but we all know the glitches that happen with their dead bodies. Only had two freak out so far but it does happen.
-There's a good bit of handholding going on in the beginning. In 5 hours of playing I only died from enemies twice, and one of those times was introducing a new enemy at the tail end of those 5 hours. EDIT: In the late game the difficulty both gets harder and gets a little easier at the same time. Harder cause you're fighting many more big guys at one time and a little easier because of some of the runes/weapon mods. You will die later on.
-Outside of big fights the soundtrack is virtually non existent

Neutral Points (things that you may or may not like):
+/-I've heard people say the multiplayer is great and others say it's not so great, yet to try it myself. EDIT: After playing a few games myself the multiplayer isn't bad. It's not quite as continuously fast paced as the single player because of the max player count/map size but It's still enjoyable with only a few minor issues so far. All in all I enjoyed the games and plan on playing it again.
+/-The platforming sections are mostly meh, particularly the longer ones. They're not especially challenging and mostly just serve as a way to break up the action and as filler.
+/-Glory Kills seem to be liked or hated, I'm neutral on them
+/-There's not a whole lot of story, but you're playing Doom. What did you expect?
+/-This game, much like the originals and older FPS games, has a predicatble pattern to the levels in that it mostly devolves into: kill, go hit button/pick up key/whatever, go to thing that you can now open, repeat. Thankfully the fights are fun enough that it works but some people may not like it.
+/-The levels aren't as maze-y as they were in the original Dooms.

Onto the in depth review.

There's not much to say about this game that it doesn't say for itself. It's Doom and it feels like a modern take of the original Doom. Combat is fun and while it doesn't start too fast paced it quickly picks up speed until you're fighting a couple revenants, a summoner, a hell knight, some imps, and some zombie dudes as you switch between weapons spraying them into the mass of bodies while sprinting and double jumping out of the way of the various projectiles coming at you. It's fun in the way only an old school FPS title like Doom or Serious Sam could be fun.

The weapons themselves are all pretty fun, my only complaint is that the base shotgun feels pretty wimpy and later on you'll just be using it for it's special fire mode. But the Super Shotgun more than makes up for this by being just as devastating as before, potentially even more so. Besides that you have the Pistol, Chainsaw, Heavy Machinegun, Chaingun, Rocket Launcher, Plasma Rifle, Gauss Cannon, and the BFG. Each one has a couple different mods that you can unlock and put points into to improve their versatility in combat and then upgrade further from there. All in all, they all feel different and unique and you'll really want to use all of them in some way. One downside is that your ammo count starts out very measly with the shotgun only being able to hold 20 shells and you have to use collectible items to increase that count. This wouldn't be an issue if it wasn't for the fact that those collectibles could also be used to raise your max health or armor as well. Personally, I just maxed out ammo before putting any into anything else.

On to Glory Kills. People seem to be fairly torn about them with a lot of people not liking them. Admittedly, they are kind of annoying in the beginning because a big push is made for them in the first couple missions instead of just letting them happen. But I quickly got used to them, and some are fairly fun to do in that Mortal Kombat Fatality kind of way. Like grabbing a guy by the leg when he's on the ground and then shoving his own foot into his face so hard his head explodes. Or ripping someone's arm off and slapping them across the face with their own hand. There is a lot of them as well with different ones triggering based on where you aim at on the enemy, with one enemy having at least 4 different ones based on if you aim for the head, legs, back, or arms. The downside is that you're likely to only end up seeing a couple for each class on any sort of regular basis. But, if the various reviews are anything to go by you'll either be ok with them or hate them, so be warned.

My only real issue with the game so far is that there are certain times where it seems like they're trying to make the game too easy. If you're low on health and gib a lower level guy they erupt in about 50 health, more if it was a glory kill. They do the same for ammo, though it's only one ammo drop per kill. These sorts of things kinda take the challenge out of the game, especially in the earlier levels. Later on this becomes much less of an issue because there's less little guys and your fights are often against a lot of bigger guys who can deliver a beat down if you're not careful. But, all the smaller pickups on the map respawn after a set amount of time or you go far enough way and come back, I'm not sure which. This means that there's a lot of times where you could go forward, get in a fight, and then retrace your steps back to ammo, armor, and health pickups and be totally fine. While this isn't an issue unless you abuse it, it is seriously easy to abuse. EDIT: In the late game enemies spawning health when you're low can be a godsend in the middle of a big fight. I'm still not sure if it was necessary considering the respawning supplies but later on it does help.

EDIT: The multiplayer is actually pretty fun. It's not as hectic as the singleplayer, though some of that might have to do with the lack of music. However, the lack of it feeling fast paced doesn't have anything to do with the game's mechanics (because they're the same from the singleplayer) but it seems to have more to do with map size and max number of players. Ultimately, the matches would feel more hectic and fast paced if the maps were a bit smaller and the teams a bit bigger. As is you can go without seeing someone in a full lobby of TDM for a minute or more, which in an arena shooter is a bit weird. Albeit going a full minute without seeing someone is a bit out of the ordinary but it happened about once a game for me. That is fairly excusable, but the main issue I think a lot of people will have is that the weapons aren't all equal. Guns like the heavy machine gun and sniper are likely to just sit in your arsenal never to be used while the Super Shotty, Rocket Launcher, and Chaingun will likely make it into every loadout and you will certainly see every one of those used by your enemies every game. That said, it's still pretty fun and worth playing a few games of.

In the end, I would reccomend it. It's fun to play with good action and just enough of story/background lore to keep you interested. All in all I think it deserves an 8.5/10.

reviewText:
It’s been 12 years since Doom 3’s release and now we have a new Doom title that drops the flashlight mechanic and follows its predecessors’ footsteps more closely. The end result is a beautiful fast-paced shooter with large maps, hidden items, and a robust upgrade system. The game is not without its flaws as it does falter a bit towards the end of the game, uses only a checkpoint system without manual saves, and sometimes the large maps can work against it by slowing the game’s pace down severely depending on a player’s obsession with collecting items and finding secrets.

The duration of the single player seems to be at a decent length as I did finish up by the 10.4 hour mark. That time includes around an hour of staring at the different upgrade screens, consulting the fantastic 3D map for collectible locations, and some unfortunate backtracking I did for some secrets. The latter later made me reconsider my desire to have everything and so I started to ignore collectibles that I could not attain easily. That said I did acquire most of the exploration items and unlocked 2 classic Doom maps which can be selected for play from the main menu after selecting campaign. The hidden levers to unlock them seem fairly obnoxious as they don’t show up on the map at all. I found that trying to search for everything bogs the pacing down and prevents you from doing what the game does best, throwing demons at you for slaying. The game has a level select available should you want to hunt any missing items down. You might wonder why I didn’t just skip more of the exploring from the beginning, but exploration equals power for Doom (2016).

The game heavily incentivizes going off the beaten path within its large levels because many of the exploration items grant upgrade points that can be used to acquire passive abilities, increase base stats like health, unlock weapon mods, or enhance unlocked weapon mods. You can also find plenty of Doom lore, a neat collectible that unlocks models for viewing, and an automap console for revealing the entire map. My personality made me take the map related Praetor armor passive skills first, but you could go for enhanced power-ups or faster weapon switching instead. Rune passives have effects such as enemies drop armor shards after a Glory Kill (melee finisher) or more plentiful ammo drops (I never went without these two). The weapon mods are critical to dealing enough damage to survive. They’re also fun and allow for different playstyles. I greatly enjoyed how the Siege Mode mod of the Gauss Cannon, a personal favorite, let me fire off a destructive piercing shot at the cost of staying still. Line ‘em up, put ‘em down.

While I dearly love the Gauss Cannon and the devastation I can cause with it, most of the other weapons can also hold their own and work together with the various enemy types to create a mostly great combat experience. The combat’s fun owes plenty to its fast movement speed, no reloads, the weapon mods you choose after finding a field drone, and how you upgrade them. Weapon upgrade points are plentiful and you should have more than enough to develop the weapons to your specifications. I had a fully upgraded Super Shotgun for pure power, a Heavy Assault Rifle that could fire Micro Rockets until I ran out of ammo, a rocket launcher with remote detonation, and more. The weapons feel, look, and sound powerful; however, I did think the pistol and regular shotgun were weak contenders that didn’t see much use in my weapon rotation later in the game. That sense of power benefits from enemies losing limbs, turning into bloody chunks, and taking visible damage until the final blow is dealt. While weapon mods allow for diverse gunplay, unlocking the final upgrade for weapon mods can sometimes be a pain since some of them have very specific challenges which impacts pacing. I often had to press TAB, mid-combat, to remind myself of the unlock conditions for several different weapons.

The special weapons and melee finishers do their part too. The chainsaw in Doom functions like a panic button and instantly gives any demon a bad day before making them explode into dozens of little ammo pickups. It’s balanced by a limited supply of fuel. Doomguy also has several weapons available for tossing at the demon horde. The thrown items have a recharge rate, but can also be replenished with the appropriate ammo pickup. Despite my preference for shooting, I did engage heavily with the Glory Kill system in order to stay alive due to the health and armor shard (Rune skill) drops. If you’re on the brink of death, a Glory Kill will produce more health drops, making it vital to success if you’re bad at dodging. The finisher animations did make my eyes grow weary after a while due to the repetition despite how fast they are. I regret not finding the Rune Trial that grants faster Glory Kills.

Doom’s combat pacing felt pretty good for most of the experience as it kept adding a new enemy type at appropriate intervals to keep things from becoming stale and has the occasional boss fight. For the most part, the game’s tempo followed a fight, explore, and fight again type of pattern. Most enemy encounters involved demons spawning into existence for you to battle instead of using monster closets. The spawning could cause some issues since the maps make great use of vertical space, making it more difficult to keep track of enemies. Late in the game, the spawns followed a similar pattern – small guys, medium guys, then large guys – which became monotonous. Far too often, fights would end by taking out the same large demon type. They could have done something with unleashing a horde of one or two enemy types, but I didn’t see that happen. Also, there didn’t seem to be a large number of enemies on screen at the same time. It always felt like 8-10 enemies at most. At least the game ended with a decent boss fight to help me forget.

The other two modes don’t seem to add much to the experience for me. SnapMap looks like it’ll need more time before the really good stuff becomes featured. I’m interested in what a co-op experience might look like with friends. The multiplayer has some fun modes, but Freeze Tag is ruined by Vortex Rifles which can one hit kill players with a full charge. It doesn’t help that the mode can end faster than the intermission time limit of 90 seconds between matches. Team Deathmatch made me wish I bought Overwatch because the gameplay just does not feel right with a loadout system. It’s not a good fit for this title. I would have greatly preferred weapon pickups, especially since the Rocket Launcher feels abnormally weak and doesn’t knock players around. War Path caught my attention and is my favorite mode because it’s a bit different, like Freeze Tag. I like the idea of a moving zone that needs to be captured and defended.

Okay, here are some other things I want to touch on before giving a conclusion: the game’s performance is a rock solid 60fps on ultra with a GTX 970, i7 4790K, and 8GBs of RAM; textures will sometimes be slow to load, allowing for a retro feel; scroll bars can be buggy for descriptions/lore; Darin De Paul’s voice gives my ears pleasure; I like this Doom much more than Doom 3; Multiplayer, Campaign, and SnapMap all use different executables and selecting one requires a restart; finally, you can hold down Shift to walk, but I don’t know why anyone would use it.

Doom can easily provide a mostly great experience so long as you don’t caught up with collecting everything in one go and really enjoy shooting demons. Otherwise, the copy/paste enemy spawning during the final areas of the game might annoy certain players. SnapMap has potential. The multiplayer portion doesn’t seem well-thought-out. The single player is the main draw for this game.

reviewText:
So after the whole fiasco with the multiplayer beta, I admit I was feeling a little worried that ID may have dropped the ball with this game and it was going to be one of the biggest dissappointments of the year. But after getting my hands on it and playing through the campaign, I've never been happier to say I was wrong. This is Doom the way it should be: Light on story, very heavy on action, gore and challenging difficulty. Even if you only get it for the single player (like I did), you won't be dissapointed at all. Not only is it insanely fun, it's highly replayable with plenty of secrets to find, upgrades to unlock and loads of demons for you to kill. I especially love all the nods to the original games they've tossed in throughout the campaign.

This is also one of the most well optimized games I've ever played. I was somewhat worried my 970 wouldn't allow me to really push this game's graphics (especially after seeing the gameplay previews) but I was pleasantly surprised when I was able to turn all the settings up to ultra and still achieve a smooth, stable framerate even during seriously intense battles. It's good to see a developer who still cares about their PC players and isn't just giving us a shoddy console port.

So if you loved the original Doom games and wanna get back to killing hordes of demons, quit reading this and just buy the game already.

reviewText:
The king is back.
id has done a fanstastic job on recreating the DOOM franchise. SnapMap and the single player campaign is what truely makes this game. Some may find the multiplayer to be fun, but it's definetly not on par with what the single player and multiplayer has to offer. Considering it was developed by a third party, it shows.

For anybody that has played Quake 1, 2, 3, 4, any Wolfenstein, and any previous Doom title prepare to have one hell of a time. I've just about completed the storyline on Ultra-Violence (step below Nightmare / Ultra-Nightmare) and it's an absolute masterpiece as far as an arena shooter goes. For those that aren't into those types of titles or haven't played any game like this, this is the game to start or try again with (as far as 2016 goes).

tl;dr - Enjoyed 90's shooters? Brings that back and more. Beware of the multiplayer as a third party developed it and is not as strong as the campaign.

reviewText: Fast paced fun. Slammin soundtrack and tonnes of fun. The 3D map is a little confusing and easy to get turned around while  roaming, but I found if you reload last checkpoint seems to help. Lots of new and innovative things with a lot of old school DOOM mixed in, I think they did an amazing job of a reboot of sorts. Its more deserving of the name DOOM than DOOM 4. I feel you'll have to be a certain age to understand that one though. I played the original DOOM when it first came out. Don't get me wrong I loved DOOM 3, but it was a step away from the original DOOM. But this one is a step ahead, if I had to choose words to describe it. To me personally, its much more than I expected. For any FPS fan its a must buy!

reviewText:
I had a good feeling about this one.

The single player campaign is the real stand out here and a return to form for those of us missing actual gameplay in our games. There is a story here, but its mostly told through 'codex' entries that pop up as enemies are killed and objectives completed. 'Cutscenes' are very few and far between, minor ones being completely ignorable (just walk away) and major ones not lasting longer than a few minutes (a sparse handful throughout the game with the biggest and the start, middle and ending).

The combat? A glorious dance of death. Anyone who has been following id Software for some time knows they've put a lot of work into animating their enemies. Say what you will about RAGE, for instance, but the enemies 'danced' around the enviornment in wonderful ways, bouncing off walls, dodging, ducking and weaving about. That animation was built upon heavily in Doom 4. Imps leap up onto walls and hurl fireballs, Hell Knights leap through the air hulk smashing the ground and so on. When you have an arena filled with enemies dodging about as you frantically tear through the map dodging and weaving yourself to find better vantage points you'll realize what modern shooters have been missing for years.

About the only negative I can give the single player is the glory kill system. While its not that bad and really doesn't hurt the flow of the game it is a very important component. When your health falls to critical levels in an arena and you have collected all the health pickups? You NEED a glory kill. Completely out of ammo in that arena? Time for a chainsaw kill.

Multiplayer? I'm personally having a lot of fun with it. If you played the Beta and disliked it because of lack of content? You will probably like the full version as there are numerous demons, maps, weapons and customization options available that were not in the Beta. If on the other hand you simply did not like how it played... the full version will not change how you feel. Glad to say that while the game has 'prestiges' (echelons) you do NOT lose any items or customizations so you are looking at 500 levels of customization drops (you get all equipment and weapons by 17)!

SnapMap is a bit disappointing as you can not actually build individual rooms and have to work with presets. There simply is not enough content available and there are questionable assets from single player not given to the player. Why no Cyberdemon or Summoner? Why no Pistol or Chainsaw? Why is only a single tileset available (No Hell tileset!?)? Hopefully as time goes on they add more functionality and content to SnapMap. I am having fun designing a remake of an old Doom campaign but I've had to dramatically lower my expectations for how accurate and true to the original it will be. Forget any sort of accurate remakes of Doom 1 or 2 maps.

All in all a ton of great content in this package. I really dove into the single player and have had an absolute blast with it and can see myself going back and trying on other difficulties (the collectibles took quite a while to find). The mp wont be for everyone but if you vary your loadouts it can offer a lot of fun. SnapMap has potential and already some imaginative and cool scenarios have been released. No regrets for a day one purchase and I hope you enjoy it too!

reviewText:
The Good: Doom's campaign is a blast. While somewhat repetitive the run and gun gameplay is as satisfying and addictive as ever. Lots of collectibles and challenges will certaly make you replay some levels.

The Bad: Snapmap, in concept, is a great idea and in fact it does allow the creation of some interesting maps and mechanics. However, the more you mess with it the more you realize how restricted is the editor. It doesn't, in any way, make up for the lack of mod support.

The Ugly: The MP feel like a completely different game. The mix of a level progression system and loadouts with arena maps and pickups is , in my opinion, one of the worst possible things they could come up with. Demon runes are also terribly unbalanced, specially if you have unlocked the greater demons. It doesn't just feel like a Halo game - it feels like a BAD Halo game.

But, should you play Doom? Yes. Just don't pay full price for it.
For me, the campaign more than makes up for the MP. I can certainly see myself coming back to try the Ultra Nighmare difficulty.

reviewText:
This game is SO good so far. I've beaten the game in Nightmare which was too fun. The story is there if you want it to be, if not you can skip past it. It's the only FPS that i've played (besides the original DOOM's) where you're punished if you try and take it slow, in order to survive you have to be as fast as possible. As you progress through the 13 levels they get bigger and more complex as you go and there's tons of secret areas, challanges, hidden pathways and doors for you to discover.

I'm currently half way through the second level on ultra-nightmare, I'm too chicken to go any further until I practice this level some more in nightmare.

The weapon and armor upgrade system lets you play how you want to when you want to.

The graphics are top-notch if you have the GPU horsepower to push it on ultra settings.

Replay value is huge with ultra-nightmare, snapmap, and a solid multiplayer.

Doom was my first game as a kid, here we are more than 20 years later and it's better than ever. I love this game so much that this is the first review I've written. Rip and tear.

reviewText:
*Note this is for the SP campaign (completed on Ultra-Violence) as I won't be playing MP.

DOOM 4 is a unbelievably WICKED game that not only stands up to the Doom legacy, but also proves itself as a very fun FPS and looks amazing while doing it.

The gameplay definetely has that old-school vibe to it, as instead of sitting in cover waiting for regenerating health, you are moving around really quickly, strafe-jumping and bunny-hopping to try to avoid getting horribly murdered by demons. Just after halfway through the campaign you can expect to be fighting many of the highly tough demons at once (though not as extreme as the Serious Sam games) that will require that you be very skillfull and effecient in the way you approach combat. The glory kill (melee) system, although lamented by many, isn't really a problem as it doesn't really break the flow of gameplay. Powerups make a great return to Doom by making certain battles easier, such as being able to decapitate demons with your fists

The redesign of the demons is just AMAZING. Many of them look and sound creepy as hell (especially the lost souls) and can definitely kill you very quickly if you are not paying attention, especially those pinky demons. The boss fights are not that easy but aren't extremely hard either, its just as simple as shooting at it until it dies and trying not to get killed, like the rest of the gameplay in DOOM 4.

Nobody should care about the story (*its a doom game for crying out loud) as it just disrupts the flow whenever there is a story segment with lots of talking.

The weapons look awesome and feel very satifying to use, except for the starting pistol. There is also a system where you can purchase and upgrade alt-fire modes on certain weapons, such as a triple shotgun burst, or a micro-missile launcher attached to a Machine Gun, which makes the weapons even more fun to use. The Chainsaw is of limited use at times but my god, it is so much fun to use as each evisceration spawns all this ammo and health everywhere. The BFG just destroys everything as it usually does, need I say more?

The level design returns to the exploration based maze like labryinth of sorts where you are constantly navigating a non-linear path. The game also places an emphasis on finding secrets so you can get the bigger weapons earlier, or getting such goodies like suit upgrades for doomguy or increases to health capacity.  The HUD also includes a compass so you can't really get lost.

The only qualms I really had with this game was a lack of quicksave function (annoying when finding dangerous secrets) and the music was a bit.. ehh... for my taste.

Despite my rig just barely scraping past the minium requirements, performance was good enough for me to enjoy this beast of a game from start to finish.

All in all I highly recommend this game to pretty much any FPS nut as it is a wonderful return to form for the Doom franchise after what happened with Doom 3.

reviewText:
I played the game now for around two hours and I must say, I'm super impressed. I know the game will be good. But so far it reached beyond my expectations.

Gameplay:
The games runs smooth and the combat is fast and fluid, it just feels right. As soon as a fight starts you're into a flow. It's a ton of fun to jump in the demon horde and decimate them with your weapons and meele attacks. The fights are also very gory, what is perfect for this game. The melee attacks are also fast and matches the combat style of the game, you wont get stopped or loose your flow when you finish of your enemies with a glory kill. (name of the melee attacks)

Graphic:
In short: AWESOME.
In longer: The game looks absolutly fantastic. I'm not playing with everything on max and I was totaly stunned by the magnificence grafic. One of the best looking games I played so far. You will love it. And so far, I had absolutly no stutters or anything like that.
The animations of your character and the enemies are absoluty smooth and stunning. The world, the weapons, your enemies and everything else just matches each other perfectly. What is also important, it looks and feels like Doom. If you had no idea what game you are going to play, after the first 5-10 seconds you would know that you are in Doom.

Sound:
Great! The weapons are sounding powerfull like they are. You will hear and feel every hit on your enemies or on yourself. The music pushed you, and alone trough their noise you will know what enemies you are up to.
Beside that, the world itself has the right sound, if some machine is working near you, when metal breaks or you are in an elevator. If you are on the surface of Mars or on the station or listen to some npc. There is nothing so far I could complain about. It fits perfectly together.
-----

I can totaly recommend DOOM to everyone that likes fast paced shooters with an awesome atmosphere. You won't find anything better at the moment.

I can't say anything about the Multiplayer so far, since I didnt played it yet.
