reviewText:
a brain dead shooter that's all about the spectacle and making the player feel good and powerful

I wouldn't mind this game being as easy and mindless shootman game that it is if it weren't bogged down by ♥♥♥♥♥♥ challenges and manditory secrets that force you out of playing how you wanna play cuz u gotta get 5 leg sweeps on a hellboy or farm zombos for 30 double kills to get those sweet weapon upgrades and masteries.

upgrades and masteries that turn your guns into all-arounders totally taking away that interesting juggle that the older games have. There is really no need to switch from the shotgun once you got the grenade mod for example, the only reason you'll be switching weapons is because a gun got boring or you ran out of ammo (which is like really no issue with the game having monsters spew ammo at you when youre low+ the chainsaw instantly filling you up)

and the monsters, they look really cool and all. Very animated and have a lot of character, you kind of just fight them all the same way, they all act the same in regards to how you fight them. The only enemies I can think of that change the way you want to deal with a situation is the shield zombiemen and pinkies, the only enemies where it might be useful to switch to a gun like the rocketlauncher and detonate a rocket behind them or the plasma rifle and using the stun to disable the zombieman's shield or to allow you to more easily get behind that pinky. Every other critter is just basicly shoot at with the gun you think kills the coolest.

and I dislike this new chainsaw, it's reward with no risk. It's just a way to circumvent an enemy you don't want to fight or instantly refill your prefered weapon.

and the bfg is just a boring room clearer that has none of the interesting nuances that that classic had. Just another way to circumvent a fight that you just wanna blow through. (the thing is also hilarious with the fully mastered ammo rune, almost guarenteeing you'll get a free bfg cell if you blast the thing in a full room making near every arena fight trivial)

The multiplayer too is like easy trash that makes halo look like UT and snapmap is this really unituitive mess, for sure people have already started making interesting things but god it's unapproachable to me. lol

I got a lot more to say about what i don't like with this game but I guess i'll stop here. lol


Man like it's cool that id scrapped the call of doom build of the game and tried making what they thought was more faithful to the originals. I feel that they are all probably fans of the original but had misconceptions of what made those games good and made what is basicly a less creepy and terrible brutal doom.


I'll go ahead and give this a recommendation I guess. I am crazy critical over the game but there is some stuff that i did have fun with and I'll be fooling around with snapmap, see if i can actually wrap my head around it. lol

reviewText:
Pretty fun game. Campaing is good, it's fast with non stop action. Gameplay feels good. Map desing is ok. It's a bit short, if you are quick you can beat it in around 2h. Optimalization is great, on my gtx970 with ultra settings I have 100+fps all the time. There are some things I didn't like; closed areas and enemies coming in waves, that is just bad or that there are only 3 boss fights in whole game.

Multiplayer is garbage. Someone didn't know how to make arena shooter and consoles were main target for this game so we got this pos. Weapons are imbalanced, demons are imbalanced, map design is bad, there is no dm or ctf, everyting feels slow, there are loadouts, you can't pick up enemy weapon, it also have diffrent controls than campaing. The rounds are very short and you have to wait in lobby 90 seconds after every match(wtf?) + 25 seconds after the game loads and another 10 seconds after match ends, that is a huge waste of time for no reason at all. Overall DOOM multiplayer is very bad.

SnapMap is a build in map editor, but due it's big limitations(thanks consoles) it's meh. You have limits for everything you place on the map. You can place around 50 demons in one map and that is just not enough. Same goes for other objects etc. You can make maps for singleplayer, multiplayer or coop. There is also limit of totall 4 players for coop and multi. I can understand that more that 4 ppl in coop mission would be too much, but only 4 ppl for multiplayer?! CTF 2vs2, yay...

Summary:
Singleplayer 8/10
Multiplayer 1/10
SnapMap 2/10

Only campaing was worth it.

reviewText:
Wow, friggin wow!!!
id Software nailed it! This game feels amazingly smooth. What a breath of fresh air.
I've played about 5 hours of the campaign with mouse and keyboard and about 2 hours with an xbox one controller and both ways of playing the game feel great. The single player is out of this world. Action packed with the old rat fighting it's way out of the maze feeling. The level design alone is killer. The levesl have the best of the multiplayer arena feel with the hugeness of the Doom universe. Lock downs are fun and feel satisfying to complete.
Multiplayer is great as well IF you are in to arena shooters. This isn't CSGO or CoD. It's Doom and it's SO good. I like the little things too, like customization of the player and weapon skins. Maps are great and feel just right. Not to big or small and tend to focus fights through out the arena. Overall, an amazing release when other developers and publishers consistantly put out half completed and borken games. Doom feels like it's polished to a mirror finish.
The options are pelentyfull and greatly appreciated. FOV slider/console cmd's worth it's weight in digital gold.
Dang, guys, thanks. I needed this.
P.S.
Thanks for the console. Quake in my blood. r_picmip 9000+
Also, Quake 5, make it happen!!!

reviewText: I'm a long time fan of the doom franchise, and this game represents an authentic love letter to us fan. The gameplay flows perfectly...even the glory kills are incredibly natural and satisfying (and i was very skeptical at first), the atmosphere is incredibile, the graphics and presentation is top notch...but most of all...this game is just fun! I'm really impressed that a game that carries such a big heritage on his shoulders came out this good. You can see clearly that the developers knew exactly what they were doing and knew what the fans wanted. There's a ton of content and replay value in this game (all the secrets, weapon/gear upgrades, snapmap mode ecc...)...not to mention the multiplayer, which i'm really enjoying so far with its modern but also old-school game feel (there's no regenerative health and you have to stay on the move constantly). I kinda wish there were more maps...and maybe if they had a more flashy design... but again, there's a lot of content to love and appreciate in this game and they really did a great job overall. Hell yeah, Doom is back!

reviewText:
Currently this review is being written from a preliminary view at the games campaign ONLY and not with any influence from the multiplayer and the beta.

The campaign is very well structured from the outset with the opening clearly forgiving the player if they lack controls knowledge and throughout the first level gives pointers as to what every part is and aims the player at looking in every corner and every area of the maps which the game offers. The graphics for the game are excellent even if you play on medium and low and whether you play on the highest or lowest, you are able to enjoy the game without having issues with low graphics like some games have. The enemies in the game are often tough and annoying at times but the game gives you tips on how to tackle each of the 36 enemies you will face throughout your time in the game.

From a campaign point of view, story is a 7, graphics are an 8 and overall feel of the game is a 9. Definitely worth checking this game out. Will update this review when and if I move on to the multiplayer. Would recommend on grounds of campaign only.

The levesl have the best of the multiplayer arena feel with the hugeness of the Doom universe. Lock downs are fun and feel satisfying to complete.
Multiplayer is great as well IF you are in to arena shooters. This isn't CSGO or CoD. It's Doom and it's SO good. I like the little things too, like customization of the player and weapon skins. Maps are great and feel just right. Not to big or small and tend to focus fights through out the arena. Overall, an amazing release when other developers and publishers consistantly put out half completed and borken games. Doom feels like it's polished to a mirror finish.
The options are pelentyfull and greatly appreciated. FOV slider/console cmd's worth it's weight in digital gold.
Dang, guys, thanks. I needed this.
P.S.
Thanks for the console. Quake in my blood. r_picmip 9000+
Also, Quake 5, make it happen!!!

reviewText:
I grew up on the DOOM series so had a mixture of excitement and slight cynicism when this reboot was announced. The new DOOM is really an homage to the first two DOOM games. It doesn't fully feel like an old DOOM game, it is more akin to Quake 2 in DOOM's clothes, however when it comes down to it the game is a huge amount of fun and packed full of intense fighting. This is the most fun I have had in a FPS for several years.

The story of DOOM doesn't matter, and the developers even purposefully show this. The marine is voiceless and portrayed as an impatient, violent, individual who just wants to get on with it. He will constantly punch, stomp and break terminals, droids and screens after their use has outlived their purpose. DOOM has very few cut scenes (basic monster introductions) and dialogue is minimal. Straight away you are thrown into fighting, the glory-kill system and other features are throw at you in mere minutes and then you are on you way killing demons and hell spawn. Most of the iconic enemies return from the series, minus the spidery/horror based enemies from DOOM 3. Speaking of DOOM 3, this is nothing like DOOM 3. It is not a horror game regardless of the excellent lighting effects and environments. This game is meant to be played at full speed, running into enemies and later on leaping and hopping around to avoid damage and chaining together glory-kills. If you try to creep and walk through this you will be killed quickly.

id Software have provided large, multi-level maps to play around in. They have packed them with combat areas that lock down when entered due to demon infestation, hidden away collectables, secrets and PDAs that detail the back story a bit more, and created sprawling platforms and walkways to clamber to different vantages. You can get lost in these environments but usually if there are no demons, you are not heading off track. One thing I enjoyed about this game is there is no nagging commander or comrade telling you where to head next. There is no floating icon stuck on-screen showing you the next door to enter, it does have a compass that shows distance to objectives but it is not in your face. There is a map too. I can't recall the last time I used a map in game to hunt for areas I had not visited. It is getting back to old school FPS shooters, which admittedly some people may think is a backwards step. I just think it is a welcome change to the normal current set of shooters.

There is a distinct rhythm that forms playing DOOM which is backed by a pulsating, hard, aggressive soundtrack that gets the adrenaline flowing. There have been moments in fighting where I have unconsciously held my breath due to the intensity cranking up through the gears to near fever pitch. The rhythm is helped by the enemies that all have been adjusted and tweaked from older games. The imps are truly brilliant as introductory demons. They clamber and swing up pillars and walkways like chimpanzees throwing fireballs in a variety of ways that keep you on your toes. The main zombies aren't too dissimilar from each other but are basic cannon fodder, the pinky demons are now armoured from the front and cause horrid damage, as do the floating cacodemons that sink down from the skies and fire lightning at you. This means that during battles there is a lot going and to contend with. You try to focus on the larger or powerful enemies only to be flanked and slapped from behind from an imp. It sounds annoying but you get used to being on your toes and leaping through gaps in the enemies to head for the power ups that are placed in levels. Power ups like Berserk which grant you the ability to one-kill punch and rip any enemy, or Quad-damage that multiples your damage by four. There is a Haste power up that increases your movement and fire rate. All these items just stir the action into whirlwind of violence.

This game is an absolute blast from start to finish. It has been designed to be a mindless shooter" and enhanced to perform its duty. Weapons are upgradable and even your armour can be modified to assist you later in game. The equipment such as grenades and teleporters I found to be of no use as they were just one button to far away to recall in battle. The chainsaw and BFG are now used more out of desperation as they have their own key assignments. The chainsaw is used to take down large enemies which spew out ammo and health like a piñata. I thought I would hate this feature of demons releasing health and ammo when you are in the red but its something I accepted. There are moments and sections of the new DOOM that aren't great however. The multi-player for example just doesn't have the depth of the arena shooter it is trying to be. I am not bothered either way about the customisation as that doesn't affect my view
date: its just the matches get tedious quickly. I don't want to play through the modes and it fails to come anywhere near the greats of Unreal or Quake. The campaign also has a few filler moments where you have to collect another hellish item before you can proceed to the end. Overall the maps are good fun but the environments can start to blend into one and other towards the end of the game. It is to be expected really as the campaign took me nearly 17 hours. There are a few nitpicks here and there such as colour coded doors not being as visible across maps as in the originals
recommended: the heavy machine gun feels a bit redundant as it turns into a small rocket spewing gun
hoursPlayed: its the same with the chain gun as it slows you down. Finally early in the game can feel a bit of a chore as it involves clearing the areas of demon nests.\n\nDOOM is a highly polished
voteText: slick game that it fun and a blast to play through. There are small darkly humorous moments hidden in the ways you can die and nods to the older id and Bethesda games. I get id's enthusiasm that was shown in all the marketing campaigns and it does manage to live up to most of the claims. It is better than Wolfenstein New Order and only marred by multi-player and a few cheap deaths here and there. Snapmap is a nice edition and I am currently messing around with creating basic maps and modes. A very solid 8.5/10."

reviewText:
It's a return to the roots of the franchise, monster's design and gameplay really take me back to my childhood when i used to play Doom and Doom 2 in my old Pentium 1 120Mhz. Maybe there isn't any deep story and that kind of things, but is really funny and addictive, is like all the old classic games from 90s, the important thing is the fun factor.

The single player is for me a 10/10. Pretty addictive macho marine badass simulator.

Multiplayer.... Meh, kinda mediocre, there are lots of better multiplayer games... can only give a 5/10 in this section.

SnapMap, simple and effective... is a cool idea but i think it's feels a bit uncomplete, anyway at least they had the balls to implement this kind of editor to the game, 90% of the games doesn't bother about this things. 8/10

Final Score: 8,5/10      Recommended specially for the campaign mode.

reviewText:
Pretty fun game. Campaing is good, it's fast with non stop action. Gameplay feels good. Map desing is ok. It's a bit short, if you are quick you can beat it in around 2h. Optimalization is great, on my gtx970 with ultra settings I have 100+fps all the time. There are some things I didn't like; closed areas and enemies coming in waves, that is just bad or that there are only 3 boss fights in whole game.

Multiplayer is garbage. Someone didn't know how to make arena shooter and consoles were main target for this game so we got this pos. Weapons are imbalanced, demons are imbalanced, map design is bad, there is no dm or ctf, everyting feels slow, there are loadouts, you can't pick up enemy weapon, it also have diffrent controls than campaing. The rounds are very short and you have to wait in lobby 90 seconds after every match(wtf?) + 25 seconds after the game loads and another 10 seconds after match ends, that is a huge waste of time for no reason at all. Overall DOOM multiplayer is very bad.

SnapMap is a build in map editor, but due it's big limitations(thanks consoles) it's meh. You have limits for everything you place on the map. You can place around 50 demons in one map and that is just not enough. Same goes for other objects etc. You can make maps for singleplayer, multiplayer or coop. There is also limit of totall 4 players for coop and multi. I can understand that more that 4 ppl in coop mission would be too much, but only 4 ppl for multiplayer?! CTF 2vs2, yay...

Summary:
Singleplayer 8/10
Multiplayer 1/10
SnapMap 2/10

Only campaing was worth it.

reviewText:
Well, I am about 9 hours in on PC and about 15 hours in on my PS4, giving me around 24 hours of gameplay time in both the campaign and multiplayer. What can I say? DOOM is BACK!!!

First off... I'd like to start by saying my opinion of the MP in the game: IT IS GREAT!!!
I seriously DO NOT understand all of the negative comments towards the MP. It is super competitive and feels like it was made for tournament style matches. Aka - serious gamers! It gets your blood pumping, and it satisfies so much more than the last several popular franchises' FPS games that have been released that are just garbage. The fact that your health doesn't regenerate and you can actually run out of ammo (picking up health, armour, and ammo packs from pickups on the map) gives it such a new and fresh edge while also feeling very classic like DOOM should feel. I don't know... I absolutely love it, and so does everyone that I have talked to, except for, apparently, people on Steam...

So enough about the divide of folks with the MP... Let's touch on the campaign a bit. Again I will say... DOOM IS BACK!!!

I honeslty can't believe they did it... but DOOM has been rebooted, and it delivers something fierce. The graphics, mechanics, customization, and even the story are all spectacular. I don't want to spoil anything, but I can easily say that this is the best SP campaign of any FPS I have played in years, especially since the release of the next-gen" of gaming. Another aspect of the game that just puts the icing on the cake is the music... METAL AF!!! There are fight scenes/levels that literally got me so pumped that I started screaming with happiness as I mowed down my foes and sent them back to Hell with my chainsaw and arsenal of weapons! You can't stop moving
date: or you are DEAD!\n\nI could keep going
recommended: but instead all I want to say is BUY THIS GAME! There is NO WAY you'll regret it. If you do
hoursPlayed: you should stop gaming and go read a book...... on how to be a better gamer. Lol. I'm joking. But seriously... Go buy the game.\n\nFIGHT LIKE HELL!"

reviewText:
RECOMMENDED! GET IT!

On top of graphics quality, it's easy to achieve + maintain. I use a single factory-clocked GTX 960, and manage practically Ultra on 1080p (Working on 4k). I had to turn 2 things down 1 notch to achieve my 60 fps, but other than that, Ultra on 1080p.

Gameplay is another aspect that is really well done. It may seem boring watching other people play and uneventful except for the occasional demon hoardes you run into, but trust me, it flows.

Storyline is done pretty similarly to the Ultimate DOOM's, but slightly better explained and characters (besides yourself) have names.

Last thing to brag about is how much tribute it pays to the older DOOM series. It follows the storyline,  has the throwback secret rooms , and uses almost the exact same guns.

The only thing there is to complain about here is multiplayer. Take COD and HALO, they make a baby, that kid becomes acquaintances with DOOM, and then is brothers with Quake. In a nutshell, not DOOM. I absolutely hate the multiplayer. Could have been done so much better. But besides that, WONDERFUL game, GREAT JOB ID! LOVE IT!

reviewText:
No need to say what many others have already said, but I will add one thing. This will sound outlandish--far from conciliatory--but it is true for me (even as someone that grew up playing the original Doom as shareware):

This feels more like Doom than the original does.

This release incorporates the essence of what defined the original, and works out a personality so strong that makes it feel like this is what Doom was meant for all along.  The design is smart and masterful, and the movement and gunplay is so smooth and interesting--all without weighing down what made Doom so great in the first place.  It's just so naturally fun, there's no room to even think about it.  The campaign just gets better and better the further in... it's really impressive, and has no right to be this great, but here we are.  So relieved. :)

reviewText:
id Software	, I want more of this. Seriously, I hope you are making a sequel, because only few FPS games in the past few years were as entertaining, gory and fun to play as your DooM.
Gameplay? Gunplay is fluid, smooth and precise. Health packs, armors, ammo, no regeneration, quad damage, challenges, secrets... it´s all there as you remember. The level design is what praised my gamer soul the most. No linear ♥♥♥♥, lot of vertical maps and dark corners. I love it. Yeah and chainsaw FTW!
Graphics? Overall atmosphere is awesome. If you look on the textures from a small vicinity, it´s not as sharp as you would expect, but the overall impression is splendid.
Sound? If you would have your eyes blinded, you would still know exactly who is attacking and what gun you are using. Great work sound guys!
Music?	 Metal gory hell with infernal vocals. Master Eploder lvl 9000
Story? It´s there.

I can´t even express how glad I am that new Doom is so awesome, polished, well optimized and FUN to play. It´s nothing like Doom 3 (although I liked D3). This is really a throwback to the times when FPS was about speed, fast fingers and will to beat that last mofo boss. And then to start the game again on higher difficulty. I know I will.
If you are a long time FPS fan who like Quake, Shadow Warrior, Wolfenstein etc ... you will be everything but dissapointed.

9/10 (I would love to have 2 or 3 levels more with more bosses)

reviewText:
In it's current state, this game is completely unplayable to me. It took several attempts to open it without the company intros to stop chugging like an 1850's steam engine. I could barely navigate the menu at the 1-2 frames per second I was getting. I sat through the opening of the campaign in hopes that the red symbol was some sort of loading screen, but alas; the local, non-internet based, fully installed CAMPAIGN was chugging along at barely 3 frames per second. I didn't even make it a full minute before I had to force quit because of the audio loop signalling an oncoming crash.

I want to play this game. I really want to play this game. However in the state it is in right now, I advise no one to buy this game on PC. My experience has not been exclusive and I found many more on PC shared my gripes. Unless you have THE highest end rig, or have a console, do not buy Doom. Yet.

For now, I am refunding this game until I hear otherwise. But like I said Bethesda, I want to give you my money for this game, just please let me play the game in a non-broken state. Or at all for that matter.

reviewText:
*Gnome Seal of Approval*
So far, I'm enjoying this more than I expected. I feared id would continue down the path they took in Doom 3 with dark rooms and corridors, jump scares and a game not in line with the previous installments regarding atmosphere. I didn't mind the darkness so much in Doom 3, I just didn't think it was the right way to go with a Doom game.

In this new Doom game, the levels a brightly lit, the action is fast paced and fluid and your adrenaline is flowing.

This is what Doom 3 should have been!

The level design is fairly non-linear (at least compared to other shooters out there), but with some of the same backtracking we used to do in the original Doom and Doom 2.

The enemies are fun, diverse and nicely modelled and animated.

The weapon and suit upgrading system is fun and encourages exploration and experimentation. The map challenges are some minor goals you can do to earn a few extra upgrading points, but your main source comes from clearing the maps for enemies. This means that casual players can just run through the campaign, yet still earn upgrades. The Rune trials you eventually encounter are yet another way of customizing playstyle and upgrading your character.

The soundtrack also helps to make combat fun and engaging.

So, there's a lot to explore and fun stuff to do! I like it!

There's even classic Doom maps to unlock and play with the new enemies and weapons, but with the classic graphics everywhere else.

My only minor complaint so far is regarding secrets. In early levels, the game lets you backtrack to all areas so you can explore and search for secrets in peace. However, soon enough you will encounter doors that lock the way behind you so you can't go back and look for missed secrets until you finish the level. I've never been a fan of this in any game. If a game have secrets and collectibles, please enable the player to go back and search for them if he/she missed some.

I have not played multiplayer. This is purely a singleplayer review.

reviewText:
I've been a long-time DOOM fan and am really enjoying this release. Wasn't a fan of DOOM 3, but this version takes a lot of calls from DOOM 1 & 2 - it's more fast paced, sillier, and the multiplayer is actually extremely fun. The lack of variety in enemies is kinda eh, but otherwise this has been a really good purchase.

Pros:
- it 'feels' like a member of the franchise, if that makes sense - more than the third game did
- the flow of play is really good - you can clamber around, climb most scenery, combat is fluid and super fast like the old games
- multiplayer is fun & has a lot of customisation options
- the map editor (snapmap) is REALLY awesome and employs a super cool visual scripting function
- A+ multiplayer taunts
- throwbacks to the other games in the franchise
- really good sound design (apart from the repetitive moaning of enemies if you're above them)

Cons:
- the campaign can get a little repetitive, chalking this down to lack of variety of enemies and sometimes glory kill can be OP
- a bit slow to load, but it is a new release

reviewText:
Ill keep it to the point.

Pros.
ID Tech 6 Engine Shines Here. Looks good!
Sound Is Great.
Fast Paced Gory Fun
Weapon Upgrades That Work
Simple Game Play Mechanics. Tight Controls
Nostalgia At Its Best!
Looks like Doom , Sounds Like Doom, Plays Like Doom , Yep Its DOOM!

Most of all its FUN!!!

Cons:
Multiplayer is a Meh...A Bonus really.
Bodies Disappear !!!
Some Low Resolution textures
Limited to 0 Mod Support
Single Player Add On Content?!

This is the Doom game I think people were hoping for and it Delivers in just about every aspect. It hits the important notes it has too !  I had my doubts with the beta but the single player portion (which is really what its all about) is actually really good. It has a few dull or mediacore moments but so far its great! Is it worth the price? Yes!!! is it worth the season pass? Hmm well , I dont think so . Mainly beacues it appears to just add multiplayer content , that content appears sparse to me and for a whopping 40 bucks , i need to see more..

If your a classic fps fan, you cant go wrong here! if your a Doom fan, you already own this anyway ;)

reviewText:
I'm torn apart. The gameplay is great but the game is literally unplayable (right now).

I really like the game itself. It's fun and engaging. I was just recently talking to a friend about games nowadays not having real secret areas like games had 20 years ago. And now D°°M (re)introduced them eventually. Also the weapons upgrades, the whole leveling and powerup-mechanics are really nice. And there are no IAPs (yes, one really has to state that nowadays). There's no in-game currency you can buy outside of the game. Everything needs to be earned by yourself and is not taken from you again.

But: The game crashes. Not just for me but for a lot (!) of people (just search the web). And it crashes in the badest way possible: Without any error message. Just puts you right back to the desktop. The first three levels where fine but now I'm stuck in the fourth level, having to play from my last save game over and over because the game crashes out of nowhere.

So what finally has become the most scariest thing of the game are not the enemies but the constant fear of doing something that will make the game crash. This is the worst that could happen to a game and it fully ruined it for me. I've been playing so many games and none of them crashed. I honestly can't remeber the last game that crashed on my system. And this from the company that owned PC game programming.

That's why I tell my colleagues not to buy Doom and that's why I don't recommend this game. At least not yet. When this is fixed I definitely will return to play it. But until then it's stays literally unplayable.

reviewText:
Okay, I've tried all 3 modes, so I'm gonna give this my utmost review.  I rarely review games, but this one I just had to...
Single Player
I cannot express how much fun I am having on single player, and learning the story of Doomguy (Doom Marine).
I started my fight on Ultra Violence, and I have to say, it's harder than a Barons dense chode!  I cannot wait to try out Nightmare and maybe give Ultra Nightmare a try.
The gameplay is a fast-paced, adrenaline rushed joyride of demon slaying joyfulness.
SP - 10/10
Multiplayer
I waited until I played campaign to go back to Multiplayer, and I truly had a BLAST in the Beta.
After playing a few matches and a few game modes (Warpath, Team Deathmatch, Soul Harvest), I found that some game modes have barely anyone playing.  The only one [gamemode] people are playing is Team Deathmatch, which makes the other game modes harder to try.  Either nobody is really playing or the matchmaking isn't much good(?)
Also, I do have to say I would like better team matching, I was in a team of Me (level 1), two level 2's, two other 1's, and a level 5 against 2 prestiges, and 3 other high levels.  Obviously our team had barely any experience with the maps so they were picking up everything before us and dominated us.
Better team making is obviously what I'd look for, but other than that I enjoyed myself.  Yeah, I have yet to be a demon, too.  Every time I'd slay the enemy demon I'd die and miss the oppurtunity.
MP - 7.5/10
SnapMap
I messed around with making my own map, without learning first, and that's a HUGE mistake.  LEARN THROUGH THE ACADEMY BEFORE TRYING TO MAKE YOUR OWN MAP.
When I went to make my own, I wanted to just see what I was able to do, and there are ENDLESS possibilities.  The amount of tools, accessories, demons, and just large and small items to be placed is so vast.  I can't wait to learn more about it.
SnapMap 9/10

My overall experience has been outstandingly beautiful.
I give this game an overall rating of a 10/10, because between the nostalgia, and the new-age, and all the easter eggs, this game is so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ fun and worth every penny that's been spent on it.

reviewText:
This is definitely one of the best titles i have ever experienced, i was originally a cod player but since that franchise has gone to hell, as we all know, *cough* cod infinite warfare *cough* anyways,  right off the bat you are thrown into combat during the first 10 seconds. Which is always nice to see unlike other games where you are sitting at a cinematic for half an hour.

The most prominent factor of this game is the gore, if you love heads exploding horns being torn off and just in general making demons punching bags then this is the game for you. Throughout the whole of the game you are thrown into thrilling battles with only one goal, to kill everything you see, also there's no denying that the music is freaking awesome, during every battle you will be bombarded with heavy metal music which adds to the adrenaline of the fights. There's nothing like using a chainsaw and ripping apart your enemies while there's some amazing soundtracks in the background.

In this title you can clearly see the effort the devs have put in to make all of the guns look like killing machines which adds to the excitement and thrill of the game, all of the models have a neat finish and have the feel of sheer awesomness.

The campaign in my opinion was very good and i enjoyed it alot, but the multiplayer i feel has alot more potential, at the minute there's not a big variety of weapons that players are able to pick from, the result of this you get people who run around with rocket launchers and shotguns, although that is a downfall of the game i can't deny that being the baron of hell and running around tearing people in half isn't fun.

So even though this game has some multiplayer flaws i would highly advise getting this title, when i first got this game i had really high expectations and DOOM most certainly smashed straight through those expectations and went over and beyond. Basically if you love killing demons listening to intense music and finding easter eggs this is the game for you.

reviewText:
Doom 2016 is very much a 2 part experience:

Singleplayer
=============

Singleplayer is great. It feels right, it has the right atmosphere and gameplay, it's Doom, in the sense of Doom 1/2, with a touch of Doom 3.

Weapons look and feel powerful, player movement suits the singleplayer experience fine, despite being mostly identical to the multiplayer movement. (More on movement later.)
Like previous Doom games, you can carry and switch between your full arsenal of weapons in a moment, as suits the situation you find yourself in.

Melee glorykills are a bit forced; you can't really practically avoid them as gameplay is balanced heavily around them(they cause ammo and health drops as well as offer momentary invulnerability that you often need. You also warp instantly from your lockon point to your glorykill point, making it the fastest means of moving between two nearby places in a map. The game could have done just fine without them. That said, they suit the Berserk powerup perfectly.

The monster designs are all well done, stylistically. Everything is either heavily inspired by Doom 1/2 in a good way, or redesigned well.

The game doesn't pull punches with difficulty; I'm a long time Doom player, and I've died several times going through on Ultra Violence difficulty.

There are a lot of upgrades, for weapons, armour, and abilities.  They work well for what the game is.

Multiplayer
=============

Now, multiplayer is another story... Google how the Multiplayer Open Beta was received on Steam. (One of the worst games ever made by Id/Bethesda" will probably come up.) The release version of multiplayer is functionally unchanged from the open beta. It's awful

reviewText:
Been a fan of the Doom franchise since the 90s and I have to give thanks to the guys and gals over at ID who made this game possible.

Game is gorgeous - I have a gtx 970, the game auto set everything at a medium setting, and it is still one of the most beautiful games I have ever played. I had trouble shooting at the varying demons on their first appearances because I was, more often than not, taken by how damn awesome their new designs were. Again, the developers stayed true to the original dooms.

Game is bug free - I LITERALLY HAD ZERO BUGS! I beat the game in just over 12 hours and never, not once, did I experience anything close to a freaking GLITCH. No graphical errors, no clipping issues. NOTHING. Even when creatures die they stay plugged into the physics of the game until their corpses turn to ash and blow away. I just couldnt believe I didnt find anything and I explored EVERYTHING.

Game is FUN! - I remember reading an article that Bethesda put out talking about how they want people to play agressively and that the game awards a gameplay style that is mobile and in the enemies face. If you sit behind a corner and camp, or try to play like its a Call of Duty fps, you will die. This game is all about moving, using the terrain, and all the tools the game gives you to bring the demons of hell to their KNEES.

The Game and gameplay make you feel like a BAMF - The game literally FEEDS your ego by talking you up and basically reinforcing the idea that YOU, THE DOOM MARINE, are the demon that the denizens of hell tell scary stories about around campfires. Unfortunately for them, you are very real! The glory killing system has you literally wade through your enemies pulling them apart and just leaving you looking for the next demon to tear apart with your bare hands! (sometimes your hands are all you need!)

THE GAME IS A REWARDING CHALLENGE! - The boss fights were AWESOME. The game constantly pits you against waves upon waves of demons as you get further into the game. It also seems like the game scaled my exposure to the waves quite well. It never felt like i was in an impossible situation. The entire combat arena could be swarming, and i mean like 20-25 guys staring at me trying to kill me and the only thing going through my mind was...Im killing that one first" and then you charge!

Item collection was a pleasure! - Alot of times you get games that basically give you the "option" of finding little treasure troves around the various levels with usually an achievement or a journal notation to reward you with. How does Doom award you for doing this? IT TRIES TO KILL YOU OF COURSE! You want to find every little secret on the map? Squeeze every upgrade you can? Get ready for puzzles
recommended:
get ready for challenges! How exactly are you rewarded? Well you become a far more capable killing machine of course! Going for all the unlocks in the game takes time but they are all interconnected with various "completion" based sub-objectives that further reward you for your diligence. Ultimately allowing you to stay ahead of the game with the best equipment and upgrades you could possibly have which you ARE GOING TO NEED!

I havent touched the multiplayer or snapmap yet because im probably gonna amp the difficulty up to its max setting and give it a go.

I highly recommend this game - the last time I felt this good about an fps game

reviewText: This is Doom alright :D Imagine taking original Doom 1 and 2, breath in HD graphics, give them actual 3rd dimension and again back it up with amazing jaw dropping graphics engine which runs absurdly fast thanks to Vulkan. I have a powerful system, but I didn't expect a brand new game that looks so amazing to run so incredibly fast. And it's not just bells and whistles, the game is stupendously fun. Monsters are really challenging and it again feels like old Doom games. No more individual demons here and there like in Doom 3, they are still there, but most of the time it's crazy battle within a map segment filled with demons. You have to constantly move and kill. It's the only way not to die. Especially if you play on Nightmare like I am. Incredibly unforgiving but still fun. Combat is really engaging and amazing, especially thanks to tons of weapons and what's new and unexpected in a Doom game, Preator suit and weapons upgrades with rune powers. By playing, killing and finding secrets you upgrade yourself and weapons to be a better killing machine. And while most would think such thing just wouldn't work in a Doom game, it totally does. It's brilliant and most upgrades for weapons are designed to deliver more boom, only few are sort of tactical oriented like scoped railgun and scoped heavy machinegun (both optional, you can opt for more firepower mods). Suit upgrades are more for movement and world awareness. But it's all so well designed it's really awesome.\n\nAnyway, I could go on and on how awesome it is, but it's really one of the best games this year. It really is. It looks great, it's incredibly fun and captures that Doom feel from the 90's, but in new refreshing form. A proper franchise reboot, something we don't often see with floods of crappy reboots. This one is properly badass like Doom should be. I can only recommend it!

reviewText:
*Single-player only will update after I play multiplayer*

Thoughts going in -

I have only played the original Doom for about half an hour, so I will say that this IS my first Doom game. I have watched a lot of gameplay of the OG Doom, though. I expected this game to be as gripping as the Bethesda walkthrough, and very hellish (of course.) I was  skeptical after seeing beta reactions, but I bit the bullet.

Initial reaction -

I was first blown away by the visuals. This is definitely a top-notch game for 2016. We know that it has Vulcun support coming, which will be amazing. I am running the game with a GTX Titan X on a 1440p, 144hz screen at max settings. I was only getting 60fps (could tell by the mouse) but I do believe it was from the graphics settings, as the game does have an unlocked frame rate. The game is much more stable than The Witcher 3, and even GeForce Experience (LOL.) There are basic menu options, so it's easy to use.

Movement -

This game is fast. It's not as fast as Unreal Tournament 4, but it's fast. A long bunny-hop chain in CS:GO could describe this game's speed accurately. I tried bunny-hopping in this game but I can't tell if it was faster than running or not. Your character can vault up legdes really easily.

Level Design -

This is one of my complaints. They levels are very large in certain areas. There is a lot of verticallity to the game, which is interesting. There are blue" and "yellow" keys that you need to obtain from dead characters to unlock doors. This is my issue. I spent a solid 15-20 minutes searching the entire level for one background-blending corpse. There was no marker on the map for it and it was just a waste of time. It's a good mechanic
date: but it can get annoying. Also
recommended:
you need to open almost every door that you pass manually (at least to unlock it.) The terminals to do so look alot like the un-useable terminals so it can be confusing at times.

Gameplay -

I played this game on the standard
hoursPlayed: medium difficulty. You gradually build up your arsenal of weapons as you progress. As you get more weapons and upgrades
voteText: (you can choose different alternate fire modes for each weapon i.e frag rounds or choked burst for a shotgun) there are more enemies that get more challenging. I sort of felt like I abused the "Glory Kill" mechanic. All you have to do is get any enemy down to low health and you will incapacitate them. You can just walk up to them and "Press F to pay respects" their asses and mutilate them. From doing that
helpfulPercent: you will get more drops vs a normal kill. I did this very often. With the chainsaw
votesHelpful: you get a TON of ammo. You can insta-kill bosses with it if you have enough fuel. All of the enemies are really different - attacks
votesTotal: health
votesFunny: speed
commentsCount:
etc. are all really well balanced.

Story -

From what I can tell so far
column16:
it's another reboot of the original Doom's plot. From what I've read about Doom 3 this game seems to have a very similary story so far. I have not finished the story yet so I will update when I finish it.

Summary -

I think this is a very solid Doom game

reviewText:
In this review I'll just write about the singleplayer campaign, since I don't play multiplayer a lot.

Perfect combination of old and new elements, like on one hand the fast paced gameplay with a variety of guns for different situations, varied enemy types and some open levels which can be explored non-linearly (including secrets!) and on the other hand the weapon and character upgrade system which lets you pick your preferred playstyle. The graphics are a mix of mostly Doom 3's dark atmosphere and a few of the old Doom's colourful enemies. The only thing I didn't like as much as the rest was the design of a few of the enemies, like the cyberdemon which looks like it comes straight out of a Blizzard title, but that's just a very minor flaw.

Technically, the game is also very good. The environments look great, indoor as well as outdoor. The enemies are extremely detailed and wonderfully animated. The framerate is stable at 60 (GTX 970, 16GB RAM, i5-4690K) and the loading times are not even noticable on my SSD. The only flaw is that the game crashed 2 times so far.

I can recommend this to old and new FPS fans alike, it's just great.

reviewText:
So i got to say, they actually made a doom game that feels like the old school doom we all love. The singleplayer is SUPER strong. Fun, fast, brutal, loads of guns and a decent story telling with big rewards if you explore. You're a badass, go kill some monsters. The storyline wont tell you everything, but you'll collect info while playing and decide for yourself if you want to read the story in detail. I like that, give the player a choice to read it all or leave it be. The game is also remarkable well optimized. I was amazed at how good the game looked with 8gb ram, a bad graphic card (GeForce GTX 560Ti) and no SSD hdd. It still runs smooth on 30-60fps after the loading, witch is nothing more than amazing.

Over to multiplayer. It's not that great imo. It's fast, but messy and it just don't give me the same awesome feeling of being a badass. It looks a lot like a version of unreal tournament tbh, with the twist. And some of the modes was not that fun. The melee instant kill range also seems to be really long. It's possible to do a finish move from far away.

Anyway, to sum it up. If you want a singleplayer shoot'em up game that's made of awesomeness, buy this. It will be worth it if you enjoy the old school doom style. If you want a multiplayer game, this will probably be a dissapointment.

reviewText:
Every time I receive a weapon upgrade from a flying robot I punch the hell out of it for absolutely no reason. This is Doom.

The campaign does everything right that the multiplayer (and Doom 3) did wrong. This is the classic Doom experience dropped into the excellent id Tech 6 engine while still preserving the rules/gameplay that defined the original. Modern updates to the formula, such as weapon/suit upgrades, serve only to enhance the core experience rather than re-defining it. Anyone for whom Doom was a formulative gaming experience will quickly fall back into the rhythm here, while those who cut their teeth on Halo/COD might feel like fish out of water temporarily but will fall in quickly with a bit more investment.

Gameplay is fast and furious with the original Doom glide" in full effect. No reloads
recommended: this is a game that rewards aggression and constant forward momentum. That would be a problem if the engine/mechanics didn't support it
hoursPlayed: but the movement and shooting are as tight as any arena shooter in recent memory. The new execution mechanics fit perfectly into the aggressive/fast gameplay style
voteText: and along with the chainsaw (which generates ammo) incentivize a pace that comes as a breath of fresh air after a decade of duck-and-reload shooters.\n\nBottom line
helpfulPercent: if you have any fondness for the early PC FPS era or you want to try out a new experience that feels significantly different from other modern shooters
votesHelpful: you can pick up Doom without concern that it throws the baby out with the bathwater. This is a labor of 90s-era FPS love
votesTotal: and you can feel it every time you shotgun an imp and then explode its head with your bare hands."

General Thoughts:

When I played the beta I didn't think it was going to be a very big game, but after seing what Snapmap can do and how much stuff there was being added to the game I bought it on Thursday, the 12th to preload the game and be able to play it right away on release. And i definitly don't regret my choice.
The game runs very smooth in 1080p with everything maxed out on my Dual 980 Ti's (what a surprise) and looks absolutely gorgeous. Gameplay overall is great and balanced and the customization of weapons and characters is awesome.

reviewText:
Ladies and gentlemen, the King of First Person Shooters has finally returned to us!

In a world where the genre has been oversaturated with bland, dumbed down, tutorial-infested garbage, it makes my heart swell with pride to play a proper sequel to the game that got me into the FPS genre in the first place.  Sure, I played Wolf 3D.  Sure, I played other ripoffs like Lethal Tender.  Of course I played Duke 3D, as well.  Hell, I even played all these games in school, instead of doing my school work!  That's how dedicated I was to the genre!

This game is a no-nonsense action game.  Just like the first game, you run around shooting things in the face, chest, arm, head, legs....wherever you like.  You kill demons, and you pick up items.
Where the game expands on the formula established by the beloved Doom and Doom 2 is this:
-More violence.
-Collectibles that serve a purpose(you get points to spend on weapons and the like for finding them).
-Finishing moves that serve a purpose(sure, Brutal Doom is awesome, but in this game, it's more than just for show-you get health for melee executions, and ammo from chainsaw executions).
-Absolutely gorgeous graphics.
-A small expansion/reimagining of the original story(yeah, we don't play this game for the story, but I'll take it).

I'm only about 3-4 hours in, and I am having a blast!

I had hoped that this game was at least good.

As it turns out, this game is f***ing METAL.

reviewText:
Ahhhh yes.... DOOM... one of the two grandfathers of the First-Person Shooter that has put the genre on the map has returned after 12 long years... And holy mother of ♥♥♥♥ its absolutly perfect!

After a long development hell this game has went through we can finally play it and it has exceeded all of my expectations. To start off, this game is everything you would want out of a DOOM game. Mindless killing demons, fast intense combat, delicious gore fest, badass weapons, badass soundtrack, and basically a fun as hell shooter.

The campaign is the best part of this game. The game doesn't hold your hand in anyways which is such a great feeling. Within the first 10 seconds your automaticly killing demons unlike modern FPS games that take a while to get to combat and shove tutorials down your throat. Story is same as always: your DOOM Guy and your main goal is to kill demons and make Satan your ♥♥♥♥♥! And figure out how to stop the demons from invading Mars on the UAC facility and thats it. The game is very focused on gameplay thankfully since there is almost no character development cause your character is just ♥♥♥♥♥♥ and wants to kill those demons!

There is a good variety of weapons to change up your playstyle as well as upgrades that can be found throughout the levels and complete challenges to further upgrade your weapons. Also there is no reloading (except of course the Super Shotgun) and feels great as well! Exploration is very rewarding throughout the levels which have secret rooms just like in the original DOOM games and you can get suit upgrades and other story related items. The glory kills in this game almost never gets old. If you played the Brutal Doom mod you would think ID Software was influenced by that mod. Basically glory kills just destroy your enemies in epic violent ways that can drop health, armor, or ammo. When you get the chainsaw the kills are just much more entertaining lol!

Multiplayer isn't as good as the campaign but is still fun to play. Its fast paced and shooter arena based like the Quake games and Unreal Tournament. However, there are aspects that can feel like Halo and CoD with mostly a Doom skin over it. There are some interesting game modes like Warpath and a good amount of customization to your character. Some game modes lets you play as demons from the campaign that makes you a power house which is a lot of fun. Overall I think the multiplayer is a lot of fun and hope the community will last a while and hope future content will be good when they come out.

SnapMap is a very interesting tool that allows you to make your own DOOM maps with their own game modes, enemies, weapons, rooms, and objectives and allow you to upload them and allow other people to play them. Personally I'm not into this modding tool since I'm not good at creating things. But seeing what others have made has been a lot of fun and in the future it will be interesting what others can make out of this modding tool.

Conclusion: DOOM is the FPS game that we have deserved compared to other crappy FPS games that decide to focus way to much on multiplayer and common design choices. This game doesn't have the following:

1. No reloading
2. No ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t QTEs
3. No hand holding
4. No slow boring combat
5. And best of all... Doesn't give a ♥♥♥♥!!!

Take all of that into consideration along with a very well made DOOM game. I dare say this is the best FPS game we have had in recent years and its great to have DOOM back to show what's up with these other FPS games!

100/10 Masterpiece!!!

GOTY so far for 2016!

reviewText:
You will be a Sinner 10/10

I played the second it came out and I will say it is bloody ♥♥♥♥ing fun to play. It is easily a very good successor to Doom 3 that we have been waiting for some years for. The core mechanics, graphics and gameplay is fluent and bloody brilliant. No doubt when you jump into the game after purchasing you won't be dissapointed. The multi-player is fun for what it is, and a good little side game to play with friends that acts like any other regular PvP shooter/arena style game. That be seeing said the real element to the game I honestly only play DOOM for is the main game, and it is really good. It has sort of a Halo meets Metroid Prime feel to the surroundings with secrets, passageways and areas of monsters to defeat, and nothing feels more satisfying than to break the neck or limbs off a monster while blowing everything away around it. That being said a well rounded game that definitely shows its trademark. That being said, I do have some problems with this game so far.

1. The Campaign is not as long as you may think. The main game does have a decent long storyplot that goes through several areas of the UAC installation and inevitably Hell. But I found the world to be smaller, somewhat linear unlike the older game of Doom 3, which always had you going through endless passageways, installations and areas and constantly discovering something new. In this DOOM however it is all pretty easy to travel and discover everything that game has to offer.

2. It is not Scary. Through my time playing it I have yet to be genuinely scared from the atmosphere, environmental elements or monsters themselves. Unlike the old Dooms and Doom3 where the game was abosultely scary, dark and grimy the new DOOM does not have this all that well. Most areas are bright, monster's are not scary and it is tough to be freightened when you are in big areas constantly blasting away at enemies left and right while ripping through them with a chainsaw. Which is not bad considering, but its tough to be scared when the action drowns it out.

3. The Multiplayer although fun is very bare, it is nothing new but the usual kill or be killed team up match battles. The unlockables are not all that great, and it's just your usual Player vs Player arena style junk that we see in hundreds of games now. It is fun for a while but it will get boring with the same stuff everytime. If have friends to play it is can be very enjoyable and that is about it.

4. No Main Game Co-Op or Co-Op Mods or Options at this point. This was somewhat a huge deal for me when waiting so many years for the next DOOM. I thought maybe finally developers of such great games would come to be aware how fun and successful main game co-op stuff could be. A big intricate main game with your friends is something many fans and my friends wanted to see. But instead there is no real co-op but little side mission/PVP Co-op junk that falls short of what we really wanted. When I first heard about this game and saw the Co-Op in its tags I was so hyped ans hoped for a real main game campaign of Doom filled with Co-op survival action, but it became a letdown and became just another Multiplayer action scroeboard game.

All in All the game is still worth its title and a great game overall that kept me entertained and still entertained with its time. So until than I am going to chainsaw some more monsters!

reviewText:
Doom is back, this time back as close as it can to its roots, while putting on new polish and new features. However, does it have enough to be the Doom folks have been wanting since the 90s? The answer is a definite 'Yes!', with a caveat or two. Doom delivers a solid singleplayer experience with plenty of love and attention to gameplay, bits of story, and speed. The multiplayer aspect feels like an afterthought, or worse, shoehorned in to try to grasp the old days of Doom multiplayer, while trying to keep it modern, which fails as the system is drastically different than what’s seen in the Singleplayer.

Overall, a must have to any FPS Enthusiast of the 90s, or those who definitely enjoy the frantic pace of the Doom series (not including Doom 3).

Graphics: 10/10
Id Software went out of their way to make some solid effort to bring back the foreboding atmosphere to abandoned facilities all the way to Hell's jagged mountains and corridors. Every sight is as foreboding as it is impressive to the eye, not once leaving the proper atmosphere of the invasion of Mars. Enemies themselves are painstakingly put together in great detail from the Possessed all the way to the Cyberdemon (something you can inspect in great detail later in the game in the gallery). Special effects and particles all play out well, leaving the game a beautiful sight.

Audio: 8/10
Music composed to this game is a nostalgic gamer's dream mixed into a new players love for intense song. Mixing in old classic tunes from the old games for remixes for a modern finish that will speak to old school gamers while still leaving the newcomers enjoying the throbbing tone of a fight in their ears. There are times when the music difference can in fact feel a little jarring, as the difference between fights and exploration ambiance music can be as different as night and day. This does happen a bit in Hell as music can come between hard techno, to suddenly the hellish chorus and orchestra echoing in your speakers. However, the real treat comes from the work put into the guns and the monsters. Almost every gun in the game has avoided the 'nerf gun' feel of firing, from the combat shotgun's ringing blast, all the way to the chaingun firing at full throttle. Only one gun in the collection feels a bit disappointing, the pistol, while only really necessary early game, it never feels like its got much impact in the sound of the shot, but this is minor.

Gameplay: 9/10
It's fast, its chaos, and its gory. The Devs really did listen to their fans this time around, trading the creeping and paranoid inducing feeling of Doom 3, and replacing it with fast run n' gun action that leaves it dangerous to stop at any point in the fight. Of course, there are small respites you can find here and there between fights that allow you to take a breath, but at the same time, while the game is fast paced and chaotic, it doesn't discourage exploration either. With secrets and badly needed supplies everywhere, you can always back track, as most of the time, it'll be rare a portion of the map will be gated off after a certain amount of progress. There are a few negative points, such as the over reliance of the Glory Kill system, especially in later levels where its not an option, its almost mandatory. (Details discussed below) However, every punch, every shot, ever messy take down brings a satisfying sense of speed and thrill that few FPS grasp these days.

Longevity / Replayability: 9/10
Contrary to rumors, DOOM is packed with content from start to finish, most of it all in the Singleplayer, which after my playthrough, lasted between 18-20 hours on the highest difficulty available right out of the box (Ultra-Violence). From secrets, challenges in every map, collectibles to obtain, weapon mods to add to your arsenal, its quite a bit to all get. Thankfully, all this is not locked away should you miss it on finishing a map. You can return to any map any time with all currently obtained equipment and upgrades, allowing you to use the advantage to take on a challenge, or get a leg up to finally reach that possible secret you were having trouble with. That said, all secrets and challenges can be done with the default gear you have during that part of the game. (Eg. No challenges / secrets that cannot be reached without double jump in maps prior to obtaining that skill). After completing the game, you still have time to challenge yourself with two new difficulty settings (Acting much like New Game+), Nightmare, and Ultra-Nightmare, where the latter throws the challenge of permadeath. SnapMap and Multiplayer also add to this, but we'll get into that next.

Multiplayer: 6.5/10
Regretfully, once you load the Multiplayer up, be it SnapMap or Standard Multiplayer, the game changes drastically from its fast paced Singeplayer counterpart. The multiplayer works on a loadout and leveling system, most of which rewards you with cosmetics. Gameplay-wise, the speed is taken down several notches, and the wild combat is somewhat muted, as the guns don't quite have the same impact, and since they are given in loadouts, guns like the Super Shotgun and Rocket Launcher don't quite have the impact folks would expect. There are options to run classical rules, but some of these matches seem devoid of players at this time. Sadly, this part of the game feels shoehorned, simply there to make multiplayer a 'thing' in Doom, which fails to quite grasp the feeling of urgency and intensity.

SnapMap, however, does add some creative credence to the idea of custom work and mod work, adhering to the idea that Doom is a mod friendly game. However, in that same stroke, actual mods of the games players could make are no longer viable. SnapMap replaces this by giving folks tools to make their own maps from between staged Multiplayer, deadly onslaught mode coop, to even missions of their very own to test other players. Including trials to test your modding skill to improve / complete a map, to letting you publish and share your work. More and more features in regards to cosmetics, textures, and objects. The downside is that the setup is rather simplistic, and scripts are rather dumbed down, making it easy for newcomers, but more advance map makers are left wanting more. Possible upgrades later, but for now, it feels like it could do much much more for what its promising.

OVERALL: 8.5/10

Disclaimer: Review was based off a full campaign run on Ultra-Violence difficulty. And 4 hours of Multiplayer and SnapMap
System Specs
Intel i7
geForce 980 GTX
16Gb RAM DDR5
500 SSD

reviewText:
For new players, Doom offers an interesting break from the usual first-person shooter style you might be familiar with (Call of Duty, Halo 5, etc.) and instead puts a focus on in-your-face, bloody combat. You'll be close with your enemies in this game, rather than picking them off from a longer distance. And it's this close-quarters focus that really brings out the game's intensity. It's constant, fast-paced action all the way through, with only occasional breaks from the carnage.

For classic Doom veterans, this game is not too far from the norm of a Doom game. It's fast-paced, visceral and brutal. You can feel like a true badass again, destroying anything in your path, but you're never shy of a challenge. The demons will mess you up if you don't keep yourself killing. And of course, just like any true Doom game, you should always be on the move.

The campaign has a nice story to it, but it rarely forces you to pay attention to it. You spend more time killing demons, which is a great thing. Most story segments you can actually just walk away from and continue killing.

Doom also introduces some new mechanics, such as glory kills - fully animated executions performed against your enemies, each one gory and...well, glorious. You have a variety of unique guns to choose from, just like any good first-person shooter, but in singleplayer, you get to modify your weapons with upgrades, new firemodes, and the like. You can also upgrade your suit abilities in singleplayer - anything from blast resistance, to a more intricate map. Further suit upgrades can be achieved through obtaining runes - gained by completing quick challenges. These runes let you get new benefits, such as armor-for-kills or increased mobility.

The multiplayer modes are, surprisingly, a really strong point of the game. Deathmatch game modes can get hectic and crazy, especially if you bring friends along. The demon rune" - a powerup that lets you turn into a demon for a short amount of time - can be a real game changer

reviewText:
Awesome game so far, finished campaign and now messing with SnapMap. I haven't liked multiplayer too much but I will try it more. About campaign;
Story; well it has a story but it ain't important too much, even game offers you some extra story such as readible entries. If you want a game with a solid story then this game is not for you. However story never was what this game has offered. So you probably know this.

Enemies are like they actually have brains or something, you don't know what they're gonna do. They can climb up ledges, turn away and attack you anytime, or suddenly escape from you and start attacking from range (unless they are Pinkies). All of the enemies feel annoying more than they were in Doom I & II thus making combat really insane.

Combat is really challenging yet fun and somehow encourages to try again if you fail somehow. Game is really fast, you run really really fast and you may think that you've missed something before such as secrets. Its really awesome but my only problem was motion blur. It made me dizzy few times so I had to give a rest, you may want to close it.

They are secrets, they are not big nor hard to find. You can come across few secrets in a level even if you are playing linearly. I suppose its fine.

Music is awesome, electronic elements mixed with heavy ♥♥♥ distorted 9-stringed guitars, pumps you more to kill some more. However I haven't liked weapon sounds too much especially normal Shotgun.

Shotgun and Pistol sucks in this game. They do. Only they do.
Yeah this is about campaign. As I've said before I really haven't played too much of multiplayer (only played in beta) so I don't have a review for it yet. I will update if I find it necessary.

About SnapMap; it is a easy to use modding tool. While it doesn't have unlimited range between what you can do with what you cannot do, I think that it is a really flexible tool. I would recommend you to give it a try. Learning it can take a few hours so be patient, it is REALLY easy compared to other official and non-official modding tools for other games.
Currently I've been trying to make a RPG mod but I don't know, it may turn out to be a Crack-Life.

Anyway, campaign is fun, SnapMap is fun. Game really feels like it is Doom. It has an appeal for both hardcore Doom fans or casual players out there. So if you want fun, not-focused-on-story-too-much game then it is for you.

reviewText:
Bottom line - D00M is a fusion of the old Doom games and Doom 3 game styles, plus a great gameplay improvement.

You have this horror film scenario style from Doom 3 fused with the butchery of the old games (when lots of mobs just appear all around and you can't catch a break until the last one of them is dead).

There is an additional element of choice when upgrading your gear, without really swaying from the well defined FPS style. Basically, seasoning the dish to your liking, yet the dish stays the same.

The maps/levels are very well designed with much to explore - and as a recommendation: take your time and explore the map!
In exchange for the time invested in exploring, you'll be rewarded with tokens to imrove you gear (and you're going save some time by not dying later in game).

The game mechanics are great and invite you to think of how you'll be going through different parts of the map. Along your journey you should manage your ammo wisely and invest the gear improvement points likewise.

I think that these are the main things I can and should say without spoiling much. After all, being surprised by stuff is part of the experience.

HURT 'EM PLENTY!

reviewText:
It feels pure DOOM: 75% oldschool and 25% modern mechanics, also you can mod the Multiplayer all you want and made it more like Quake, Unreal, or Toxikk (fast competitive arena FPS games)

My score for this is 90/100. These are the good and the bad things imo:

Pros:

- Great production, technically excellent with amazing sound and graphics.
- Smooth, fast paced, bloody like hell.
- Level maps and boss designs.
- Metal music with some really good tunes, and a bit of electronic and classical music for each moment.
- The game is so fun and addictive for itself but add a lot of things to do for a better replay value such as secret levels, different paths, upgrades, challenges etc. Nice Easter eggs.
- Glory kills (Melee Fatalities) looks and feel really good and you can disable the visual effect that indicates when an enemy is staggered if you don't like it. With this, you can get bonus ammo and health.
- You can turn off the crosshair, the compass, the objectives... for a more hardcore experience.
- Definitely SnapMap (They key for the ones who are looking for a more competitive multiplayer experience)
- Casual but really fun multiplayer with tons of creative modes and a well designed online world with skins, new weapons and other stuff to unlock while you play.
- Perfect balanced difficulty (Nightmare, the harder one, is really hard) Also you have that same difficulty level but with Perma-death called ''Ultra-Nightmare'')
- Weapons beautifully designed with collectible modifications you can get through the game.
- Spoiler: Classic nostalgic levels hidden inside the campaign and you can play it later from the title menu.
- First time since 90's we see a real good FPS (I mean with an AAA production in the back) with no health/shields regeneration, no reload, tons of beautiful weapons, good maps, and fast combat speed and exploration.


Cons:

- Disappointment achievements, all of them so easy to get.
- The... Story? (I know, is DOOM)
- No coop.
- Expensive Multiplayer DLC.
- Limited Strafe Jump as default (Don't know if you can change that with SnapMap)
- No Rocket Jump and no Plasma Climbing. (SnapMap maybe?)
- It seems this is another PCGame victim of the cross-platform because textures have been downgraded a bit. I can feeling it.

Overall I'm happy with the new DOOM. Games evolve and change, 90's were great but we should accept and love the new era because it does good things too. Not everything is awful nowadays.

---------------------------------------

TL;DR: Good multiplayer (Outsourced) and a brutally gorgeous singleplayer thanks to ID.

reviewText:
This is what I wished hard Doom 3 would be back in the day. And Quake 4.

Quake 4 did a silly thing in hamstringing the player down paths like other corridor shooters of the time while the multiplayer was Quake 3 arena at the core. This relaunch of Doom has done the polar opposite where the multiplayer of the beta was slow while the pace of the primary game is ferocious as they come and on the higher difficulties is up there with Doom's spiritual successors like Serious Sam.

Doom does borrow from a lot of modern game mechanics like grenade cooldowns, weapon/armour upgrades and the like. However, it seems to blend in well and isn't a main distraction for the player. The execute-stunned-enemy-to-recover-health mechanic works well as the kills only take a second compared to the slow times of Space Marine and Hatred and help keep the player running on the fast dance of death.

Just try to remember not to grenade yourself, DoomGuy. Rip and Tear.

reviewText:
Finally, after more than a decade i have an opportunity to come back to my first and beloved videogaming franchise. Summing up my first hour experience:
1. Kick and punch.
2. Grab a gun.
3. Shoot.
4. Shoot MORE.
5. New gun/gear/upgrade WOW THANKS
6. Shoot again.

reviewText:
You move fast, you move constantly. You shoot fast, you shoot constantly. Metal music pounds in your ears. You don't stop to reload, you don't hide while your health regenerates, you don't cower behind cover. Basically you don't do anything you do in most modern shooters, and that's awesome.

This is DOOM, pure and simple. It's the most pure, addictive, and fun FPS experience you're likely to have all year.

I haven't even bothered with the multiplayer or snapmap, so I can't comment on those. The single player campaign is well worth the price of admission. I've spent almost 18 hours on the campaign and still haven't finished it or found all the secrets yet, and I am absolutely planning on replaying it over and over just because it's such a joy to play.

10/10, would punch demon's face off again.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Let's get something out of the way right now. Doom has never been about Multiplayer. It has always been the single player experience that has driven the game to it's heights.

While this is the fourth Iteration of Doom, it is not Doom 4. It is not a continuation of the jump scares that were used to great effect in Doom 3. Unfortunately the scene deformations are lacking this time around. So if you were hoping for a corridor shooter, You won't get that here.

What you do get are waves of enemies à la the original Doom 1 and Doom 2. Hordes of them. It's fast. It's frantic. It's a bloody good gorefest. Some people might hate the new Glory Kills, but I find them to be gratifying. All the weapoons have impact. If there is anything to be said about a game with great gunplay this has got to be it.

This is a game that is meant to be enjoyed for the sake of enjoyment. It looks gorgeous on my system running at 2560x1440 all settings maxed out, Motion Blur is turned off, on my GTX 980Ti. At these settings, I get a solid 90fps. 4k is somewhat playable at around 47fps all settings maxed out, but I'd take the higher frame rate any day.

I can appreciate that perhaps some people wouldn't like the metal soundtrack, but you know what. That's what DOOM is. It's Dungeons and Dragons, Heavy Metal, and Grit. It's tough as balls.

As far as the multiplayer...I'm not interested. It doesn't (yet) have Local LAN, so I couldn't care less about playing with Randos.

TL;DR
This game is extremely satisfying. Buy this game for a fantastic Single Player experience. Don't buy it just for the Multiplayer.

reviewText:
It feels pure DOOM: 75% oldschool and 25% modern mechanics, also you can mod the Multiplayer all you want and made it more like Quake, Unreal, or Toxikk (fast competitive arena FPS games)

My score for this is 90/100. These are the good and the bad things imo:

Pros:

- Great production, technically excellent with amazing sound and graphics.
- Smooth, fast paced, bloody like hell.
- Level maps and boss designs.
- Metal music with some really good tunes, and a bit of electronic and classical music for each moment.
- The game is so fun and addictive for itself but add a lot of things to do for a better replay value such as secret levels, different paths, upgrades, challenges etc. Nice Easter eggs.
- Glory kills (Melee Fatalities) looks and feel really good and you can disable the visual effect that indicates when an enemy is staggered if you don't like it. With this, you can get bonus ammo and health.
- You can turn off the crosshair, the compass, the objectives... for a more hardcore experience.
- Definitely SnapMap (They key for the ones who are looking for a more competitive multiplayer experience)
- Casual but really fun multiplayer with tons of creative modes and a well designed online world with skins, new weapons and other stuff to unlock while you play.
- Perfect balanced difficulty (Nightmare, the harder one, is really hard) Also you have that same difficulty level but with Perma-death called ''Ultra-Nightmare'')
- Weapons beautifully designed with collectible modifications you can get through the game.
- Spoiler: Classic nostalgic levels hidden inside the campaign and you can play it later from the title menu.
- First time since 90's we see a real good FPS (I mean with an AAA production in the back) with no health/shields regeneration, no reload, tons of beautiful weapons, good maps, and fast combat speed and exploration.


Cons:

- Disappointment achievements, all of them so easy to get.
- The... Story? (I know, is DOOM)
- No coop.
- Expensive Multiplayer DLC.
- Limited Strafe Jump as default (Don't know if you can change that with SnapMap)
- No Rocket Jump and no Plasma Climbing. (SnapMap maybe?)
- It seems this is another PCGame victim of the cross-platform because textures have been downgraded a bit. I can feeling it.

Overall I'm happy with the new DOOM. Games evolve and change, 90's were great but we should accept and love the new era because it does good things too. Not everything is awful nowadays.

---------------------------------------

TL;DR: Good multiplayer (Outsourced) and a brutally gorgeous singleplayer thanks to ID.
