reviewText:
I wasn't expecting much, but god dammit they've did it, a game that does Doom justice.

I'm blown away but how good the gameplay, graphics, smooth/responsive controls, enemies, weapons, speed, and most of all level design is.

Everything feels streamlined. The game knows it's an over-the-top action shooter about demons from hell, and it has FUN with it. You're constantly moving, as are the enemies, and it's the closest singleplayer FPS has ever come to reminding me of the old Quakeworld days of frantic movement, jumping around, shooting in mid-air, and so on.

The levels are full of hidden stuff, and generally there are very few points-of-no-return in each level (with the end-of-level being an obvious thing you have to explicitly trigger), meaning you can search for secrets through the level until you find them. The map and optional upgrades (in a light RPG system) can also help you locate secrets, or most of them at least.

I was sceptical about adding things like execution moves, double-jump and ledge-grabbing to Doom but having now played it, it all works and fits into the mechanics surprisngly well. (Executions are useful as they give you a little bonus health and ammo, for the small risk of having to get close to the enemy in time, although you need not get _that_ close. They're over very quickly, and if you really don't like them then you simply never push the button that does them and you'll never do them.)

SnapMap looks interesting, in terms of providing various types of extra maps and game modes you (and other players if you wish) can drop into, and make yourself. I haven't played with it much though, and it's early days in terms of seeing what other people can create.

I have no idea what the multiplayer is like as I have not tried that yet. After years of playing nothing but Quakeworld and then Counter-Strike, and later CoD:MW2, I try to avoid multiplayer as it can end up eating up so much time, and never ends. This was all about single-player fo rme, and the game has delivered well beyond expectations.

Highly recommended if you enjoy shooting demons in the face and searching multi-level, intricate levels for hidden stuff.

Runs and looks great on Ultra/1080p on my lowly GTX 960 (4GB). While it cannot quite maintain 60fps all the time, it's pretty close to it, and the adaptive v-sync means I rarely even notice. (Maybe the really well done motion blur helps as well? I don't consciously notice it is there, but it's very visible in still screenshots.)

reviewText:
TLDR: When the first boss appeared, I laughed - he had no idea how much of a pounding I was about to give him.

I was dubious when I saw the trailers - I thought this was going to be a mindless action game with no thought or depth to it, pandering only to people who still boot up Final Doom at the weekend. Armour and health pickups? Power-ups? Cheesy insta-kill melee system? Silent protagonist and minimal plot?

It turns out that the single player campaign for DOOM is actually really good. It's an extremely satisfying game to play and goes right to the core of a good shoot-'em-up - interesting environments, varied enemies, and excellent weaponry. Everything else is just icing on the top of a very solid cake.

The story is present, it's just given less of a focus. You can largely ignore it or you can ponder the plot between firefights. The game would not have been improved by adding a supporting cast or giving the protagonist an invested opinion, witty one-liners, or defiant retorts.

The weapon/armour/rune progression is a nice touch, too; it rewards exploration and creative use of your arsenal. The chainsaw and BFG both serve a purpose, and you'll find yourself thinking about when best to use them as you progress. They are tactical tools, not unlike a character's powers/abilities in games like Mass Effect or The Division.

For me the only underplayed element was the utility items (grenade/hologram/siphon) - they don't really add much value and could have done with further development.

The game is about being a bigger badass than every demon in hell, and then punishing the demons for thinking they could possibly take you on.

The glory kills never get old and once you develop your bloodthirst there are never enough enemies onscreen at a time to sate it.

If there is going to be a sequel to this game with more enemies to rip and tear, I'll be on that bandwagon faster than a guass cannon round through a cacodemon's eye.

reviewText: So far I'm loving DOOM!  I'm old enough to have and played the original DOOM(S) and this one does not disappoint.  Alot of ppl are bashing the multiplayer but personally I really enjoy it.. .  I think I've only gotten about 5 hours of sleep this whole week because of the multiplayer. I don't know if they got tired of DOOM and moved on,  were banned by Steam,  or just quit using aim bot.  It is way more fun now that there isn't someone killing everyone with 1 shot or taking 5 rockets to the face and 175 rounds from chain gun just to glory kill you and dance over top of your body.  There is still some things I don't quite get like snap map and why I don't see anyone on it at all.   Lots of maps just no one to play them with.   Also the prowler demon really boggles me.  I haven't figured out how to use him/her effectively but I know it is a super powerful demon when used correctly.  Anyway you all know the single player is great and if the cheaters and hackers can be kept from the servers then the multiplayer can be fun also.  I'm giving DOOM a solid 9 outta 10.

reviewText:
This is what I wished hard Doom 3 would be back in the day. And Quake 4.

Quake 4 did a silly thing in hamstringing the player down paths like other corridor shooters of the time while the multiplayer was Quake 3 arena at the core. This relaunch of Doom has done the polar opposite where the multiplayer of the beta was slow while the pace of the primary game is ferocious as they come and on the higher difficulties is up there with Doom's spiritual successors like Serious Sam.

Doom does borrow from a lot of modern game mechanics like grenade cooldowns, weapon/armour upgrades and the like. However, it seems to blend in well and isn't a main distraction for the player. The execute-stunned-enemy-to-recover-health mechanic works well as the kills only take a second compared to the slow times of Space Marine and Hatred and help keep the player running on the fast dance of death.

Just try to remember not to grenade yourself, DoomGuy. Rip and Tear.

reviewText:
I was initially very sceptical about the game. A very long and troubled development cycle, no review copies sent out before release, a multiplayer that was poorly received and did not sound or look all that exciting.

I did end up getting it anyway (a good deal on greenmangaming), I had to see what id had done to make a follow-up to what was perhaps my two most favorite games ever.

About 5 seconds after the loadscreen is gone you have a gun in your hand and are shooting zombie guys. 30 seconds later you've violently destroyed a couple more in grotesquely violent melee animations and picked up a shotgun. Shortly you're off over the surface of Mars, through a bunch of sci-fi facilities in the sort of style that Doom 3 laid out, but far more open, expansive and brightly lit. The game looks great, even on medium settings (+85% res) that I was forced to run it at to get a performance that'd sit stable in the 45-60fps range. (2560x1440, 2gb 680gtx, i5 3570k, 16gb ram).

Melee finishing animations were a hotly debated topic, but they are so short they don't interrupt the flow of combat. In later levels they become sort of your in-combat health-regen and later on you can equip a powerup to shorten their duration further.

The gunplay is extremely enjoyable, every single gun has a distinct feel, good sound effects, nice visuals and all are upgradable with interesting alternate firemods that can be upgraded further to improve on their effect, ending up in a Mastery Unlock that buffs the alternate mode fully.

The enemy gallery is almost entirely the classic Doom lineup buffed with a few extra new monsters and new takes on former humans.

Absent from the game are the Arachnotron and the Archvile, the latter replaced by the Summoner the Summoner, a sort of new version of the Archvile. It doesn't feel as threatening, but it shares the agility and speed of all the other monsters in this game.

Which is something quite new and fresh in the FPS genre. The monsters literally jump and climb all over the environment, dodging and weaving to avoid your shots or position themselves to rain lasers down on you. You'll be doing the same, moving with speed up and down ledges, no fall damage is present, so your freedom to move is great. Later in the game you'll get a double-jump and a powerup that lets you move faster after performing melee kills, a powerup that lets you control yourself while in the air much like in Quake 1 and powerups that let you engage melee kills from farther away.
All this combines to a combat system that feels smooth, precise, extremely fun and very rewarding.

I find it to the game's credit that dying seems entirely my own fault for not taking good enough advantage of the options allowed me. And the options are many. You can carry all the game's weapons and you will be swapping between them often and you'll have many, many available approaches in every single fight.

The soundtrack is blazing modern industrial style metal in combat, out of combat there is a light ambient drone, all of it heavily inspired by the original Doom soundtrack. There are many, many eastereggs and little things paying homage to the original games in here and it's clear that it's been made by someone who obviously cared a lot.

With the snapmap editor allowing community creations and a robust replayability, I foresee Doom staying on my drive for quite a while. I hope to see more.

I have not had any experience with the multiplayer, but I'll probably take a look at some point, but it's not why I bought the game and not why you should either, I'd reckon.

Highly recommended.

reviewText:
Doom 2016 is a reboot of the iconic Doom franchise that has us back to square one on Mars awaiting the start of the demon onslaught once again. Unlike the original game that has us be a normal space marine with nothing more than a pistol and the will to live we now start in a giant coffin as some kind of prophesied chosen one. We are then immediately given a robotic suit very similar to the Master Chief's armor from Halo. From waking up from cryogenic sleep to the enemy with the energy shield this whole game feels a lot to Halo with a dash of Painkiller more so than Doom. The levels are not intricate mazes with key card hunting, there is little real enemy placement as they just spawn out of thin air and the secrets are now for collectibles and upgrades instead of vital resources. It's not a critic but something I feel fans of the first two Dooms should be aware of since those games were not arena shooters such as this.

Your first weapon will be the pistol which is as useless as ever though what rather surprised me is how fast you are thrown into the action. Within the first moments of being able to move you are already shooting down foes which is rather unheard of these days. Story is kept to a minimum thankfully and there are no cut scenes though the game will take away control of your character making you listen to characters blather on about uninteresting stuff on occasion. It is rare enough to be a non-issue but when it does happen it is annoying and stops the game dead in its tracks while General Grievous explains backstory to why they opened the portal in the first place and the need to keep it open. Characters are bland, the story is completely predictable and honestly the Codex pages you find scattered around the levels would have been more than enough context to the invasion without slightly damaging the quality of the campaign.

Luckily it has a far heavier focus on pure gameplay where you are given little room to keep the adrenaline down as another wave of demons awaits your every step. It's the closest a Triple A game has been to the fast paced, balls to the walls action of yesteryear in a very long time. There is no hiding behind cover or hit-scan projectiles here instead you will always be on the move and surrounded on all sides while mowing down enemies with absurdly impractical yet glorious weaponry. Add to that the ability to double jump and very good AI and you have a recipe for a good time. All the Doom enemies minus the Elemental and the Arachnotron are back and ready to rip and tear you to pieces. Many of the monsters are pretty much unrecognizable from their previous appearances like the Summoner that represents the Arch-vile in this game and the Imp looking like a fleshy Halo Promethean. It's cool to see how they are  redesigned into the modern age and now appear far more threatening than their counterparts of the 90's.

They don't just appear more threatening but the enemies like the Imps and Pinkys are now far more capable of killing you than ever before. Imps are very agile and cling to walls while flinging projectiles while Pinkys are now the true tanks they were meant to be and an enemy you really don't want to face head on. The Barons of Hell are the stars of the show being giant charging beasts capable of sending you sailing across the sky by just punching the ground near you and throwing fast moving projectiles from a distance. There is just a ton of variety between the monsters and seeing how your childhood foes now fight with the power brought to you by over 20 years of technical progress is just amazing. One thing that bothered me was your movement speed being a bit too slow making it a bit harder to deal with shielded enemies among other things.

In single player you can carry all weapons at once meaning you always have the right tools for the job taking the luck out of carrying the right weapon at the right time very common in modern FPS games. There is no reloading either which really helps with the flow of combat since no one wants the needless realism of waiting for your gun to reload in game about killing demons with a chainsaw on Mars. All of your weapons have two alt fires you can switch between that really spice up the variety in your already vast arsenal of weapons. They are pretty wacky as well like an Assault Rifle firing mini rockets at your enemies and charging up your shotgun to fire three consecutive blasts to annihilate your foes. Causing your opponents to gib is a bloody satisfying feeling in this title.

Levels themselves have a ton of secrets scattered around the place and are pretty well hidden. You can easily go from arena to arena in a linear fashion but branching off the beaten path gets you some pretty nice rewards such as an orb that increases your overall health, armor or ammo limit to entire retro levels of the original Doom in all its low res'd texture goodness. It's an interesting process to finding the retro levels, first you must pull a random lever hidden somewhere in the level which in turn opens up a wall somewhere else. You can play these levels from the campaign menu though they feature Doom 2016 enemies, weapons and gameplay so these are mostly one of nostalgia extras. There are also challenge stones hidden about that unlock single player perks such as more control while in air but to unlock them is a challenge as you are always given a very short time limit to do whatever they ask of you.

Glory kills is in my opinion the greatest flaw in the combat. Killing wounded enemies in that matter makes them drop health for you which is weird but I can live with but the way it is implemented is terrible. When you shoot an enemy enough they have a very good chance of being stunned which in itself doesn't sound too bad but imagine being swarmed by enemies and shooting one point blank with a shotgun only for it to stagger a bit while you do the same to another enemy but that one explodes into bloody pieces. It feels very inconsistent and not killing them in time will have them recover to full health. So you either waste some more ammo to kill the stunned enemy or enter a cheesy animation that is far too zoomed in on the enemy making it very hard to see what's going on in the battlefield while manhandling that demon for a few seconds.

Snapmap is ID's replacement for proper modding and allows you to make preset rooms and place enemies as well as edit gameplay options such as movement speed, damage and game mode rules. You'll see stuff like survival modes, playing as demons and a weird Harvest Moon clone to name a few of the creative things you can do. It's pretty easy to use and maps are all shared between PS4, Xbx1 and PC which is going to lead to a massive amount of options for the fanbase. It is a double edged sword though. Since maps have to be playable on the hardware of the consoles there is a pretty small limit to the amount you can add to the maps. You and up to three strangers can play on multiplayer supported Snap maps. Multiplayer is where Doom 2016 falls on it's face. Perks, small uninteresting maps and taunts like a dudebro teabagging option make this portion of the game feel run of the mill. Not to mention the two weapon limit, loadouts where you can start with any weapon you want and the season pass that focuses entirely on multiplayer and will most likely split up the playerbase. Team Deathmatch's only unique feature is the ability to play as a demon. It's a pretty annoying feature that has a rune randomly spawn on the map with a few seconds of warning. It would have been better to announce it far ahead of its spawn arrival to cause players to fight over that area instead of blind luck to have it. When all is said and done Doom 2016's is a flawed yet fun overall package but its campaign is one of the best the FPS genre has had to offer in a very long time and one I'm itching to replay time and time again.

reviewText:
DOOM 4 is fast, gory, chaotic and blast!

One of the best single player campaigns I have played in years, perhaps one fo the best ever. The momentum and the pacing of this game are freakishly good. The level design and added depth is just fantastic. Each level is a sprawling open map that all last more than an hour.  Theres half a dozen secrets per level as well, I only ever managed to find 1/4 of them. You can also find parts of classic DOOM levels and play the full levels outside of the main campaign.

I could only describe DOOM 4's singleplayer as near perfect.

If theres on very small issue I had with its the fact that some of the jumping puzzles in the early and mid game drag on for abit too long and are just kinda annoying.

Overall multiplayer is not worth bothering with, it hasnt really improved from the BETA and its not even by Id anyway. It was outsourced to a studio that does Halo and CoD stuff. Snap map on the other hand has some potential to be a really great tool for DOOM modders and level designers to make some really great stuff. I cant wait to play some of the levels by the community soon.

Finally If you dont have a 900+ plus card you can expect some preformance issues. For the most part with my 770 the game ran fine on high settings at 60 fps but I would experiance the rare frame rate drop which brought it down to 15fps for some bizarre reason. Across all cards and systems there have been some random and really annoying crashes.

All in all its a great game, RIP AND TEAR

666/Cyberdemon

reviewText:
Doom is back, this time back as close as it can to its roots, while putting on new polish and new features. However, does it have enough to be the Doom folks have been wanting since the 90s? The answer is a definite 'Yes!', with a caveat or two. Doom delivers a solid singleplayer experience with plenty of love and attention to gameplay, bits of story, and speed. The multiplayer aspect feels like an afterthought, or worse, shoehorned in to try to grasp the old days of Doom multiplayer, while trying to keep it modern, which fails as the system is drastically different than what’s seen in the Singleplayer.

Overall, a must have to any FPS Enthusiast of the 90s, or those who definitely enjoy the frantic pace of the Doom series (not including Doom 3).

Graphics: 10/10
Id Software went out of their way to make some solid effort to bring back the foreboding atmosphere to abandoned facilities all the way to Hell's jagged mountains and corridors. Every sight is as foreboding as it is impressive to the eye, not once leaving the proper atmosphere of the invasion of Mars. Enemies themselves are painstakingly put together in great detail from the Possessed all the way to the Cyberdemon (something you can inspect in great detail later in the game in the gallery). Special effects and particles all play out well, leaving the game a beautiful sight.

Audio: 8/10
Music composed to this game is a nostalgic gamer's dream mixed into a new players love for intense song. Mixing in old classic tunes from the old games for remixes for a modern finish that will speak to old school gamers while still leaving the newcomers enjoying the throbbing tone of a fight in their ears. There are times when the music difference can in fact feel a little jarring, as the difference between fights and exploration ambiance music can be as different as night and day. This does happen a bit in Hell as music can come between hard techno, to suddenly the hellish chorus and orchestra echoing in your speakers. However, the real treat comes from the work put into the guns and the monsters. Almost every gun in the game has avoided the 'nerf gun' feel of firing, from the combat shotgun's ringing blast, all the way to the chaingun firing at full throttle. Only one gun in the collection feels a bit disappointing, the pistol, while only really necessary early game, it never feels like its got much impact in the sound of the shot, but this is minor.

Gameplay: 9/10
It's fast, its chaos, and its gory. The Devs really did listen to their fans this time around, trading the creeping and paranoid inducing feeling of Doom 3, and replacing it with fast run n' gun action that leaves it dangerous to stop at any point in the fight. Of course, there are small respites you can find here and there between fights that allow you to take a breath, but at the same time, while the game is fast paced and chaotic, it doesn't discourage exploration either. With secrets and badly needed supplies everywhere, you can always back track, as most of the time, it'll be rare a portion of the map will be gated off after a certain amount of progress. There are a few negative points, such as the over reliance of the Glory Kill system, especially in later levels where its not an option, its almost mandatory. (Details discussed below) However, every punch, every shot, ever messy take down brings a satisfying sense of speed and thrill that few FPS grasp these days.

Longevity / Replayability: 9/10
Contrary to rumors, DOOM is packed with content from start to finish, most of it all in the Singleplayer, which after my playthrough, lasted between 18-20 hours on the highest difficulty available right out of the box (Ultra-Violence). From secrets, challenges in every map, collectibles to obtain, weapon mods to add to your arsenal, its quite a bit to all get. Thankfully, all this is not locked away should you miss it on finishing a map. You can return to any map any time with all currently obtained equipment and upgrades, allowing you to use the advantage to take on a challenge, or get a leg up to finally reach that possible secret you were having trouble with. That said, all secrets and challenges can be done with the default gear you have during that part of the game. (Eg. No challenges / secrets that cannot be reached without double jump in maps prior to obtaining that skill). After completing the game, you still have time to challenge yourself with two new difficulty settings (Acting much like New Game+), Nightmare, and Ultra-Nightmare, where the latter throws the challenge of permadeath. SnapMap and Multiplayer also add to this, but we'll get into that next.

Multiplayer: 6.5/10
Regretfully, once you load the Multiplayer up, be it SnapMap or Standard Multiplayer, the game changes drastically from its fast paced Singeplayer counterpart. The multiplayer works on a loadout and leveling system, most of which rewards you with cosmetics. Gameplay-wise, the speed is taken down several notches, and the wild combat is somewhat muted, as the guns don't quite have the same impact, and since they are given in loadouts, guns like the Super Shotgun and Rocket Launcher don't quite have the impact folks would expect. There are options to run classical rules, but some of these matches seem devoid of players at this time. Sadly, this part of the game feels shoehorned, simply there to make multiplayer a 'thing' in Doom, which fails to quite grasp the feeling of urgency and intensity.

SnapMap, however, does add some creative credence to the idea of custom work and mod work, adhering to the idea that Doom is a mod friendly game. However, in that same stroke, actual mods of the games players could make are no longer viable. SnapMap replaces this by giving folks tools to make their own maps from between staged Multiplayer, deadly onslaught mode coop, to even missions of their very own to test other players. Including trials to test your modding skill to improve / complete a map, to letting you publish and share your work. More and more features in regards to cosmetics, textures, and objects. The downside is that the setup is rather simplistic, and scripts are rather dumbed down, making it easy for newcomers, but more advance map makers are left wanting more. Possible upgrades later, but for now, it feels like it could do much much more for what its promising.

OVERALL: 8.5/10

Disclaimer: Review was based off a full campaign run on Ultra-Violence difficulty. And 4 hours of Multiplayer and SnapMap
System Specs
Intel i7
geForce 980 GTX
16Gb RAM DDR5
500 SSD

reviewText:
For new players, Doom offers an interesting break from the usual first-person shooter style you might be familiar with (Call of Duty, Halo 5, etc.) and instead puts a focus on in-your-face, bloody combat. You'll be close with your enemies in this game, rather than picking them off from a longer distance. And it's this close-quarters focus that really brings out the game's intensity. It's constant, fast-paced action all the way through, with only occasional breaks from the carnage.

For classic Doom veterans, this game is not too far from the norm of a Doom game. It's fast-paced, visceral and brutal. You can feel like a true badass again, destroying anything in your path, but you're never shy of a challenge. The demons will mess you up if you don't keep yourself killing. And of course, just like any true Doom game, you should always be on the move.

The campaign has a nice story to it, but it rarely forces you to pay attention to it. You spend more time killing demons, which is a great thing. Most story segments you can actually just walk away from and continue killing.

Doom also introduces some new mechanics, such as glory kills - fully animated executions performed against your enemies, each one gory and...well, glorious. You have a variety of unique guns to choose from, just like any good first-person shooter, but in singleplayer, you get to modify your weapons with upgrades, new firemodes, and the like. You can also upgrade your suit abilities in singleplayer - anything from blast resistance, to a more intricate map. Further suit upgrades can be achieved through obtaining runes - gained by completing quick challenges. These runes let you get new benefits, such as armor-for-kills or increased mobility.

The multiplayer modes are, surprisingly, a really strong point of the game. Deathmatch game modes can get hectic and crazy, especially if you bring friends along. The demon rune" - a powerup that lets you turn into a demon for a short amount of time - can be a real game changer

reviewText: This game is ♥♥♥♥ing amazing. It's metal as hell, and I love it. The Doom series has been my #1 favorite game franchise since I was a young lad, so I had my expectations set pretty high. And as far as the campaign goes, it did not dissapoint. Everything from the brutal, gory combat and gunplay to the industrial and metal soundtracks that play while you obliterate horde after horde of demons is exceptional. My only compaints would be that the campaign didn't feel as long as it should have been, and the multiplayer was not quite the arena shooter I was hoping for. But, hopefully Bethesda and id Software will bring us more great story mode content, and even fix up the multiplayer a bit, fingers crossed. At the end of the day, I would highly recommend this game for the campaign alone, and would definitely suggest it to any fan of Doom or FPS fan in general.

reviewText:
I was initially very sceptical about the game. A very long and troubled development cycle, no review copies sent out before release, a multiplayer that was poorly received and did not sound or look all that exciting.

I did end up getting it anyway (a good deal on greenmangaming), I had to see what id had done to make a follow-up to what was perhaps my two most favorite games ever.

About 5 seconds after the loadscreen is gone you have a gun in your hand and are shooting zombie guys. 30 seconds later you've violently destroyed a couple more in grotesquely violent melee animations and picked up a shotgun. Shortly you're off over the surface of Mars, through a bunch of sci-fi facilities in the sort of style that Doom 3 laid out, but far more open, expansive and brightly lit. The game looks great, even on medium settings (+85% res) that I was forced to run it at to get a performance that'd sit stable in the 45-60fps range. (2560x1440, 2gb 680gtx, i5 3570k, 16gb ram).

Melee finishing animations were a hotly debated topic, but they are so short they don't interrupt the flow of combat. In later levels they become sort of your in-combat health-regen and later on you can equip a powerup to shorten their duration further.

The gunplay is extremely enjoyable, every single gun has a distinct feel, good sound effects, nice visuals and all are upgradable with interesting alternate firemods that can be upgraded further to improve on their effect, ending up in a Mastery Unlock that buffs the alternate mode fully.

The enemy gallery is almost entirely the classic Doom lineup buffed with a few extra new monsters and new takes on former humans.

Absent from the game are the Arachnotron and the Archvile, the latter replaced by the Summoner the Summoner, a sort of new version of the Archvile. It doesn't feel as threatening, but it shares the agility and speed of all the other monsters in this game.

Which is something quite new and fresh in the FPS genre. The monsters literally jump and climb all over the environment, dodging and weaving to avoid your shots or position themselves to rain lasers down on you. You'll be doing the same, moving with speed up and down ledges, no fall damage is present, so your freedom to move is great. Later in the game you'll get a double-jump and a powerup that lets you move faster after performing melee kills, a powerup that lets you control yourself while in the air much like in Quake 1 and powerups that let you engage melee kills from farther away.
All this combines to a combat system that feels smooth, precise, extremely fun and very rewarding.

I find it to the game's credit that dying seems entirely my own fault for not taking good enough advantage of the options allowed me. And the options are many. You can carry all the game's weapons and you will be swapping between them often and you'll have many, many available approaches in every single fight.

The soundtrack is blazing modern industrial style metal in combat, out of combat there is a light ambient drone, all of it heavily inspired by the original Doom soundtrack. There are many, many eastereggs and little things paying homage to the original games in here and it's clear that it's been made by someone who obviously cared a lot.

With the snapmap editor allowing community creations and a robust replayability, I foresee Doom staying on my drive for quite a while. I hope to see more.

I have not had any experience with the multiplayer, but I'll probably take a look at some point, but it's not why I bought the game and not why you should either, I'd reckon.

Highly recommended.

reviewText: I've hated AAA games for a while at this point; they've conditioned me to expect nothing good or fun from a reboot or modernization of an old game or the schlock that gets peddled and shilled all over the internet (granted that DOOM also got a lot of advertising in the same vein as well). DOOM (4) is the first game in a long time to give me hope, especially from an idthesda game, that it's possible for the old school to get a fresh coat of paint and still look good.\n\nThe game is raw and non-stop combat with large sprawling levels with lots of vertical and horizontal movement and plenty of demons to blast. Visuals have only been getting better since the Build Engine, and as much as I've hated the modern idtech engine games (MEGATEXTURES DURRRR), idthesda has managed to actually make them work. There are lots of little gameplay details that keep the game moving (weapon wheel bound to one button, fast glory kills" that give back health a la 40k Space Marine
date: etc). It's one of the best games I've played in a long time and I don't regret paying release price. Their version of the Reflex map-maker and Halo 3's FORGE is great as well; doesn't have the customization of a Build Engine .wad but the gameplay is still there and at the end of the day

reviewText: The cerebral slaughterhouse has been resurrected after 12 long years, and it's now morphed into a slicker beast. This time, the emphasis is more on pace & strafing than Doom 3, but in doing so sacrifices any proper narrative and removes the fear-factor it's predecessor had. Also, you no longer encounter any other survivors at the UAC facility, or get to wield the Crucible Artifact, making the whole experience feel a little hollow. None the less, hoards of Doom fans will still lap this up as it up's the brutal violence & Satanic sites, fusing it with thumping hardcore metal tunes. The new melee Glory Kills are a joy to execute when you're in a tight spot, and doesn't affect momentum. In it's current state, the single player campaign is a far more appealing experience over multiplayer.

reviewText:
Summary:
DOOM(2016) is not only just a great game, it is a great Doom game.  Unlike Doom 3 which tried to focus more on narrative and horror aspects, DOOM brings what fans always enjoyed about the series.  Fast paced action, gory kills, sprawling level design, epic music, and wonderful boss fights.  The story is minimal to non-existent, but that is a good thing, DOOM knows what it's doing, providing an avenue for players to experience the most adrenaline fueled gameplay of the past few years in gaming.

Pros:
-Excellent level design
-Return of Secrets" across each level
-"Always Run" is back
-Old School mechanics (health packs
date:

-Excellent visuals
-Well optimized for PC
-Gameplay is stellar
-Enemy design is grotesque and gory
-Memorable boss fights
-Snapmap is a great addition to the game
-Good length campaign (~10 hours on ULTRA-VIOLENCE difficulty)

Meh:
-Multiplayer is just OK
recommended:
some old school Doom fans will be disappointed

reviewText:
Finally, after more than a decade i have an opportunity to come back to my first and beloved videogaming franchise. Summing up my first hour experience:
1. Kick and punch.
2. Grab a gun.
3. Shoot.
4. Shoot MORE.
5. New gun/gear/upgrade WOW THANKS
6. Shoot again.
7. SECRETS? GIVE MORE
8, I NEED THAT SOUNDTRACK TO BE BOOMING A LOT LOUDER ID.
9. WHY DO I EVEN STOP TO WRITE A REVIEW?
Well, because this game deserves it, and because its not Doom 3: Part Two. And that is great!
Thats it, and that delivers gigantic amounts of fun, because it's executed on the highest possible level, with deep understanding of players' expectations on gameplay and leveldesign. It is true, Doom is indeed great, and the King of all shooters is back. Now with mutliplayer, fancy looks and DLCs (sure, its bethesda afterall)

reviewText:
I wasn't expecting much, but god dammit they've did it, a game that does Doom justice.

I'm blown away but how good the gameplay, graphics, smooth/responsive controls, enemies, weapons, speed, and most of all level design is.

Everything feels streamlined. The game knows it's an over-the-top action shooter about demons from hell, and it has FUN with it. You're constantly moving, as are the enemies, and it's the closest singleplayer FPS has ever come to reminding me of the old Quakeworld days of frantic movement, jumping around, shooting in mid-air, and so on.

The levels are full of hidden stuff, and generally there are very few points-of-no-return in each level (with the end-of-level being an obvious thing you have to explicitly trigger), meaning you can search for secrets through the level until you find them. The map and optional upgrades (in a light RPG system) can also help you locate secrets, or most of them at least.

I was sceptical about adding things like execution moves, double-jump and ledge-grabbing to Doom but having now played it, it all works and fits into the mechanics surprisngly well. (Executions are useful as they give you a little bonus health and ammo, for the small risk of having to get close to the enemy in time, although you need not get _that_ close. They're over very quickly, and if you really don't like them then you simply never push the button that does them and you'll never do them.)

SnapMap looks interesting, in terms of providing various types of extra maps and game modes you (and other players if you wish) can drop into, and make yourself. I haven't played with it much though, and it's early days in terms of seeing what other people can create.

I have no idea what the multiplayer is like as I have not tried that yet. After years of playing nothing but Quakeworld and then Counter-Strike, and later CoD:MW2, I try to avoid multiplayer as it can end up eating up so much time, and never ends. This was all about single-player fo rme, and the game has delivered well beyond expectations.

Highly recommended if you enjoy shooting demons in the face and searching multi-level, intricate levels for hidden stuff.

Runs and looks great on Ultra/1080p on my lowly GTX 960 (4GB). While it cannot quite maintain 60fps all the time, it's pretty close to it, and the adaptive v-sync means I rarely even notice. (Maybe the really well done motion blur helps as well? I don't consciously notice it is there, but it's very visible in still screenshots.)

reviewText:
===SINGLE PLAYER REVIEW ONLY===

So, you wana play Doom, eh? You wana play a good game? You're in luck. When they said the levels were linear, they lied. I got lost for a bit on level two. If that level is representative of the whole product, the level design is on par with the original. When they said it was slow, they lied. DoomGuy isn't as fast as the original, but he's fast. The weapon switch wheel is optional console garbage, and the infamous glory kills are decent speed.

Doom's all about the quick and dirty, so instead of writing a retrospective, I'll bombard you with bullet points, and I won't skimp on the negative aspects of the game.

The Good:
* Modern FPS hand holding is 100% optional. Compass markers, tutorials, press 'E' here" shimmer

reviewText:
This is what I wished hard Doom 3 would be back in the day. And Quake 4.

Quake 4 did a silly thing in hamstringing the player down paths like other corridor shooters of the time while the multiplayer was Quake 3 arena at the core. This relaunch of Doom has done the polar opposite where the multiplayer of the beta was slow while the pace of the primary game is ferocious as they come and on the higher difficulties is up there with Doom's spiritual successors like Serious Sam.

Doom does borrow from a lot of modern game mechanics like grenade cooldowns, weapon/armour upgrades and the like. However, it seems to blend in well and isn't a main distraction for the player. The execute-stunned-enemy-to-recover-health mechanic works well as the kills only take a second compared to the slow times of Space Marine and Hatred and help keep the player running on the fast dance of death.

Just try to remember not to grenade yourself, DoomGuy. Rip and Tear.

reviewText:
I was hesitant to pre-purchase Doom since there were practically no reviews for the game and I have been burned so many times by AAA titles.  After seeing the game released, I read nothing but great reviews so I chose to give it a shot...

It is Doom.

This title in the series has taken the graphics from today's generation of video games and applied it to the classic FPS game play of the old Doom.  While the single player aspect of the game will seem a little short, it makes up the difference in replayability and secrets.

Unlike most of todays games, this one has a little story with some minor cut scenes sprinkled into the game play to keep the story moving along from loction to loction.  The game play moves most of the games story forward and the plot is true to the classic Doom and goes something like this:

SPOILER ALERT:
A portal to hell is open and demons are pouring forth.
Kill them.

I know, with a plot that runs that deep it can be hard to follow...

Graphics 9/10 (Great, alomst perfect)
Sound 10/10 (Fantastic)
Game Play 10/10 (Sublime)
Story 9000/10 (This has the right amount of story for Doom)
Multiplayer 5/10 (Average.  Still I enjoyed it, but nothing complared to TF2/Overwatch)
Snapmap 7/10 (I was not impressed, but it is still new so this could easily go up as more maps are created)

The only issue I have with the game is sometimes it will crash to desktop.
Additionally, I have seen lots of complaints about the ending...  If you have ever beaten Doom/Doom 2/Doom 64, then you will be pleasantly supprised since the game will not end with a still shot and some text.

Overall: An enjoyable experiance.  Worh the price of admission.

Intel i7 @ 3gzh running in an old Gateway 870 rig
16 gigs System RAM
Nvidia 960 FTW ed. w/4 gigs RAM

reviewText:
+ Fast, fluid gameplay succesfully capturing most of the old school DooM feel
+ I love the fragmented metal-industrial-glitchy soundtrack. It's tight, modern, dynamic and brutal. It's not as rememberable als Doom 1 or 2, but it gets me in the mood all the time.
+ You know what I despise about modern shooters? The fact that you can't backtrack from start to end of a level. None of this in Doom 4. You can fully explore back and forwards at your own damn leisure just like old times.
- [edit:]...at least, that's what I thought. Unfortunately there are some too many points where the level designers thought it *would* be a good idea not to let the player backtrack all the way to the start. A weak, infuriating and ununderstandable design choice. [/edit]
+ And there's a lot to find and explore on the levels. I would recommend disabling the compass and using the map to a bare minimum because that makes it a bit too easy to discover everything, but on the other hand.. well, suit yourself.
-+ There are some very hard to find secrets, if you're set on discovering all of the classic maps. It's fun to actually discover one yourself without looking it up on the internet, but it's not likely to happen with every one of them.
+ I actually like the weapon and armor upgrade system. It's redundant, but at the same time fun enough to keep yourself occupied with so why not. Same goes for the challenge levels.
+- Enemies come in waves instead of placed thoughtfully throughout the levels. However these waves themselves have been orchestrated pretty well and are fun to beat, it's not too bad at all (one has got to love Painkiller after all).
+- There's still something left of the chunky, too shiny too clean too round environments that made me insta-dislike Doom 3 so much back then. But many improvements have been made over it, it does look and feels good this time around.
+- Also I'm not the biggest fan of the lighting used in this game. Sometimes it's perfectly fine, sometimes it gets very oversaturated and foggy. It's very nice and thoughtful that you can actually change the rendering to gritty or cinematic, although I find myself switching between the modes depending on where I am instead of just using one setting the whole time. It's a bit of a mixed bag to my taste.
- Still too much exposition. Why the hell do we need a boring generic seen-it-before-too-many-times storyline? This is not Doom 3 (thank god)
- This is Doom 4. Not Doom, not Doom 2016, Doom 4. Seriously, name your game properly guys.
- Just ignore the multiplayer. It's not Doom, it will never be Doom. Snap Map seems interesting though, but I yet have to dive into that at this point.

All in all this game actually turned out to be great. It was really hard to believe anything good would come out of this game after that very mediocre multiplayer open beta, but you better believe it: Doom 4 is awesome. Highly recommended.

reviewText:
What an absolute gem this game is. id shows nobody can outdo them in the genre they invented.

First off this game is absolutely gooorgeous. No brown hallways here. Everything is super vibrant and the vast mars landscape views are really something. And it plays even better than it looks. Long gone are the dark hallways and spooky scares of the old games. They've been replaced with high octane encounters full of a variety of monsters requiring the player to think on their feet while blasting away.

Each gun and the player himself is also customizable in their mechanics, allowing the player to really tweak their experience to their play style.

It's just, a marvel. Seriously. I'm in love. Probably the best pure fps flow/ mechanics game ever made. Period.

Absolutely perfect 10/10.

reviewText: I'm far from completing Doom 4 but the campaign feels like the old Doom I remember. Its fast and frenetic. Bethseda also brought back the Cacodemons missing in Doom3 so I'm happy. I havn't tried the multiplayer yet which was disappointing in the beta release. The graphics on my MSI GTX 780 have been solid. If you access the Doom console you can check the FPS using com_showfps 1 and switch it off with com_showfps 0. I'm getting a steady 60fps with occasional dips but I've switched it off. There are also many other console commands with cheats like unlimited ammo, god mode etc but I'm not interested in those. There are secret areas which can be revealed. I'll probably try to find those on a separate play through. The melee works well and is important to use to preserve ammo in the harder settings. Bethseda did a decent job much better than Doom 3. Recommended.

reviewText:
This is DOOM 3.
Doom 3 never happened. Please, just trust me. Doom 3 literally does not exist. This game, however, is the actual DOOM 2 follow-up. Building on the spirit, speed and goregasm that made the original two the influential, industry significant and timeless games they are means this reboot needs to be celebrated.

Holy hell, this is beyond ultra-violence. There is so, so much blood. It's ridiculously fast. It's instantly fun. It's so sprawling in both its vertical and horizontal level design and best of all is that the single player campaign feels lovingly crafted. This is DOOM. This is DOOM 3. This is MY CHILDHOOD RELIVED.

Pure joy.

On a final note relating to performance; This PC release is easily the most optimised release I've experienced in a long time... and on a launch day. This too needs celebrating.

reviewText:
No more than 10 seconds into the game, you're already fighting. Shortly after that, yo're tearing demons up with a shotgun. From there, it just get's more brutal.

THIS is the Doom that long time FPS fans have been waiting for. With all the same crap flooding the genre, Doom is a welcome return to what made FPS games great.

- Fast paced combat with tight controls.
- Fight and move in every angle. Demonds don't just come at you from the front.
- Primary/secondary weapons? Nope! An arsenal on your back ensures you have multiple ways to fight at any time.
- Great graphics yet keeps minimum specs low.
- Lots of gore accompanied by heavy metal.
- Actually earn the right to feel like a badass, and not just an artifical winner (*cough* COD *cough*)
- Explore each map to find secrets, collectibles, weapons and ammo.
- Locked door? Dead end? Tough ♥♥♥♥. Find a key or another way. Prepare to explore each map.
- This is no corridor shooter. There is no one way only.
- There's a story... I guess. But that's not what you're here for.

The FPS genre is sorely missing this kind of fun gameplay. Future shooters can learn A LOT from Doom. Hell, they could learn a lot from any of the Doom games.

Overall, an excellent game and looking to be the shooter of the year. Maybe even the decade. Hell, since the last Doom.

Welcome home Doomguy. We missed you.

reviewText:
Would you like to relive the flavor of the first two games of the series with a modernized construction? This game will be a great choice for you! On the contrary of the Open Beta, it is possible to count plenty of pros for this one.

+ Being nested with the story line during the game less than Doom 3 is one of the major stuffs to relive the first two Doom games. The main story is as same as those of the previous games, nothing else. But if you look for a keen story line, this series is already the wrong address for you. Recall Carmack's idiom: Story in a game is like a story in a porn movie. It's expected to be there, but it's not that important. You'll just encounter some short cutscenes that do not affect keeping the entire action going on.

+ Some veins evoking the earlier Doom games like pressing Tab to see the map, grabbing the computer item called Area Map" to see the whole map
date: requirement to find colorized keys to unlock doors
recommended: presentation of the statistics at the end of a level regarding on how many monsters you have killed
hoursPlayed: how many secret areas you have found etc...\n\n+ Unlike Doom 3's atmosphere that gets boring and is usually formed by cheerless hallways

reviewText:
Hell Yeah!Rating : Excellent

(Played only single player)

Played lots of DOOM back in the days when I was young, remember playing it with a friend linking 2 PC's with a cross-cable. Great fun!

Nowadays the old DOOM feels a bit slow and bare. Sign of the times. This DOOM is a product of this age, and deliveres the goodies we expect, BUT with that same old run-and-shoot feeling like before. Damn, I really like this game and was having fun the first time I booted it up. Shoot, run, turn, dodge, jump, I like it. Just run across stuff to pick it up etc. Action all around until you get to the point that all demons are dead. Silence. Great. Unfortunately the bodies disappear, I think in the old DOOM they stuck around but can't be sure.

Love it! Sound(track) is also great, visuals are good, I like the mix of cell-shaded with the 'normal' visuals, mechanics are good (Jumps need to be good, not pixel perfect), weapons feel great most of the time.

All in all : instabuy imo

reviewText:
Welcome back to the old id.

Anyone who remembers the visceral feeling you first experienced playing Doom back in 1993 will fondly welcome the feelings again a mere 23 years later (!!).

This is classic id software telling the world that if there's an action packed FPS to be made, we're going to be the daddies. It's manic, fast paced, incredibly rewarding and utterly satisfying. I did not expect this game to be as good as it was but after having gone to bed 5am last night I can only tell you that the single player campaign has boiled down to its absolute core the very essence of pure gameplay.

It's epic.

reviewText:
Here's my very mixed recommendation. I went with Yes" because I at least liked the game enough to finish it and Steam doesn't have a "Maybe" option. I beat the campaign on ultra violence in 9 hours.

Pros
------------------------------
-It's Doom/Hell themed. We don't get too many gorgeous video games centered around Hell.
-It's well optimized. I was able to run the game on ultra settings at 2560x1440 while sticking mostly in the 50-60fps range off of a GTX 980.
-The sound design is great.
-They give you tons of options for customizing your HUD.
-Shooting demons in the face is fun.

Cons
------------------------------
-People seem to think this is just like good ol' Doom 1 & 2 but I really don't think they remember how those played. The levels in this are set up that you'll shoot a few weak enemies on your way to a main objective marker before getting trapped in an area that you can only get out of if you kill every last enemy in the room. This formula repeats throughout the entire game. There isn't a single room that I can recall like this in my beloved Doom 2. This in no way
recommended: or form is set up so you can just find the necessary keys and switches to complete a level while shooting anything that gets in your way. Shooting literally everyone in the face is the only way to progress the game. If you have never played Doom 1 or 2
hoursPlayed: the formula may still bother you but it's not as much of a letdown.\n-The story is forgettable at best. Even Doom 3 had a better reason for bringing Hell to Mars.\n-The game has pacing issues. The game has 3 speeds: stuck in a room listening to an awful story
voteText: shooting an imp or two while navigating through the map
helpfulPercent: and drinking from a firehose from hell once you're inevitably trapped in an area and forced to kill several waves of enemies.\n-Glory Kills are cool at first but once you realize that's the only way to guarantee a kill will yield health
votesHelpful: they get annoying. It would be really cool if it was just an optional way to take a demon down but it's mandatory if you value your life.\n-Some of the weapons feel under powered. It seems like a strange system to let you upgrade the hell out of your earlier weapons only to have them be complete garbage compared to the next gun that uses the same ammo type at stock.\n-The multiplayer is infamously average and they're selling a $40 season pass for it. Strange call."

reviewText:
The best way I can sum up DOOM 4:
If old DOOM was a rebellious teenager with an attitude and very strong views on what is cool or not,
then DOOM 4 is a 5 year old hyperactive brat with ADHD who lives to break things, scream at his parents and smash his action figures together till they break.
His mother has forgotten to give him his ritalin, and he won't stop until the entire family home is nothing but chaos.

DOOM 4 does to DOOM 1+2 what Hotline Miami 2 did to Hotline Miami 1. (If you know what I mean).

After the events of DOOM 1+2, Doomguy became so annoyed at the UAC and Hell that he decided to destroy every incarnation of hell he could find (WADs). The demons couldn't kill this man. He was becoming more than simply human.
Unable to kill Doomguy, the demons decided to trap him inside a mystical tomb to keep Hell safe. So scared of Doomguy waking up infact, that they would kill anybody who got too close to the tomb.

The UAC managed to recover the sarcophagus Doomguy was held inside, taking him back to Mars. However, Doomguy is a light sleeper.
The UAC are messing with Hell portals again. Demons are running amok once more with nobody to teach them a lesson. Won't they ever learn?

It the midst of all this chaos, it seems an ancient evil has awakened.
It's you.

reviewText:
As a singleplayer game, I love the new DOOM and would definitely recommend it. The campaign is very fun and doesn't waste your time with too much exposition, it thrusts you into the action right away. However, if you're looking for a multiplayer game, look elsewhere. While it isn't bad per se, it feels a bit generic, especially compared to the campaign.

Pros:
-Fast paced, challenging gameplay
-Feels like a modernized version of the classic (in a good way)
-Looks amazing, even on the lowest settings
-Tons of secrets
-Minimal cutscenes/story
-Good variety of weapons, both classic and new
-Great mix of exploration and combat
-Pacing feels almost perfect
-SnapMap works great, and there's already some pretty awesome fan-created levels

Cons:
-Multiplayer is mediocre and feels a bit generic
-SnapMap has some unnecessary limitations (such as only being able to carry 2 weapons)
-Regular deathmatch can only be done through SnapMap (which is limited to 4 players)
-The ending is kinda lame (not that it really matters)

reviewText:
DOOM 4 makes me happy to be alive.

It is a heartwarming game.

You can hug a demon until his head explodes.
You can massage his face with your boots until his head explodes.
You can tickle him with shotgun shells until his entire body explodes.
You can take his cold heart out of his chest, warm it up in your sweaty palms, and feed it to him.
Etc.

If you like life, you will like DOOM 4.

reviewText:
DOOM is amazing.

DOOM is a game with a big legacy and it certainly does exceed my expectations by far.
True to its 1993 incarnation, the story is interesting but not forced down your throat. You can ignore it nearly completly, if you want.
The gunplay is very solid and a nice throwback to times when FPS-Games were more about crosshair-control than aming down sights.
The graphics are more than impressive, it looks beatiful while still having the same asthetics as the original. Every demon and monster is recognizable and even sometimes even more threatening.

The multiplayer part of the game is also pretty solid in my opinion. It isn't a Quake Live but it does it's job well in my opinion.

Last but no least is the Snapmap feature. Which is in my opinion a welcome addition to DOOM. It allows for creativity in the community, even people who are not that into modding can create.

Final Verdict: 666/10 Go to Hell! It will be a pleasant trip. ^^

reviewText:
Maybe one day I will write a more detailed review with my thoughts, but for now you should know that this is genuniely one of the best FPS to come out in recent times.

Immensely fun, looks lovely and knows that it is a game and not a film, book or anything else.

Like I say, maybe one day I'll expand on this, but I just wanted to add my positive review because this game really really deserves it. Not just another shooter, an excellent shooter that for me is right up there with Wolfenstien The New Order, and anyone that enjoyed that is likely to enjoy this.

Great game and I am already hoping against hope that we have a new rebooted series on our hands and this isn't just a one off. I hope you get to play it and enjoy it as much as I am. Congrats to everyone involved.

Outstanding campaign, outstanding fun and not bad multiplayer to boot.

reviewText:
Well the game is called doom.
It has demons in it.
You kill demons in a very visceral manner.
You kill demons in a very visceral manner in a hellscape filled with gigantic skulls.
When you shoot demons enough you can perform a variety of manuevers ranging from tearing out
their respiratory organs and shoving them down their soficus to performing open heart surgery with a chainsaw. It's filled with blood. (I like blood.)

You start on mars, there are alot of demons and zombies and things to kill.
There are big guns to find, some go BANG, some go PEW PEW PEW PEW!, some go BOOOOM!
You have to run around to find them, opening doors, punching things, collecting corpses. (my fav)
Sometimes there will be doors you need a keycard for, you will need to find that to get big guns.

You can kill your friends, which is cool with those big guns in multiplayer games.
multiplayer is okay i guess, nothing special. Not as good as killing demons.

Snapmap is cool, i like torturing the player. So i set up a map with blood red filter, multiple speakers rigged with sirens so when they spawn in to multiple barons of hell, with a puny combat shotgun in their hands and a terrible case of tinnitus in their ears they can sympathize with my day to day life.
Then die.


overall i would recommend
i like killing demons

reviewText:
A must buy!

Graphics: Looks beauitful, high resolution textures, high poly models and incredible lighting make this game one of the best looking games this year. Performance is amazing ( running Titan X ) and acheive 100fps+ on 1440p and near solid 60fps at 4k on a single GPU.


Sound: Bullets have impact and weapons like the BFG deliver huge bass drops.

Gameplay: Old-school with a modern twist. No BS just run and gun with tons of secrets to find. Boss fights are awesome and require skill and timing on higher difficulties.


Overall: A wonderful game to play that will hook you within the first few minutes. Killing demon's hasn't been this fun in years.

reviewText:
If...

- If you are 40+ like I am
- If your first game was Pong on TV
- If you grew up with shooters like Doom, Quake, Wolfenstein, CoD 1 until 4
- If you like fast, very fast gunplay (no reloading etc)
- If you don't dislike lots of gore

Then this game is a MUST BUY!

THE best shooter in 20 years!

reviewText:
A review of the blood and gore effects in DOOM

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jitdRJ49iPo

The verdict:
Good looking body damage (though the mechanics themselves are somewhat limited)
Awesome executions and player deaths
Blood spilling looks great, the mechanics themselves are not bad though could be expanded

Biggest issues are the disappearing mess (in 10 seconds or so) and the lack of behavior changes for wounded characters (especially important when it comes to bullet sponges that can take a lot of damage)

In general the experience is somewhat responsive, hope permanent (or near permanent) mess can be modded in sometime in the future

reviewText:
Its not perfect. Takes some tweaking to get SLI to work. I have a GTX 690 and now with a combination and ultra and high features (vram limit) and activating SLI in NVidia control panel. Plays perfectly at 60+ fps...

Minus that one hangup (No true SLI profile yet) THIS GAME IS FLIPPING AWESOME. OMG OMG OMG OMG OMG OMG. This game signal handily saved me from never buying a computer game again after the Batman AK fiasco. This is how you release a game. Not totally perfect but still great and enjoyable.

As far as the game itself. There is a story, not much. But something to follow along to but the main point of this game is shoot and kill, repeat that step 10000 times and it  never gets old. This is how I like FPS shooters to be. Thank you id for answering prayers and keeping it old school. I haven't enjoyed a doom game this much since the first one. 1 was great, two was good, 3 I have my reserves against it, but this, this master piece you have here. Truly a great game. If you guy's are reading this. Thank you. And for anyone thinking of buying, BUY IT NOW!!!!!!!
voteText: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
tl;dr: if you have doubts about this game.. don't. this game is good. go get it. now. do yourself a favor.

pros:

this game is good. like.. really good.

they managed to get that fast-paced run'n'gun feel from the first two games done perfectly in this game. this is what doom 3 should have been.

there are a lot of new things added into the formula this time around, like the execution moves, a double jump feature, a progression and by extension, upgrade system, but none of it seems tacked on or gimmicky. everything blends together perfectly.

upon seeing the reveal trailers, i was catiously optimistic regarding the execution attacks. people said they'd become old and monotonous really fast, and i thought so too, but there are like 20 different execution animations for every enemy depending on which bodypart, and from what angle you attack, and they're all very.. visually satisfying, and also go by really quickly, so it doesn't feel like it slows down the game.

another thing about the execution moves is that enemies killed in such a manner drop health and other items when you kill them, so you get rewarded by going up close and personal. nothing feels quite as exciting as running between the legs of 3 barons of hell to get to one vulnerable mancubus while you got 20 health, just to rip its heart out, and forcefeed the damn thing its own innards, then get enough health from the ordeal to survive a ♥♥♥♥♥slap of green plasma.
regaining health from melee attacks eliminates my one and only gripe with the original games; having to stop fighting when i get hurt to backtrack through the map to find leftover health items. this new system helps keeping the pace going fast, and the action high. love it.

i mentioned the double jump right? if you've played metroid prime, then you know what this means. verticality. and lots of open ended exploring. the original games had secrets all over the damn place. this game is no different. and no different from other new" ID games
hoursPlayed: you can unlock secret levels from the original games. also there are doomguy bobbleheads. and upgrade chips for your suit to hunt down
voteText: as well as new attachments for your weapons.\nfinding secrets and doing certain challenges on each level will earn you upgrade points
helpfulPercent:
which allows me to segway into..

..the upgrade system. what? you don't think doom needs an upgrade system? think again!
you can upgrade your guns with said attachments
votesHelpful: like a multi-missile launcher for your assault rifle
votesTotal: which you can then upgrade to remove the need to reload  it
votesFunny: and make it fire almost indefinitely. you can get a burst-fire attachment for your shotgun and upgrade it to do more damage depending on your accuracy. most weapon attachments have three upgrades you can buy for upgrade points

reviewText:
tl;dr: if you have doubts about this game.. don't. this game is good. go get it. now. do yourself a favor.

pros:

this game is good. like.. really good.

they managed to get that fast-paced run'n'gun feel from the first two games done perfectly in this game. this is what doom 3 should have been.

there are a lot of new things added into the formula this time around, like the execution moves, a double jump feature, a progression and by extension, upgrade system, but none of it seems tacked on or gimmicky. everything blends together perfectly.

upon seeing the reveal trailers, i was catiously optimistic regarding the execution attacks. people said they'd become old and monotonous really fast, and i thought so too, but there are like 20 different execution animations for every enemy depending on which bodypart, and from what angle you attack, and they're all very.. visually satisfying, and also go by really quickly, so it doesn't feel like it slows down the game.

another thing about the execution moves is that enemies killed in such a manner drop health and other items when you kill them, so you get rewarded by going up close and personal. nothing feels quite as exciting as running between the legs of 3 barons of hell to get to one vulnerable mancubus while you got 20 health, just to rip its heart out, and forcefeed the damn thing its own innards, then get enough health from the ordeal to survive a ♥♥♥♥♥slap of green plasma.
regaining health from melee attacks eliminates my one and only gripe with the original games; having to stop fighting when i get hurt to backtrack through the map to find leftover health items. this new system helps keeping the pace going fast, and the action high. love it.

i mentioned the double jump right? if you've played metroid prime, then you know what this means. verticality. and lots of open ended exploring. the original games had secrets all over the damn place. this game is no different. and no different from other new" ID games

reviewText:
THE DOOM WE HAVE ALL WAITED FOR, THE SEASON PASS WE HAVE NOT

The single player campaign so far has honestly been the most refreshing immersive gameplay and the balance between plot and classic deathmatch style killing is perfect. Not only has this release featured throwback gameplay combat elements, it has completely out shown the recent trend of monotonous red screen duck and wait shooters that have become a fps genre norm.

Bringing back the classic health and armor pickups was genius, but I was not looking forward the the issues this classic system brought with limited item availability per level, the search this involved, and limitations it made. With this release ID has completely revamped the mechanic and has incorporated them into a driving force to live and push the player to take increasingly higher risks to succeed and excel in combat.

A problem with many classic run and gun shooters was in many ways the monotonous non stop action. There were rarely moments for the player to stop and be immersed in the story or environment. The constant push to continue moving the entire game caused in a large part a haze over the experience. Going through a level would often simply involve mashing keys and constantly clicking the mouse until the next loading screen. It even popularized buying a mouse with auto-fire button so you would not tire your finger and hardware.

With this release of doom it has not only brought back the positives of that classic gameplay but has remastered it in a way that brought a balance to combat, plot, unlockables, secrets, and character progression that is a evolution in a lot of ways doom 3 was with it's unique 2 way lighting engine that inspired a more reserved horror survival style incorporating the ability to choose between seeing the horror that befell UAC Mars and actually being able to combat it to survive.

I am 12 hours into DOOM and constantly remarking how impressed I have been so far and continue to be.

THIS IS THE DOOM WE HAVE ALL WAITED FOR.

Unfortunately, the season pass is not. At this point it is shown as only featuring content for online combative multiplayer and snap map features.

As a classic DOOM fan, I am not interested a COD online rehash or Halo reach style unlockable armor skin dress up features.

I am here for the campaign. The continuation of a world I have grown up with and continue to want to learn more about. The one that I am consistently learning more about every time I replay Doom 3 and re-live emails, audio logs, video training sessions, and immersive plot elements.

This recent release of DOOM brought back the classic gameplay I loved with the originals and paid respect to Doom 3 and continuation of the revolution in immersive content and gameplay.

The Season pass does not, but there is hope.

As doom 3 had a full game expansion, and wolfenstein the new order also has a full game expansion bad blood" I am hoping that if there is not going to be included either several small dlc levels
date: expanded single player content included campain levels or secrets
hoursPlayed: mods
voteText: or the ability to co-op the existing single player campaign with increased difficulty included in this upcoming season pass then hopefully an additional full game expansion will be released in the near future.\n\nAs a long standing doom fan I have waited years for a new release.  So often with new pc releases in the past couple years we have not only had sub par performance with console ports
helpfulPercent: bad hardware support
votesHelpful: horrible optimization issues
votesTotal: locked or not available settings
votesFunny:
but the fact that most games for pc upon release will crash and not even run until patched months later by the video card manufacturer as developer support after the base release is continually dropped soon after collection of pre-order funds.

ID delivered on it's promise to the doom community and brought a sequel we can stand by and continue to play for many years to come. They brought the PC gaming community a stable release including everything we need and continue to lack from most recent releases.

All I am asking for is the same I have been asking for many years now. I WANT MORE DOOM."

reviewText:
Single player? Absolutely spot on.  No, it's ♥♥♥♥ing PERFECT.  You'll be tearing the map inside out looking for those last damned secrets, the fights just get better and better the more enemy types they throw at you (and the more firepower you throw back) and the Nightmare difficulty is actually a challenge.  I'm frankly amazed that they translated the gameplay so well to a modern game, from essentially a 2D topology (and gameplay) to 3D as well.

Multiplayer? Meh.  Needs some more work.  The weapons are inherently unbalanced and the guns are not satisfying.  The speed is okay but feels slower than it actually is because too many of the wrong weapons are weak e.g. rocket launcher, and the game is very unhappily married with this horrendous two-weapon loadout system.  Why did they have to introduce THAT element, especially when the single player game does not, thank God?  Also the announcer sounds like he's a centuries-old wizard with just as much understanding of the game.  Bad, bad.  Tragic thing is the finishing-touch work to make multiplayer as evil and nosebleed-inducing as it ought to be is a couple of hours work, if that.  Except for new VA work, obviously.

Overall get it today for the satisfying single player, if you're a Doom fan.  Don't bother with multiplayer until it's actually worked on a bit more.  The multiplayer would probably be a bit more okay if the single player wasn't such a glorious masterpiece right alongside it, making the multiplayer look even more of an afterthought.

Snapmap is more of the same as multiplayer sadly, the tool itself is pretty darned cool but for all of its options it is limited by the imposed limits set to keep the framerate up on consoles and minimum spec PCs.  Come on guys... the best part of the game is the part you refused to advertise.
