reviewText:
I'll update this as I continue through the game, but here are my initial thoughts:

This game instantly feels more like DOOM than any game since 1996. Combat is extremely fast-paced, and by the second mission, even on the normal difficulty, you're circle-strafing around the room just trying to stay alive while you pick off anything you can. It feels like the most intense Ultra-Violent maps from the original games, with movement speed turned up beyond Nightmare! levels.

One of the major strengths of the originals' design was the weapon balance, in that every weapon was a tool for a specific job. That has returned in an even more pronounced way with the new DOOM. It's clear the developers understand, gameplay-wise, what made the originals so good. From what I can tell, they've captured and refined those qualities here.

UPDATE:

My initial review was written while I had something like ~7 hours in the game. At the time of this update, I've played about 40 hours, the vast majority of tha being the singleplayer campaign and maybe ~10% of it in team deathmatch.

I've completed the singleplayer campaign from scratch twice now, once on Ultra-Violence and once on Nightmare.

I'll elaborate on what I've already written. DOOM (2016) gets everything right that the first game did, and in fact, does it better. Aesthetics aside, what made the first game so cool was its gameplay elements consisting of harmonization between the weapon balance, player movement, and enemy types and what they brought to the table for you to work with.

The first game had enemies that caused you to use certain weapons depending on your position in relation to theirs, as well as affecting your movement. Dodge projectiles by strafing, evade the demon by backpeddling, keep enemy positions in check by charging forward. Take cover against hitscan weapon enemies. This game features all of this and more. Well, actually I guess not hitscan enemies, but I digress.

Player movement is extremely fast, lack of bunnyhopping notwithstanding, and movement is absolutely essential to success. This is the only game I've ever played that kind of felt like the original DOOM's movement. The inertia isn't quite there, nor is wallrunning, but it feels right, and it feels good.

Combat is very hard until you have enough experience to understand what to upgrade and how to leverage your strengths. I recommend starting on Ultra-Violence and moving up. It will challenge you hard, and it's fun every second of the way.

The soundtrack is brutal and intense. The compression on the drums, especially, makes for some psychotic slams and it fits the combat very well. There are hints of old DOOM songs in there, too, so veterans that listen closely might be able to pick them out. Off the top of my head, I can think of four references that are present in varying degrees of completeness.

Commentary on game systems and multiplayer might be coming in the future with another update.

Bottom line is this: I've only fallen harder for this game after spending ~30 more hours playing since the initial write-up. I still highly recommend this. I believe this is probably the best singleplayer shooter ever created.

UPDATE 2: Multiplayer

I've spent the last three days or so playing a lot of team deathmatch. I've managed to level up to Echelon 3 rank 20-something (that means level to 50, then level to 50 again, and again, and then 20-something more levels) (updated: I've since leveled to echelon 6 and I might get to 8 before I sleep tonight). Somewhere between 15-20 hours of play I think (now over 30).

DOOM TDM is the best Halo game ever for PC. Why do I (and others) compare the game to Halo? There is an unmistakable influence found in everything from the announcer's tone, to the game design, down to the player models and maps. Everything in the MP game's design has been touched by the influence of Halo. Let me elaborate before rambling on random multiplayer thoughts.

Let's start by pointing out that it just doesn't feel like id deathmatch. Two-weapon loadouts. Power weapons. There are only team modes. No duel modes. Only huge, extremely complex maps. The weapon set has been expanded with several new items that specifically feel very Halo. There's not only one sniper weapon (the vortex rifle). There are like three. That's very Halo. There's even one called the BR that shoots in bursts of three, which ought to remind any Halo veteran of a certain infamous weapon from the past. While there are (thankfully) no vehicles, there are demon powerups, which are a kind of analog to Halo's vehicles. The person controlling the demon can absolutely dominate unless the opposing team coordinates a focused attack. Nevertheless, the inclusion of explicit demons from the campaign (baron, revenant, mancubus) is one of the only distinctly DOOM things in the multiplayer. Hell, they can't even bring themselves to use the word frags
date: something found in every id Software deathmatch game since the original DOOM. Until now. Now, they're just kills
recommended:
just like Halo.

Is this a bad thing? It's not bad, per se. It's very fun. But I have to warn you, if you're looking for the next installment of classic id Software multiplayer, this is not it. But again, it's very fun and addictive. So whatever issues I raise from here on out, keep that in mind. And keep in mind that I'm nowhere near done playing it; I plan to level to Echelon 10 level 50 (the current cap). It should probably take 1.5-2 weeks if I play every day. So look, it's cool. Now onto some commentary about mechanics.

This is where my thoughts get weird. This is a video game, so does anything matter other than the fun factor? The game's MP is fun. But I have to say, it's like the junk food of game design. What I mean is, it's a team-based shooter (no duel mode in sight), just like Halo. But the rewards systems are all about your individual performance. It hardly matters if your team wins. Hell, it doesn't really matter that much if you die a lot, provided you get roughly as many kills as deaths. You get bonuses on top of bonuses when you kill with the absurdly overpowered power weapons
hoursPlayed: a borrowed maxim of Halo. The team as a whole doesn't really benefit from controlling the map, other than winning" but who cares about that? It's all about you and your points and progression. Hell
voteText: there's a large health pickup literally around every corner
helpfulPercent:
so you don't really even have to know the item layout to survive. You just sort of jump in and play.

And that's really ♥♥♥♥ing weird.

After spending several hours in a few Overwatch beta weekends
votesHelpful: I've come to appreciate the required teamplay aspect that game brings to the table. This game is almost exactly the opposite. What can I say
votesTotal: it's the ultimate selfish team shooter. But it's fun.\n\nThere's nothing like knowing the power weapon spawn points and trying to capitalize on them and just destroying other players with the chainsaw. It's so fun and visceral. Actually
votesFunny: the MP chainsaw is my favorite powerup in any game

This isn't the MP I wanted and dreamed of all of these years since DOOM 3. It's still very fun. Just don't expect the successor to Quake Live.

More updates later? I don't know."

reviewText:
I haven't been hyped for a game's release since Resident Evil 2. When it comes to DOOM(4), I actually felt a little pre-release hype, simply because I love DOOM 1&2 (with Brutal DOOM or Project Brutality), and DOOM 3.

Now that DOOM out, and I've had a chance to play it, it's everything I could have wanted from a single player experience, in this genre. ( I haven't played the MP yet, and don't really care to. It's not what interest me about DOOM).

The game run smooth, looks great, excellent enemy AI, tight controls, and so on...

But rather than just repeat the strong points of the game, that many other reviewers have done so well. I want to make a point about why YOU should support this game.

We're see a trend in the gaming industry right now, where shooters are focusing on multiplayer, while throwing in a short, and often times, lacking campaign. While some games are releasing as multi-player only.  DOOM, on the other hand,  has not taken this approach. It's campaign is a full product that could stand on it's own, purchase wise.

Many of these companies are also releasing games that are lacking in content, in order to milk more money out of the consumer. DOOM gives us, the customer, the snap map tool, with can offer endless amounts of user created content. So your experience with the game does not end with the completion of the campaign.  (As a PC player I really wish they released a modding toolkit, but next to that, the snapmap feature, is the next best thing).

In short, this is the time to show the industry that it is still profitable to make a shooter with a full/complete single player experience. And that when you give the community a way of making their own content, rather than milking them for expensive map packs, the community will reward you with a high amount of products sold.

You're not going to see EA or Activision give this type of feature to their customers. Support the companies that try to give more.

reviewText:
Analazing the playstyle:
Well it's a 1st Person Shooter, but there is more to it the combat is hectic (Like the old DOOM games) and amazingly swift. You'll be moving all the time and quick movement is needed in the higher difficulty, that being said there are oppertunities to snipe a couple of enemies from safe spots before you step out in the open. The old DOOM secrets have also re-appeared so searching the map extends the playstyle. The upgrade system for weapons, and the Suit is not super innovative but it gets the job done nicely and the Upgrade Drones you can find in the level can give you extra right click functions for your weapons.

Graphics:
The engine this game runs on is perfect for the combat in this game. I've seen no tears what so ever and no Framerate stutter of any kind and you'll be moving and looking around during combat a lot since these enemies flock and swarm like an infestation.

Audio:
Great ambiance sound, perfectly synced weapons and great monster growl all you'll ever need when battling the forces of Hell on the Red Planet.

Final Thoughts:
DOOM is near and dear to me it's one of, if not THE first game I've ever played on PC back when the best PC's around where 486's and Bethesda & ID did a great job bringing it back for a restart of the franchise. If you're a 1st person shooter fanatic and like the atmosphere of a dark, gritty, monster infested planet then you should certainly wanna try this game. Wether it's worth the $60 I'll leave for everyone to decide for themselves but no matter if you buy it now or during a sale... you'll be glad you played it none the less!

reviewText:
Not finised yet but I've sunk a good 9 hours into the single player and its fantastic.

Its exactly what a reboot of a old game should be, takes all the content of the origial game and updates it and the gameplay to make sense within a modern video game without slavishly copying something else or losing the spirit of the original game. This feels like Doom on fast forward. Total choas yet you know exactly what you are trying to do at any point or you are dead.

This game is fast, you cannot stand still, or snipe from cover, the game forces you to keep moving, adapt as new monsters they enter the fight, balance when and how you use your pickups and which ammo you save and use. Even the custom kills which I thought would be annoying feed into the gameplay, you have to balance the risk and reward of letting something live longer and possibly recover to boost your health, armour and ammo. You are locked into set areas for each fight which usually I dont like but in this game the areas are so well sculped for combat and the premise for it in the story is actually sound too.

The music, particually in hell is perfect. There is some kind of story going on too though thats not really the point. Upgrades, unlocks, secrets, and apparently multiplayer though I'm happy to pay for just the single player in this game its so good.

reviewText:
I was worried about the quality of Doom when I saw the first reveal, the new cyberdemon looked way too cartoonish for my liking. I was worried about the quality of Doom when I saw one of the earlier trailers, all the environments were yellow and gray, and the monsters were gray and brown. I was worried about the quality of Doom when after the beta, everyone was arguing like crazy on what the quality was going to be from a cut down multiplayer mode designed by a different studio entirely.

I was not worried about the quality of Doom once I actually played it.

The new Doom reboot/update/continuation reaches a good balance of action, violence, speed, level design, and story in my opinion. The action is fast, the gore is great, and it keeps the story aspects on the backburner for the most part. Playing the game on Ultra-Violence really does provide a fun challenge, with many enemies posing a real threat. The glory kills are optional, but provide extra bits of ammo and health which is very helpful on the harder difficulties. There are many unlockable abilities and upgrades to either make glory killing faster and more helpful, or do other handy things. The weapons are fun and sound good, though maybe the plasma gun could use a better sound when firing. It nods to the originals plenty and there are many rewards from exploring the surprisingly open ended levels. The music does a good job of hilighting the action a lot of the time, with metal/industrial scores for Mars bases, and more orchestral-y stuff for hell.

The multiplayer is mainly what you'd expect. Halo + Unreal Torunament + extra gore. It is better than the beta now that there are much more modes, much more weapons, and better balanced gameplay. If a kind of watered down Halo/Unreal Tournament is good with you, you'll have a fun time.

Snapmap is a cool idea that harkens back to classics like TimeSplitters. It can be pretty restrictive, (no outside Mars areas, no Hell tilesets, can't spawn Cyberdemons) but some of the levels I've played created by other players showed great promise. Hopefully more great things show up by players and maybe we'll get more content hopefully for free if not in DLC.

Overall, the game is good. Maybe it won't be a new Icon of Sin like 1 & 2 was, but even Doom 3 holds a special place in my heart as one of my many favorite games, so the liberties that this game took will most likely solidify this new iteration as another one of my favorites. It's challenging, it's quick, the new take on the UAC is interesting, and it has lots of other goodies like snapmap and multiplayer to keep you entertained when you take a break from the single player.

It's Doom. Rip and Tear.

reviewText: Bethesda is no stranger to rehabilitating id Software games that have fallen by the wayside. After it passed the Wolfenstein IP over to Machinegames and released Wolfenstein: The New Order back in 2014, then The Old Blood in 2015, they instilled in me the confidence that they knew what they were  doing when it came to the 'modern retro shooter'. In that span of time, DOOM was announced and I kept my hopes high. Boy, did they deliver. DOOM is an amazing shooter with just enough old and new to hit all the right notes. Fun, fast, visceral... it's nothing short of glorious. I can't recommend the game enough.

reviewText:
I was a bit hesitant about getting DOOM along with some friends of mine. After taking the plunge and playing a good chunk of the singleplayer and multiplayer, I can say with confidence that this is worth playing. The singleplayer is pretty refreshing and pits you in the mute boots of good ol' RIP AND TEAR doomguy, rather than the more story driven horror shtick that Doom 3 had. Right off the bat you're in killing demons, and it stays pretty true to the original franchise. The levels are large and somewhat open, with keycard progression, secret areas, collectibles, and item pickups lying around to encourage exploration. Combat itsself is very fun and fast, if you enjoy old arena shooters you'll feel right at home playing DOOM. Staying mobile is important, and you'll have to use the open verticality of the maps if you don't want to find yourself dying. The upgrades for weapons and armor add some progression and also encourages looking for secret areas to gain upgrade points. All of the weapons are very satisfying to use, and the weapon mods add useful additions such as a grenade launcher for the shotgun, airburst for the rocket launcher, or 'siege mode' for the railgun.

Now for glory kills. Glory kills, despite my initial worries, actually feel very natural to use and are not too overbearing. They give health and are primarily used to replenish or stay alive in the thick of it. The chainsaw holds up to 5 units of fuel, and is capable of basically instagibbing demons. The larger demons cost more fuel, ranging from 3-5 and makes it very impractical to use this weapon more than once per fight, but at times thats all you need to refill your ammo. Most of my kills are made with the guns anyway, with glory kills being thrown in on occasion to get a small bit of health if I start to run low. You can also speed up the glory kill animation later in the game so it doesn't pull you from the action for as long.

As for the multiplayer, it feels a bit different from the singleplayer but is still pretty fun. It's taken on the usual trend in games lately of having loadout and cosmetic customization. Glory kills are still around in the multiplayer but they lock you into an animation that people can and most likely will kill you in, making them impractical to use other than as a finisher in a 1v1. There's a few different weapons in the multiplayer that so far are great to use, though I haven't quite used all of them yet.

Finally there's snapmap. I feel the best way to describe it is as the child of Halo's gamemode customization and forge with Timesplitters: Future Perfect's map maker. It's streamlined and easy to use, and provides numerous different tools ranging from decorating rooms, atmospheric filters, simple to complex logical tools, spawning weapons and even AI. Maps are made by snapping hallways or rooms together, and there's a lot of variety between the available pieces. Some of the map's i've played in snapmap range from basic team deathmatch to survival maps to tower defense, and even a map mimicing harvest moon. The only thing I feel snapmap is lacking is a bit of variety in the environment of the pieces, with almost all of them being that of an underground complex. You also earn 'snappoints' when making or playing snapmaps that you can use to buy cosmetic armor, weapon skins, or emotes for when you play snapmaps. Overall, snapmaps is probably my favorite part of the game and provides people with a lot of freedom in what they can make.

As a whole, I'd say DOOM is definitely worth picking up. I'd give it an 8/10, or maybe even a 9/10. I'll decide on that once I put a little more time into the game.

reviewText:
When I was a wee lad Doom was released, and completely changed what little had consisted of my video gaming world.   Doom has stuck with me for years.  Of all the NES, Genesis, SNES, N64 games, most PC games I had played as a kid, Doom was the only consistent game in my life.  With a strong community, nearly infinite modded maps to choose from, the photo realistic graphics, what I would consider flawless game play, every thing was perfect.  Up until this day, I consider Doom a perfect game.

I was excited about Doom 3.  I was let down by Doom 3.  I suppose it was a good game in it's own right, but it had taken most elements I had considered most fun about Doom out of the game.  It took a very serious approach, adding horror elements, story line and a flashlight.  Doom wasn't about carrying around a flashlight, it was about slaughtering demons to rockin' metal tunes, exploring large maps, collecting secrets, power ups, weapons and the like.

So with low expectations upon Doom 4's release, imagine my surprise when nearly every thing I loved about my favorite video game has been revived in the latest remake.  The game is fast, it looks amazing, and most importantly it's incredibly fun to play.  There were moments in the game where I was desparate for more in game fighting, that is how fun it was to me.  The strangely designed maps, copious amounts of slaughter, clever and rewarding secrets are all back.  There is very little story line, you just wake up and fight your way through the forces of Hell, as ID had originally intended.

Doom 4, you in my eyes are as close to perfection as a modern game could hope to achieve.  I salute you folks at ID for standing true to what I believe every Doom fanatic has been yearning for years to happen.  10/10

P.S. I never really got into multiplayer on Doom, either original or this version.  I've heard it's weak, I intend on trying it, but my review is solely on single player.

reviewText:
Read Completely, This is a Thumb's up ONLY for SinglePlayer, the Multiplatyer leaves alot to be desired, and I cannot say that it leaves anything positive for the game as a whole.

I am giving a thumbs-up with this review only for the Single Player campaign.  I'm really liking it and it seems to go back to the run and gun roots of the original doom games.  The levels look beautiful, the game play feels decent, and there's tons of gore to go around. I've been playing FPS since WolfenStein 3D came out, and I have spent of time playing Doom and Quake. Alot of people didn't like Doom 3, but personally I enjoyed it, yes it was different, but it was still fun none the less.

Now for the Bad news. The multiplayer leaves alot to be desired. It still feels just as bad as the Beta's did. Between load outs and glory kills I might as well go play COD.  It feels nothing like old arena shooters, it doesn't feel like quake, it doesn't feel like Unreal, it doesn't even feel like Doom 3 's deathmatch.  The one major point in the multiplayer I will applaud is the customization. But that's about it.

If I can leave more than 1 review I will split these, since I honestly wish I could give just the multiplayer a big fat thumbs down.  I will come back and polish up this review after I play some more.

reviewText:
Just DOOM...

I am giving the singleplayer mode 10 / 10. There is barely any story, later you will just notice a few audio tracks filling the search for ammunition after combat. The action in this game is extremely intense and challenging. Especially on Nightmare difficulty. It combines old-style shooter with refreshing new concepts in a harmonic way. I recommend it to everyone, who loves action games.

On the other side - as per usual - the multiplayer didn't get as much love as the singleplayer. I rate it 4 / 10 - It is slightly below the current average PC multiplayer games, even those free to play games can offer more if you don't like spending your hard-earned money.

My overall rating is 8,5 / 10 - Since it is DOOM, it is primary designed for singleplayer pumping action - and it brings the hell on your hard drive in a way, that you will remember for years!

reviewText:
Doom 3 was a good game. It was just really friggin' dark and a crappy Doom game. What I mean by that is the original Doom is very rarely about not being able to see, and jump scares. Rather, it's about intense action, strafing wildly, wielding heaps of cool weapons, and not taking it too seriously while having fun. Doom 3 has some of these elements, but tries much too hard to be mature and gritty in the wrong ways.

This 2016 version of Doom is Doom done right. It's a reboot that I expected to be garbage, but ended up having a lot of fun with. Each weapon has a job, each enemy is dealt with a different way, fast melee finishers which I didn't think I'd like surprised me and added a fun new element to the game, and although it feels weird at first, the further I got into the game, the more this felt like the original Doom games. It's a fun reimagining of the original with a story that you can pay as much or as little attention to as you like, with delays for exposition being very rare. The enemies are very detailed and redesigned, but some of them, such as the cacodemon, revenant, pinky, etc., while looking so new, also have that nostalgic look to them as well when you take in their overall shape, purpose, and aesthetic.

However, it's not just Doom with a shiny new coat of paint and melee finishers. Almost every weapon has upgrades, as does your Doom Marine suit. You are awarded upgrade points for finding various collectibles, killing large numbers of enemies, and completing challenges (such as kill X number of imps from behind in melee, etc.) on each level. Completing these challenges, finding the secrets, and upgrading your guns and suit are practically a mini-game in and of themselves, because I spent a rather large number of hours combing through levels looking for goodies. It's definitely worth it, though, because having better guns and such make clearing later areas much easier and give you more options.

That said, if you aren't the kind of gamer who has a lot of spare time, you may not want to spend a terribly large amount of time looking for the secrets. Although there's a really rewarding feeling about finding some of the tougher secrets on your own, Youtubing to find secrets you're missing isn't a bad idea if you really do need to cut back on how much time you're spending playing, and videos of that are already available from several users on the aforementioned site.

If you like games you can get all the achievements in, this one's doable but not super easy. I have 100% achievements now, and most of them are for finding all the secrets and upgrading everything. I got the competitive multiplayer achievements in under an hour easily, despite me being terrible at it, and the Snap Map achievements can be obtained within an hour or two depending on how much attention you pay to Snap Map's tutorials and playing legitimate maps to entertain or simply trying to finish maps fast to get achievements.

The competitive multiplayer seemed alright, but I'm hardly the person to ask. It's just not really my jam. The mode I played was a lot like Transformers War for Cybertron's mode where you try to hold command points,except I could turn into a jet on a whim whenever I felt like it in Transformers, so for me, Transformers all the way. ;)

Snap Map is surprisingly robust. Basically, you have an overhead view of an x-ray" of a room

reviewText:
Welcome to DOOM, a lightning-fast virtual reality adventure where you are the toughest space trooper ever to suck vacuum.

When I first read those words many years ago, I knew this game was going to be something different. That's the intro to the original Doom manual circa 1993. And over two decades since those words were first printed, the legacy is still going strong.

DOOM (2016) is everything that I expect from a Doom game. Big guns, much bigger demons, and one lone tough-as-nails Marine using the first to obliterate the second. Rest assured that this is an epic and action-packed assault through Mars, and hell, and back to Mars, and back to hell. (Repeated many times over a 15 hour campaign, twice as long as most FPS these days.) DOOM is a fantastic return to a time when games were about fun gameplay, story was something you had to dig for (instead of being spoon fed to you), bosses were challenging, and protagonists knew when to shut the hell up instead of yapping through the whole campaign.

While most shooters today encourage you to move cautiously, keep a finger on the reload key, and kill maybe a dozen or so enemies in a mission, DOOM takes things a different route. In DOOM, speed and aggression is the only way to get things done. If you back down from a fight, if you try to camp your enemies, if you try to hide in cover, you will lose. Over and over again. Play offensively, and always be on the move. This applies equally to campaign and multiplayer.

In DOOM, you will be moving 99% of the time. To help keep you from having to stop, DOOM does away with sprint-keys and weapon reloading. Instead, your weapons never need to be reloaded. So long as you have ammo in your inventory, you can fire your weapons. Rather than a sprint-key, your default speed is running and you can hit a key if you (for some reason) wish to walk. Movement overall is much less restrictive than in most shooters. By jumping towards any ledge, you can grapple on and quickly pull yourself up. You can also rapidly climb railings and vault over low obstacles. These mechanics are very fluent and far more versatile than they seem on the surface. While some games have mechanics like this that feel gimmicky, in DOOM they feel natural and work exceptionally well. In addition to this, fairly early in the campaign you will acquire a set of boots that let you double-jump (double-jumping is standard in the multiplayer). This combined with the ledge-climbing enables you to reach new heights.

But you aren't the only creature that can traverse the world with ease, nearly all of the thousands (literally thousands) of demons you will fight are just as agile as you. They can, and will, chase you all throughout the combat zone with surprising intelligence. Killing these demons is frantic, hellish, and very satisfying. The ability to melee weakened enemies for a quick finishing move (called glory kill") is a welcome feature in DOOM. These glory kills might sound clunky and repetitive
date: but they are neither. Glory kills happen very quickly (so as not to slow down the action)
recommended: and they have many variations. They are even contextual
hoursPlayed: so that what part of the enemy you are looking at when you hit the melee key will determine which glory kill you preform. These are not quicktime events and do not detract from the speed of the game. To aid in your assault
voteText: you will find numerous powerups that give you temporary abilities such as haste (makes you even faster)

Some of these upgrades take the form of runes which require you to beat a brief combat arena under specific instructions. (Example: Kill every enemy with only the super shotgun in 12 seconds.) You can equip up to three runes at a time and swap them out as you wish. Finding "field drones" throughout the game will unlock weapon mods which can be individually upgraded at your discretion. Once unlocked

reviewText:
As someone who's grown up on the old school ID games, I can actually say that this game brought back alot of nostalgia from the older days of gaming. It's story is practically non-existant and focuses more on the crazy, breakneck pace of the shooting. People complaining about a lack of story in an ID game should be directed towards the company's past projects and see that ID games have never been about the story, it's about blowing the CRAP out of some aliens/demons and leaving everything behind you in smoke.
I've completed the game, and while I did say that the story isn't important, I did find myself invested enough to feel kinda blueballed by it. The writing is pretty damn good! Hopefully they come out with a (Hopefully Free/Almost Free) second part!

reviewText:
Very good.

I grew up playing wolfenstein, doom, all the quake games, unreal, unreal tournament, half lifes, tf2 etc so I know a little about the evolution and specifics of those old games that created the fps games we have these days.

Doom 4 is a proper sequel when discussing single player. The single player is awesome, the graphics are good and so on. The story is decent with great locations. All the enemies are from the classic doom games and more.
This is all I will say about single player, my beef is with the multiplayer.

What I don't like is the multiplayer, they really took a massive step back. Quake 2 had single player coop and most of those other games i mentioned in the beginning have capture the flag. Capture the flag has to be included in this game along side the other basics like death match and team deathmatch but it's not.
There is an option to play CTF but only 2v2 (Wtf)

I also find the multiplayer generally crappy, instead of classes they should have went the classic way of picking up weapons and power ups that are spread out through the map because this removes choke points and makes the battles more interesting.  Classes single handedly ruin the experience of the classic multiplayer games.

Another terrible idea was not including server browser, at times you are left with waiting a long time  finding players" until it times out.

Server browser is a must for a game like doom
date:
a way to customize matches or maps but bethesda again skipped out on the multiplayer and took the easy way.

They could have made this game glorious if they fully made this the way classic FPS games where designed.

So in essence
recommended: my recommendation is for you to get this game for a discounted price
hoursPlayed: currently almost everyone hates the multiplayer for different reasons. My biggest issue is that they felt lazy and took a massive step back in designing the multiplayer aspect.\n\nI like the ability to make maps
voteText: but again this is worthless with a proper way to play multiplayer.\n\nAll in all this game is worth it

reviewText: This game is great. It performs great at 4k with everything maxed out on a  980TI as it never dips below ~45 fps even at the most intense moments with the majority of the game running at or above 60FPS. Its so fast paced that even though theres some repitition the most boring part is when they take breaks to tell the story and when you get lost, although that only happened to me like twice. Even though people some reviewers have an issue with the multiplayer I still think that it is fresh and is much better than what call of duty is offering. I haven't bought a COD game since Ghosts burned me and everyone else so badly.\n\n9.5/10 Would buy again.

reviewText:
I didn't have any doubt id would do this title justice. A stellar FPS and old school fun while feeling cutting edge still. The gameplay for singleplayer is rock solid and that is all that counts.

Amazing graphics aside, if you choose to endure the Nightmare difficulty experience; you are in for a seriously intense ride. It is absoutely worth it.

As a side note, Mick Gordon (who also did Wolfenstein) adds a refreshing and inspired metal soundtrack with electronic/glitch aesthetics and it works seemlessly.

reviewText: I have to admit, after the poor Beta and some lack lustre preview videos i was sceptical on this and thought i might get it when on sale.  However, after seeing the positive comments and good reviews, i thought i would cave in and get it at full price.  And i have to say I dont regret it in the slightest.  If you are a true doom fan, you should love this.  Its probably the fastest shooter i have ever played, certainly in the modern era.  The guns are punchy, the combat excellent, and the graphics are superb.  On top of all that the game is very well designed.  It was a smart person who said level design is everything".  And doom is basically a tribute to its ancestors heritage.   Not quite as groundbreaking as its predecessor

reviewText:
I remember I ran a BBS back in the late 80's, early 90's.  I was a PC enthusiast and always was jealous that consoles had such really cool games -while the PC had some good ones, most were adventure style games like King's Quest or Ultima - great games of the day, but the PC was lacking high end action ga,es.   My BBS was the only local Apogee distribution site, and I remember when my modem spent hours downloading a game called Commander Keen at 2am from the distribution hub.   I woke up as the modem initiated its handshaking sequence.  And thought, what a stupid name for a game.

Then I played it.   Things changed on the PC from that day forward.   Thanks to the developers at id Software, the PC was no longer relegated to backwater gaming.  The consoles had direct competition - and the PC could be on the same footing.   Then Wolfenstein 3D came.  While not the first FPS game - it certainly took PC gaming to new heights.  Then came Doom - a game that forced many to upgrade from 286 or 386 to 486 machines - and that started the trend of PC Gaming driving new computer sales.   It was that important of  a game.  Many forayed into Networking, or Modding - a game that drove people to the IT industry.   Myself included.

Ok, sorry for the mind numbing nostalgia - but I'm sure a lot of people who grew up in that golden age of PC gaming get the same feeling playing the latest Carmack and company installment.  A feeling most didn't get with Doom 3.   But here is a game with an engine a cut above what's out there (as we should expect from id), and displaying what made early FPS so popular in the first place --- fast pace action, twitch reflexes, not a lot of thought above wow

reviewText:
Finally a Doom game capable of being both modern and true to form. This game brought back what was sorely lacking in Doom 3: Exploration, fast pace and butchering demons by the dozen. Gone are the cheap jumpscares that Doom 3 brought us at every corner, you're not some ♥♥♥♥♥ marine shooting at spiders or ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ his pants in front of a Cyberdemon, you're the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Doom Marine and you kick major ♥♥♥ all the way.

Remember when someone at ID said the point was to feel like Bruce Lee roaming around on a skateboard with a shotgun? The pacing reflects exactly that, there's a sort of rythm to the game: Shoot, run in, Glory Kill their asses then do the same with the other fools snarling and throwing fireballs at you. This new Doom is all about movement, to stay still is to get killed. The Marine can easily climb ledges and jump around, especially once you get the Thrust Boots and the well-designed levels let you moce easily during arena combat. All in all, combat in this game is Brutal Doom in the ID Tech engine, very satisfying. The Glory Kills are quick enough to not break the pace and they are indeed very brutal and gory. So satisfying.

One of my biggest disappointment with the closed alpha was the impossibility of carrying all the weapons, the loadout system felt unnecessary since just about everybody spammed rockets during the game and it just feels like it was implemented to be more modern" ... but in the single-player campaing? You can carry all you find and there's a great slection including classic weapons from the earlier Doom games as well as some newcomers

reviewText: So much yes to every aspect of this game. It is incredible. It's basically a super, mega sexy HD remake of the OG and in no way at all is that a bad thing. I got all nostalgic playing this game. The demons, powerups, colour coded key card, teleports and no reloading. All the great things from the original game. This has done what so many games have tried to do. It's taken the old FPS formula and made it modern and it is glorious. This game is just so much fun. It's exactly what the gaming industry needs right now. Glorious, fun, over the top action. I'd recommend you all get it immediately.

reviewText:
Alright. Doom.This is a spoiler-free, rather detailed DOOM review that should give you a basic idea of what this game offers.

Let's start right at the beginning.
My beginning is the DOOM Beta. We've all seen it.
Not being developed by id Software themselves, it was bound to be different than what we expected.
A popularized Doom-Quake. A modern day shooter, if you will.
Skins. Taunts. A pre-order-only multiplayer equipment pack.
A lot of people got worried: Was DOOM going to be modernized to please the average crowd instead of the old fans?
Was it going to lose everything that makes DOOM, well, DOOM?
No. No, it didn't. Not in the slightest.

In DOOM you control a very p!ssed-off guy who doesn't give two sh!ts about anything.
As him, you slaughter thousands of demons in the most satisfying ways possible, faster and with more flow than ever before.
Your arsenal consists of upgradeable, moddable badass weaponry, all useful in their own ways. A new system of Glory Kills" was introduced - gore-filled finishing moves that let you preserve ammunition
date: get rewards depending on your enabled in-game perks and get some sweet fist-to-face combat going (You can also turn them off if you find to dislike them; Perks are received by completing side-challenges
recommended: you don't have to use them).\nThe level design is a very well executed mix of arena-like battling grounds and every level has a great vertical aspect. In the heat of the battle you'll be on the move constantly - especially on higher difficulties where a single hit means death. That's where DOOM delivers adrenaline in a way no other current game can. Once everything has settled down a bit
hoursPlayed: you can head out and explore the secrets each level hides from you. Whether you do it for the extra upgrade points for your weapon- or suit-improvements
voteText:
to stock up on armor and health or because you like tons of retro-content - exploring is fun and very rewarding.

With that neat package of extremely blood-thirsty gameplay come astonishing graphics and a surprisingly stable framerate on the suggested hardware.

Sadly
helpfulPercent: no game is without any flaws
votesHelpful: and DOOM is definitely not an exception in that regard.\nA very common and very annoying issue are the crashes.\nDOOM crashes an awful lot on my (quite powerful) system
votesTotal:
seemingly increasing amounts over time.
Crashes happen when:
I start or finish a side-challenge
I load into new level parts
I load into the campaign levelsAnother thing are VERY laggy intros. The initial DOOM Nvidia driver fixed those for me
votesFunny: however I still disabled them by writing "+com_skipIntroVideo 1" into the DOOM launch options on Steam.\n\nThat's all
commentsCount: folks!DOOM is what we wanted
column16: DOOM is what we got.\nThis game plays great and has a fun factor way above the dose your doctor prescribed you.\nOld DOOM fans will find a brutal
column17: beautiful run-and-gun-shooty-shoot-game in this one
column18:
and if you want that good old hard experience - DOOM on Nightmare difficulty and above is definitely for you. You can unlock Nightmare difficulty without having finished the game by typing "+menu_advanced_AllowAllSettings 1" in the launch options.
(Don't get mad if it doesn't work - they might have patched it out by now.)

If this review gave you a peek into what DOOM is
column19: give it a like!\nIf you think it sucked
column20: give it a dislike.\nIf you're going to play DOOM
column21: I wish you lots of fun!"

reviewText:
Play time: 20 hours: Single player campaign: +- 19 hours.
Should take far less time if you just run and don't take in the views. :)

So I just completed Doom's single player campaign after a 19 hour trip through hell that was like heaven. I played doom as a very young kid, then I played Doom 2 and I also loved playing the custom maps! Unlike most people I really enjoyed Doom 3 as well. Although it wasn't like Doom 1 or 2, it experimented with so much and geniunely frightened me with it's well designed monsters and frightening atmosphere! It also had DoomEd
and I spent countless hours making maps of my own. Now, on to Doom 4.

Holy mother of barons, what a game! The format is very simple, get into a simple area, and move! Run, use pickups, get health, destroy those demons, tear them apart, run, get powerups, eviscerate more demons, repeat! It seems like a repetitive formula but that is what Doom has always been! Running and gunning! And it was so much fun! Finally, finally,
they even brought back the Baron of Hell, my favorite demon from Doom! Man guys, the demons aren't lumping, drooling muscleheads like in Doom 3 either! They run, dodge climb up everything and come after you to rip you to shreds! Such an improvement over Doom 3! There was this one stage where I had little health left and I frantically tried to get away from a hellknight and jumped down a path and as I looked back in fear I saw him jump after me in all his glory,
trapping me. That's when I knew, well done Doom AI team, bravo.

The only disappointment perhaps was it's  lack of plot atmoshphere. Don't get me wrong, with Doom I'm not expecting much but I do feel that the voice recordings and videos of the PDA system in Doom 3 created a brilliant atmosphere. I feel they could have introduced all the cool sciency parts of the first UAC complex in a different way. The walls and walls of text the pda's provide you do feel kind of empty. I also feel the characters are extremely forgettable. Dr Betruger from Doom 3 genuinely frightened me in a 'This guy is satanic as hell'-way.

If the long single player campaign with secrets and battles abound isn't enough to satisfy you there's still the multiplayer and snapmaps! Especially the snapmaps, with it you can create your own multiplayer or single player missions, I can't wait!

9/10

TLDR version

An awesome old school shooter in 2016. That's NOT an easy task to pull off, well done DOOM team!

reviewText:
Despite being bored with the MP Beta before release, the SP campaign for this game is fantastic.  After 12 years, this game was worth the wait.  Gone are the slow-moving, dark shadows of Doom 3: Where that game was a horror game with action elements, this is the complete opposite - This take on Doom is brutal, bloody, brightly-colored, and otherwise a chaotic gore-fest deluxe.

The Good:
1.  Awesome graphics - blood runs out of the walls, clouds of smoke rise from destructed building on the horizon, great glass and DOF effects, etc.
2.  Action, action, action, and more action - the game never stops moving.
3.  Glory Kills to finish off opponents in completely blood-drenched fashion
4.  All the classic Doom weapns make an appearance, are fully upgradable, and there are even a couple new ones
5.  The Demons have all been revamped, and are more aggressive and deadly.   Imps now climb walls and hurl fireballs at you from all sort of angles.  Hell Knights will jump up to ledges to pursue you, etc.  And there is no shortage of any of them.
6.  Secrets galore and areas to explore
7.  Minor RPG upgrading elements on gameplay and the marine's suit
8.  Double jumps and climbing allows for more expanded environments and movement
9.  Demons react when being damaged - they will stumble or step backward from machine gun fire, etc instead of just charging forward like a robot
10.  Smooth as silk on Ultra settings (GTX 980, i5 OC to 4.3 GHZ).

The Bad:
1.  Checkpoints....need I say more?
2.  The maps are somtimes confusing and it's difficult to figure out where you are at a lot of the time
3.  The music, while fitting to the game, is sometimes a little repetitive
4.  One type of Demon is missing from the game, but was replaced with another similar one - diehards might not like this.

The Ugly:
1.  For those who suffer from motion sickness, repeated Glory Kills will catch up to you.

In the same ways that the original Doom had minor aspects of Wolfentstein in it, this version reminds me of the more recent Wolfenstein games and has minor similarities to those also.

I couldn't put it down, I never lost interest, and it never got boring.

All in all, it's a killer game.
666/10
A+

reviewText:
Read Completely, This is a Thumb's up ONLY for SinglePlayer, the Multiplatyer leaves alot to be desired, and I cannot say that it leaves anything positive for the game as a whole.

I am giving a thumbs-up with this review only for the Single Player campaign.  I'm really liking it and it seems to go back to the run and gun roots of the original doom games.  The levels look beautiful, the game play feels decent, and there's tons of gore to go around. I've been playing FPS since WolfenStein 3D came out, and I have spent of time playing Doom and Quake. Alot of people didn't like Doom 3, but personally I enjoyed it, yes it was different, but it was still fun none the less.

Now for the Bad news. The multiplayer leaves alot to be desired. It still feels just as bad as the Beta's did. Between load outs and glory kills I might as well go play COD.  It feels nothing like old arena shooters, it doesn't feel like quake, it doesn't feel like Unreal, it doesn't even feel like Doom 3 's deathmatch.  The one major point in the multiplayer I will applaud is the customization. But that's about it.

If I can leave more than 1 review I will split these, since I honestly wish I could give just the multiplayer a big fat thumbs down.  I will come back and polish up this review after I play some more.

reviewText:
NOTE: This review is a work in progress.



I want to put my first impressions out there so I can alleviate some of the fears I know a lot of the fans have about this game after reading the press releases, watching the early access gameplay videos, and maybe even trying out the Beta.  I've waited a long time for this game, and have high expectations.  So far it's been pretty damn fun and definitely worth a buy right now if you are a long-time fan of shooters and/or Doom.  Fans expecting an amazing multiplayer experience may want to wait for a sale though.  Personally, I bought this game for the single player anyway so I'm a happy camper.

My initial impressions of the single player campaign are very good.  All the key elements are there: fast-paced gameplay, cool and upgradeable weapons, gorgeous graphics, lots of secrets and hidden passages to explore on each level.  The story is minimal, the combat is extremely fun and satisfying, and there lots of easter eggs for the long time fans to discover.  The guns are awesome and killing demons with them has to be on of the most viscerally satisfying experiences I've ever had.  The jury is still out on the new execution system, so far it's been okay but I could definitely have just as much fun without it.  It makes the game easier and I think the devs wanted the game to appeal to a broad audience, not just the old-school PC gamers.

My impression of the multiplayer... is that the devs lost sight of the core elements that made Doom multiplayer enjoyable.  I think the biggest gripe for me are the loadouts."  Basically you have to choose between a designated set of weapons before each match.  This made me feel restricted and overall like the devs didn't intend to make this multiplayer fun for the fans of arena-shooters.  They intended to make it more like other modern shooters
hoursPlayed: etc.  and possibly to cater to console gamers.  I'm not too happy with this as a PC gamer
voteText: but I understand compromises have to be made when you're trying to sell a game on multiple platforms and appeal to a broader audience.\n\nOverall
helpfulPercent: this game is well optimized and it satisfies my craving for a no nonsense
votesHelpful: fast-paced shooter.  I'm looking forward to even more fraggin' fun once I unlock Nightmare and Ultra-Nightmare mode!\n\nDemons beware

reviewText:
DOOM is a visceral, adrenaline pumping romp through Mars, Hell, and back. Although DOOM is a relatively simple game, it is this very simplicity that makes id's achievement so impressive. Everything had to be executed with surgical precision, and I'm happy to report that from a gameplay perspective, this is one of the finest first person shooters ever released. The weapons are satisfying to use, the combat is fast and frenetic, and it is all backed up by a masterful score from Mick Gordon. This is the DOOM legions of fans had been hoping for.

Visually, the game looks nice, though maybe not quite as impressive as Doom 3 looked when it first came out. It is certainly a very pretty game, however, and perhaps more importantly, it runs like a dream. Doom 3 was a game many people built new systems for. DOOM, on the other hand, will likely run smoothly on the system you already have. I have absolutely no complaints about the game's optimization.

The combat in DOOM is absolutely the highlight of the game. Hearing about the skate park" design philosophy behind the combat arenas prerelease
date: I was a little worried that this would make for tedious pacing where you might dread the next time the game decides to lock you in a room
recommended: but it's actually quite the opposite. I found myself anticipating the next "skate park
hoursPlayed:
which it turns out is a surprisingly apt moniker for DOOM's combat arenas. The speed and fluidity with which you move around these arenas almost has a Mirror's Edge-like quality to it. Add in the excellent soundtrack, and it's hard to imagine that anything could be more violently thrilling than these sections.

The maps are large, non-linear, and full of secrets. It is a return to FPS map design many had feared lost. One minor flaw is that due to the nature of a facility like the UAC, things can look a little repetitive, though this is somewhat mitigated by a brilliantly simple system that uses the color green to let you know where to go. They've struck the right balance of making this obvious enough to help, and subtle enough to not be distracting.

The story is absolutely a weak point. While you might say that Doom has never been about story, and I would agree with you, the game itself can’t seem to decide whether its story is important or not. For the most part, it only exists to move the action along, though there are moments of conceit where the exposition seems to take a bit too long and the game forgets that its story is merely a means to an end. There are a lot of concepts that seem interesting, especially if you take the time to read the data logs you find while playing the game, but everything leaves you feeling much like you would if you started watching a TV series halfway through a season. You can follow things, but you can’t shake the feeling that you’re missing something. It feels like the story used to be bigger, but in the interest of pacing, many things were cut. I think they could have stood to cut a bit more. All in all though, this detracts from the experience very little.

Glory kills were something many people were worried about, and caused much consternation in the gaming community. While it played well in trailers, many were skeptical that it could actually work from a gameplay perspective without ruining the pacing by taking you out of the action. In actuality though, glory kills have turned out to be a great addition to the series. When you do enough damage to an enemy, it enters a stagger state, from which it is susceptible to a glory kill, which grants you extra health, armor, and/or ammo, depending on the runes you have equipped. Far from interrupting the flow of combat, it actually greatly enhances it by adding a certain kind of rhythm to the violence. While I think the system was a huge risk, id has proven that an assassination-style melee-kill system in an FPS can work if done correctly. In my mind, they proved all the skeptics wrong.

In fact, between the glory kill system and the multiplayer beta, DOOM garnered a lot of skepticism during the period of its prerelease promotion. The multiplayer mode is bland and uninspired, and it was likely a mistake to make this the general public’s first hands-on experience with the game, as it ended up negatively coloring their perception of the package as a whole. However, DOOM defied expectations and offers one of the best first person shooter campaigns in years. This is a game very much worth playing.

reviewText:
I don't know where to start besides saying that I just love it. Calling it perfect would be absurd, but it's damn near close. The critiques I have are mostly too minor for me to really care about. Four things that stood out to me the most about the game are:

The Level Design

The levels are huge and full of secrets. They remind me very much of the original Doom levels in the sense that they can be full of twists and turns with little alcoves and corners hiding items that you need to sniff out. The verticality makes for a lot of interesting routes you can take. I love the fact that they included an automap and managed to make it completely readable and easy to use. I'm always tabbing in and out of it to look for secreat areas or places I might have overlooked, just like in the original games.

The maps are also very pretty. The Martian surface with the vast landscapes that you can look out over, seeing different parts of the UAC base that you eventually travel to almost strikes me as a callback to the intermission screen of Knee Deep in the Dead. My two favorite levels so far are probably Foundry and the Lazarus labs. Running around the gritty industrial facility with molten slag pouring out of the walls making everything glow bright orange. And later on, deep inside the Lazarus labs, you can see the extent of what the UAC have been up to with their experimenting and cult worship of Hell, which leads me to my next favorite bit.

The Story

Yeah Doom seems to actually have a halfway decent story so far. Well, I haven't finished the game yet so I still have to see what happens, but I love reading all of the tidbits you pick up along the way about the environments and the monsters. Each codex entry you find gives you some insight into the research and development behind the projects that UAC have been up to, as well as the indoctrination of their workers. Slowly brainwashing them from their low level positions until they eventually convince them that it's perfectly okay to kneel over and be ripped apart by a demon.

Another thing I like is that half the time the game simply lets you ignore things if you don't want to bother listening to what's going on. There are some forced cutscenes where you have to stop and look at a thing that's happening, but most of the time these only last about 5 seconds, with the exception of a few that may last quite a bit longer.

I want to keep this review mostly spoiler free, but the way they handled Doomguy is great. Reading about his backstory and seeing how ♥♥♥♥♥♥ he is with what the UAC is doing is a great way for them to let Doomguy speak without actually using his voice.

The Gameplay

The combat is just fun. You move very quickly, you jump around up onto ledges and over demons heads, smacking down on their chests and pulling their heads apart, blasting them with rocket launchers and slicing them in half with chainsaws. It's so fast, fluid, bloody and fun. Everytime I reach a room that I can tell is going to be a fight I get excited, I think to myself  hell yeah
date: let's do it " and then the monsters pour in and the music kicks in and you just start dancing around the room fragging one demon after another.\n\nWhen it's over with you get a breather to look around the level and stock up on health and ammo
recommended: wandering the corridors again for the next room that needs to be cleaned out
hoursPlayed: or trying to find a secret. The levels are very nonlinear at times and your path is your choice. Some people may not like the fact that rooms go into lockdown and you're forced to fight and kill everyone before you can leave
voteText: but for me there's never been a time where this has been disappointing or frustrating. You have plenty of weapons and can always fight your way out if you're resourceful enough.\n\nAnother aspect I like is the inclusion of upgrades for weapons and your character. As far as I can tell
helpfulPercent: these are completely optional except for the first time you come across a suit upgrade. I like these light customization elements
votesHelpful: they essentially bring new weapons into the game by letting you add on two mods to your guns that offer an alternative fire mode. In addition to this
votesTotal: you can upgrade your suit by allowing for more health
votesFunny: armor
commentsCount:
and ammo capacity.

Snapmap

For me
column16: Snapmap is a love-hate relationship. I love love LOVE the fact that id designed this and included it with their game. I've been making maps for as long as I can remember
column17: anything from a simple WYSIWYG editor to things like Hammer. I love being able to create a level and control the gameplay behind it. Nowadays
column18: most editors are quite complicated with a steep learning curve
column19: and even after you've bothered to learn them it still takes a LOT of time and effort to produce anything that looks and feels halfway decent. Snapmap basically takes care of this for you
column20: and lets you connect levels together with premade assets. Rooms are already made
column21: and you place props
column22: lights
column23: effects
column24: ambience
column25: monsters and pickups within them. You can manipulate logic to create events and other actions within the level. From what I've seen

You can't alter the lighting too much besides a couple of entities they give you as well as changing the atmosphere of the room

column35: Snapmap is a wonderful addition to the game. It will hopefully keep the community alive for a while longer.  Maybe we'll also get some true modding tools in the future so that the more talented people out there can put together some campaigns and other cool stuff. But in the meantime

I'm really glad they created this.

In summary

I feel like Doom really hit it's mark. It's a great blend of the classic run and gun

column38: appreciating the aesthetics of the sleak UAC base and the twisted depths of Hell.\n\nI absolutely recommend it to anyone who's a fan of Doom or just likes a good old fashioned shooter game."

reviewText:
Right off bat, if there were 1 word for me to describe this game it would be: EPIC!

People may have been skeptical about rehashing old games just to jump the hype train but Bethesda Software does nothing short of delivering a software masterpiece that captures all the glory of the old games and invent new innovative ways to approach FPS.  To my knowledge they really set a new bar for FPS game standards.

STORY/SETTING:

You didn't buy Doom for a story as deep as Bioshock Infinite or Uncharted.  No excessive characters, no complicated story plot, very simple and to the point.  The environment and setting is vastly unknown to you and part of the enjoyment is to see what happens next after series of completing events.

GAMEPLAY:

Every encounter involves RUNNING and SHOOTING.  You won't be taking cover, you won't be sniping, there is no subtlety here as those will almost immediately get you killed.  Every fight is an unrelenting battle against insurmountable odds ranging from waves of small imps to multiple towering hell knights.  There are a great variety of monsters ranging from numerous but weak to few but nearly immortal, slow precise ranged to insanely fast melee, all of which requiring unique strategies with the weapons available.  This makes all of the weapons useful to the very end of the game as well.  Plasma rifles can be modified to stun monsters (great for stopping rushing melee enemies in their tracks), Rocket launchers with homing capabilities for tough medium ranged monsters, and rail guns for tough but slow long ranged monsters.

There is a spec" system for upgrading weapons
hoursPlayed: perks
voteText: etc.  I didn't calculate it precisely but I am pretty sure it is possible to max out all attributes by the last level of the game if you find all secrets in every level.  Missions can be replayed to recollect any missed secrets and gain additional upgrade points.  The upgrade system does seem a bit complicated though.\n\nI was also impressed with the double jump and climbing up cliffs function in the game.  Platforming has always been somewhat cumbersome in FPS games but with this new system
helpfulPercent:
it definitely allows significantly more control and agility of the character when running from enemies.  This greater control makes FPS games not feel so handicapped when moving and jumping around allowing for new enjoyable challenges that require running around.

SOUND:

The Music is quite fitting with the overall mood of the game.  In the base areas
votesHelpful: there is always some upbeat techno music and most of the encounters have some heavy metal type music.  It definitely adds mood and character to the game itself.  Each weapon has awesome sounds and it really feels like they hold a tremendous amount of power behind them.  Explosions
votesTotal: bullets whizzing
votesFunny:
laser blasts are all satisfying to constantly hear without feeling annoyed or repetitive.  The whizzing noise of rockets shooting out of the assault rifle and sticking to the enemies before exploding was one really memorable sound effect that stuck to me.

GRAPHICS:

The graphics are decent and on par with the most advanced games out there now.  I always felt DOOM was a game where you would fight off a tremendous amount of monsters at the same time
commentsCount: so I was concerned that some graphics would have to be sacrificed in order to accomodate large amounts of enemies on screen at the same time (I felt this was a problem for doom 3).  Turns out my worries were unfounded.  I played this with dual 980ti in SLI and could consistently get 120 to 150 fps with maxed out settings on a 1080P monitor.  Even on the forums
column16: people reported that they could achieve decent performance with single 970s.  The animations are all smooth
column17: each classic doom monster was reworked and given a new look while preserving what made them what they were in the 80s.  They really seemed to hit a good balance in providing great animations
column18:
looks without excessive stress on decent video cards.

OVERALL:

DOOM 2016 is an awesome game!  It is very challenging
column19: it stays true to its origins and brings a lot of new innovation to the table as well.  It is also decently long!  Ultra Violence difficulty
column20: which is what I am playing at
column21: will probably take 18 hours so.  I think I will hit the higher difficulty next.  I haven't explored the map editor or multiplayer at all yet.  I highly recommend this game to anyone looking for an adrenaline rushed action FPS game.  Starting with Wolfenstein the new order
column22: I really think Bethesda has found their place and niche in the gaming world.  If you see their games
column23: rest assured it will be action packed and it won't disappoint."

reviewText:
What can be said about ID’s new Doom title other that it is one of the
best first person gaming experiences I have had in years. It focuses on
knowing exactly what it is and what it is supposed to do for the players.
Let’s get into why the games great and why you should give it a chance
if you enjoy First Person Shooters..

Doom’s gameplay mechanics are incredibly solid. The fast movement
speed took me a while to get used to, as I was used to more realistic
movement speeds of Battlefield, Red Orchestra, Rainbow Six etc. Once
however I had played for about an hour I started feeling right at home
with how agile my space marine/god was. You fly through the air shooting
demons off of walls and land on top of them smashing them into puddles
of blood and sinew. The weapons feel resounding and have an excellent
responsiveness to them. Combat is incredibly fast paced and rewarding.

The GloryKill system which presents the player with the opportunity to
brutally execute stunned enemies is a delight for players, and happily it
does not slow down the pace of the combat at all. Doom features an
excellent incentive to search maps for secrets that are the key to upgrading
your weapons and armor, as well as challenges to unlock runes to further
enhance your Space marine. ID outdid themselves with how good the
actual gameplay is. It’s so response and so exciting that it never got old.

The sound design and graphical fidelity of the game is presented very
well and shows a lot of quality and attention to detail. While the story
is just engaging enough to the point where you are “curious” it doesn't
hold your hand and make you a likeable character. No you are a ♥♥♥♥♥♥
off Space marine that has to fight the forces of hell by himself. Hes angry
he smashes things that most characters would coddle and yammer on
about. It made me laugh several times when he did something unexpected
but it all made sense in context of the amount of ♥♥♥♥ you have to put up
with.

This game is one of the best remakes/reboots of a franchise we have
ever seen. I highly encourage anyone who loves a good FPS to pick
this sucker up post haste. Its excellent and deserves to be played and
enjoyed. I got 16 hours out of my first run through on the 3rd to hardest
difficulty mode. I love the game and look forward to playing it again.

Absolute recommendation from me. 9/10.

reviewText:
To put it bluntly, DOOM is a good game.  It's worth a buy.

DOOM had a troubled development to say the least, with initial gameplay tid-bits making it look scatter-brained and life-less, with colorless imagery and vain attempts at showing off, but it turns out that the sum of its parts weren't all there in those promo's, and that the final product is actually, well, amazingly well done.

The weapons are meaty and satisfying, all the alternate fire modes serve their purpose and each offer a different kind of gameplay style for that particular weapon, the grenades are all very unique, the environmental traversal adds a new level of depth to Doom that wasn't present previously, and the executions are far from just the pointless cosmetics" that everyone is so quick to jump on them about.

Basically
date: every negatice preconcieved notion that you had about this game was wrong
hoursPlayed: and they managed to make an experience quite unlike any other on the market for FPS's for this era."

reviewText: I know it's a shame, but this is actually the first DOOM Game I've ever played, so here's a review from a guy who's completely new to this series. reviewText:
This is precisely what I expected from an updated Doom. An FPS with great graphics, cybernetic demons, badass guns and badass music to kill by. The story is simple, you are a slayer of demons killing demons on Mars who have come through a hellgate created by an evil corporation. This is classic Doom with all the keycard hunting and demonic iconography in tact. I am really looking forward to getting the official soundtrack and a campaign expansion.

The multiplayer on the other hand is boring. The player skins all look like Power Rangers and there is a Code Of Conduct that prevents smack talk. My advice would be to get some friends together and explore some of the interesting game modes in an environment that doesn't discourage smack. And lastly SnapMaps sounded great, but it was made for consoles so the interface sucks. But some of the community maps are cool.
5/5 (for the campaign)

reviewText:
--- Update ---

I've finished the SP campaign. Clocked in at about 12 hours in length.

I need some time to reflect because I feel like making some pretty bold claims about how this is the best FPS I've played in at least the last decade. No game has made my adrenaline pump this much in a while. Bravo id.

I want more. Please make more. Just like this. More.

Doesn't look like games media has their reviews out yet but I don't expect much from them since they are almost universally terrible at video games, especially PC-centric twitch shooters that require skill. Just trust me on this one. It's great. (edit: called it)

--- Original ---

The single player campaign is really, really great. It's fast, it's frantic, it's metal as hell. I love it. If you're looking for a straightforward action packed twitch shooter, look no further.

I had 0 expectations and didn't even plan to buy this game, but damn, this has been a huge surprise. They dropped the ball with marketing. Raw gameplay footage sells itself (of a good player... not that Polygon crap).

I can't speak for multiplayer. Honestly when I played the beta I thought it was bad (doesn't help that an Overwatch beta was happening at the same time), which really soured me on the whole thing. Maybe I'll try it out later, but the single player alone is worth it.

Performance-wise it runs great on my system (GTX970) mix of high and ultra @ 1440p, mostly 60-80fps with a few dips to the 40s (once again gsync is god-tier). I did have issues getting it to run at the right refresh though, it kept wanting to be 60Hz which broke gsync. Fiddling with windowed mode and fullscreen eventually fixed it, I don't know what I did exactly, but it's been fine since. Would be nice if they just had a refresh rate option - I don't know why they don't considering everything else is there.

reviewText:
DOOM is a visceral, adrenaline pumping romp through Mars, Hell, and back. Although DOOM is a relatively simple game, it is this very simplicity that makes id's achievement so impressive. Everything had to be executed with surgical precision, and I'm happy to report that from a gameplay perspective, this is one of the finest first person shooters ever released. The weapons are satisfying to use, the combat is fast and frenetic, and it is all backed up by a masterful score from Mick Gordon. This is the DOOM legions of fans had been hoping for.

Visually, the game looks nice, though maybe not quite as impressive as Doom 3 looked when it first came out. It is certainly a very pretty game, however, and perhaps more importantly, it runs like a dream. Doom 3 was a game many people built new systems for. DOOM, on the other hand, will likely run smoothly on the system you already have. I have absolutely no complaints about the game's optimization.

The combat in DOOM is absolutely the highlight of the game. Hearing about the skate park" design philosophy behind the combat arenas prerelease
date: I was a little worried that this would make for tedious pacing where you might dread the next time the game decides to lock you in a room
recommended: but it's actually quite the opposite. I found myself anticipating the next "skate park
hoursPlayed:
which it turns out is a surprisingly apt moniker for DOOM's combat arenas. The speed and fluidity with which you move around these arenas almost has a Mirror's Edge-like quality to it. Add in the excellent soundtrack, and it's hard to imagine that anything could be more violently thrilling than these sections.

The maps are large, non-linear, and full of secrets. It is a return to FPS map design many had feared lost. One minor flaw is that due to the nature of a facility like the UAC, things can look a little repetitive, though this is somewhat mitigated by a brilliantly simple system that uses the color green to let you know where to go. They've struck the right balance of making this obvious enough to help, and subtle enough to not be distracting.

The story is absolutely a weak point. While you might say that Doom has never been about story, and I would agree with you, the game itself can’t seem to decide whether its story is important or not. For the most part, it only exists to move the action along, though there are moments of conceit where the exposition seems to take a bit too long and the game forgets that its story is merely a means to an end. There are a lot of concepts that seem interesting, especially if you take the time to read the data logs you find while playing the game, but everything leaves you feeling much like you would if you started watching a TV series halfway through a season. You can follow things, but you can’t shake the feeling that you’re missing something. It feels like the story used to be bigger, but in the interest of pacing, many things were cut. I think they could have stood to cut a bit more. All in all though, this detracts from the experience very little.

Glory kills were something many people were worried about, and caused much consternation in the gaming community. While it played well in trailers, many were skeptical that it could actually work from a gameplay perspective without ruining the pacing by taking you out of the action. In actuality though, glory kills have turned out to be a great addition to the series. When you do enough damage to an enemy, it enters a stagger state, from which it is susceptible to a glory kill, which grants you extra health, armor, and/or ammo, depending on the runes you have equipped. Far from interrupting the flow of combat, it actually greatly enhances it by adding a certain kind of rhythm to the violence. While I think the system was a huge risk, id has proven that an assassination-style melee-kill system in an FPS can work if done correctly. In my mind, they proved all the skeptics wrong.

In fact, between the glory kill system and the multiplayer beta, DOOM garnered a lot of skepticism during the period of its prerelease promotion. The multiplayer mode is bland and uninspired, and it was likely a mistake to make this the general public’s first hands-on experience with the game, as it ended up negatively coloring their perception of the package as a whole. However, DOOM defied expectations and offers one of the best first person shooter campaigns in years. This is a game very much worth playing.

reviewText:
NOTE: This review is a work in progress.



I want to put my first impressions out there so I can alleviate some of the fears I know a lot of the fans have about this game after reading the press releases, watching the early access gameplay videos, and maybe even trying out the Beta.  I've waited a long time for this game, and have high expectations.  So far it's been pretty damn fun and definitely worth a buy right now if you are a long-time fan of shooters and/or Doom.  Fans expecting an amazing multiplayer experience may want to wait for a sale though.  Personally, I bought this game for the single player anyway so I'm a happy camper.

My initial impressions of the single player campaign are very good.  All the key elements are there: fast-paced gameplay, cool and upgradeable weapons, gorgeous graphics, lots of secrets and hidden passages to explore on each level.  The story is minimal, the combat is extremely fun and satisfying, and there lots of easter eggs for the long time fans to discover.  The guns are awesome and killing demons with them has to be on of the most viscerally satisfying experiences I've ever had.  The jury is still out on the new execution system, so far it's been okay but I could definitely have just as much fun without it.  It makes the game easier and I think the devs wanted the game to appeal to a broad audience, not just the old-school PC gamers.

My impression of the multiplayer... is that the devs lost sight of the core elements that made Doom multiplayer enjoyable.  I think the biggest gripe for me are the loadouts."  Basically you have to choose between a designated set of weapons before each match.  This made me feel restricted and overall like the devs didn't intend to make this multiplayer fun for the fans of arena-shooters.  They intended to make it more like other modern shooters
hoursPlayed: etc.  and possibly to cater to console gamers.  I'm not too happy with this as a PC gamer
voteText: but I understand compromises have to be made when you're trying to sell a game on multiple platforms and appeal to a broader audience.\n\nOverall
helpfulPercent: this game is well optimized and it satisfies my craving for a no nonsense
votesHelpful: fast-paced shooter.  I'm looking forward to even more fraggin' fun once I unlock Nightmare and Ultra-Nightmare mode!\n\nDemons beware
