reviewText:
This is precisely what I expected from an updated Doom. An FPS with great graphics, cybernetic demons, badass guns and badass music to kill by. The story is simple, you are a slayer of demons killing demons on Mars who have come through a hellgate created by an evil corporation. This is classic Doom with all the keycard hunting and demonic iconography in tact. I am really looking forward to getting the official soundtrack and a campaign expansion.

The multiplayer on the other hand is boring. The player skins all look like Power Rangers and there is a Code Of Conduct that prevents smack talk. My advice would be to get some friends together and explore some of the interesting game modes in an environment that doesn't discourage smack. And lastly SnapMaps sounded great, but it was made for consoles so the interface sucks. But some of the community maps are cool.
5/5 (for the campaign)

If you look for a game where you get the satisfaction of bashing an enemies head in with his own arm after you ripped the same off, then I recommend you to buy DOOM. See you in hell...

reviewText:
Guess it says a lot about me if I don't feel an ounce of sympathy for the demons DoomGuy brutally murders, yet feel absolutely horrible for those robots he punches in the face after they give him gun upgrades :(

For those of you who are kind of pulled one way and the other because of the reviews of the multiplayer beta: don't be alarmed. The campaign is definitely everything you asked for: the speed (definitely fast on 120 pov), the guns, the demons. All checked off, plus a few bonuses:

-The environments are GORGEOUS, even with medium settings (yes, my rig is modest).
-Secrets that get you looking all over the damn map, and are fun to look for
-The difficulty of Ultra-Violence (almost) matches Doom II's difficulty on the same level; safe to say, you will die a lot.

I do have nitpicks, of course. The upgrade system is definitely a bit cumbersome; I want cool guns, but having to pull off tricks to get their upgrades feels bleh. No, game, I really don't want to pull off 4 sweep-the-leg Glory Kills on ONE specific demon. Glory Kills in general, I'm very neutral about. The rune trials are weird and out of place, and I do feel a bit bleh about replaying one map twice (the second time, it's destroyed, which is dumb).

Still. They are nitpicks of a colossal, fast, brutal game that I can easily see myself sinking in ungodly amounts of time. I have yet to sink my teeth into Snapmap and Multiplayer outside of beta, but if it's the campaign you're here for, pick this one up. It's a worthy successor to the grandaddy of fps.

reviewText:
Right off bat, if there were 1 word for me to describe this game it would be: EPIC!

People may have been skeptical about rehashing old games just to jump the hype train but Bethesda Software does nothing short of delivering a software masterpiece that captures all the glory of the old games and invent new innovative ways to approach FPS.  To my knowledge they really set a new bar for FPS game standards.

STORY/SETTING:

You didn't buy Doom for a story as deep as Bioshock Infinite or Uncharted.  No excessive characters, no complicated story plot, very simple and to the point.  The environment and setting is vastly unknown to you and part of the enjoyment is to see what happens next after series of completing events.

GAMEPLAY:

Every encounter involves RUNNING and SHOOTING.  You won't be taking cover, you won't be sniping, there is no subtlety here as those will almost immediately get you killed.  Every fight is an unrelenting battle against insurmountable odds ranging from waves of small imps to multiple towering hell knights.  There are a great variety of monsters ranging from numerous but weak to few but nearly immortal, slow precise ranged to insanely fast melee, all of which requiring unique strategies with the weapons available.  This makes all of the weapons useful to the very end of the game as well.  Plasma rifles can be modified to stun monsters (great for stopping rushing melee enemies in their tracks), Rocket launchers with homing capabilities for tough medium ranged monsters, and rail guns for tough but slow long ranged monsters.

There is a spec" system for upgrading weapons
hoursPlayed: perks
voteText: etc.  I didn't calculate it precisely but I am pretty sure it is possible to max out all attributes by the last level of the game if you find all secrets in every level.  Missions can be replayed to recollect any missed secrets and gain additional upgrade points.  The upgrade system does seem a bit complicated though.\n\nI was also impressed with the double jump and climbing up cliffs function in the game.  Platforming has always been somewhat cumbersome in FPS games but with this new system
helpfulPercent:
it definitely allows significantly more control and agility of the character when running from enemies.  This greater control makes FPS games not feel so handicapped when moving and jumping around allowing for new enjoyable challenges that require running around.

SOUND:

The Music is quite fitting with the overall mood of the game.  In the base areas
votesHelpful: there is always some upbeat techno music and most of the encounters have some heavy metal type music.  It definitely adds mood and character to the game itself.  Each weapon has awesome sounds and it really feels like they hold a tremendous amount of power behind them.  Explosions
votesTotal: bullets whizzing
votesFunny:
laser blasts are all satisfying to constantly hear without feeling annoyed or repetitive.  The whizzing noise of rockets shooting out of the assault rifle and sticking to the enemies before exploding was one really memorable sound effect that stuck to me.

GRAPHICS:

The graphics are decent and on par with the most advanced games out there now.  I always felt DOOM was a game where you would fight off a tremendous amount of monsters at the same time
commentsCount: so I was concerned that some graphics would have to be sacrificed in order to accomodate large amounts of enemies on screen at the same time (I felt this was a problem for doom 3).  Turns out my worries were unfounded.  I played this with dual 980ti in SLI and could consistently get 120 to 150 fps with maxed out settings on a 1080P monitor.  Even on the forums
column16: people reported that they could achieve decent performance with single 970s.  The animations are all smooth
column17: each classic doom monster was reworked and given a new look while preserving what made them what they were in the 80s.  They really seemed to hit a good balance in providing great animations
column18:
looks without excessive stress on decent video cards.

OVERALL:

DOOM 2016 is an awesome game!  It is very challenging
column19: it stays true to its origins and brings a lot of new innovation to the table as well.  It is also decently long!  Ultra Violence difficulty
column20: which is what I am playing at
column21: will probably take 18 hours so.  I think I will hit the higher difficulty next.  I haven't explored the map editor or multiplayer at all yet.  I highly recommend this game to anyone looking for an adrenaline rushed action FPS game.  Starting with Wolfenstein the new order
column22: I really think Bethesda has found their place and niche in the gaming world.  If you see their games
column23: rest assured it will be action packed and it won't disappoint."

reviewText:
A nod to the classic deathmatch days but a gamechangng twist to bring the genre to the future. Demon runes can make this game as tense as any other and swing the overall score from an almost certain loss. Lots of fun, not terribly e-sportsy yet.

A lot of real oldschool quakers will mourn the lack of rocket jumps and bunnyhopping that became iconic of the quake series. But fingers crossed a DLC will open the game up to different styles of play.

Judging this game of Doom on its own merits, I would say it's a very enjoyable successful revival.

reviewText:
Read Completely, This is a Thumb's up ONLY for SinglePlayer, the Multiplatyer leaves alot to be desired, and I cannot say that it leaves anything positive for the game as a whole.

I am giving a thumbs-up with this review only for the Single Player campaign.  I'm really liking it and it seems to go back to the run and gun roots of the original doom games.  The levels look beautiful, the game play feels decent, and there's tons of gore to go around. I've been playing FPS since WolfenStein 3D came out, and I have spent of time playing Doom and Quake. Alot of people didn't like Doom 3, but personally I enjoyed it, yes it was different, but it was still fun none the less.

Now for the Bad news. The multiplayer leaves alot to be desired. It still feels just as bad as the Beta's did. Between load outs and glory kills I might as well go play COD.  It feels nothing like old arena shooters, it doesn't feel like quake, it doesn't feel like Unreal, it doesn't even feel like Doom 3 's deathmatch.  The one major point in the multiplayer I will applaud is the customization. But that's about it.

If I can leave more than 1 review I will split these, since I honestly wish I could give just the multiplayer a big fat thumbs down.  I will come back and polish up this review after I play some more.

reviewText:
I'm actually impressed and surprised at how good this game is.  If you have played and enjoyed the new Wolfenstein, you'll love this.  This game is a tremendous step up from their previous FPS, and it's amazing how much fun I'm having.
Favorite part has to be the soundtrack.  The heavy metal sounds kick in right as the action starts, and it really does feel like you're a badass.
Another interesting thing about this game is that it rewards you for being aggressive with the glory kills that restore a very small amount of HP (+5 is the highest I've gotten from one).  Being aggressive is how this game is meant to be played, after all.

reviewText:
Product received for free

At the point of writing this review I have played the game for around nine hours; I want people to understand before reading this review I am just slightly biased, because I've been playing the Shareware of DOOM from 1993 since I was like nine, and my best-friend went out of her way to buy this for me so that only makes this even more endearing.

That aside, I'll begin in earnest saying that while I respect everyone's opinion and feel they are entitled to have one, I'm going to have to say the people saying that this game doesn't capture or bring back the original memories of the first DOOM are silly. I'd say the only real difference between this game, and the first released version of DOOM is the enemy density, but if you'll be so kind as to note combat was slightly different in the series' first entry and didn't feature combat on vertical planes and multiple levels at once. It was far easier to keep track of projectiles and dodge while fighting simulteanously and switching between weapons to manage one's arsenal, not only that, but aside from the zombified base-staff there are very few enemies in the original game that don't have attacks you can't dodge.

Keep in mind now that we've far exceeded the technology of the first game, this game may feature a far more smaller enemy density, but it will be in arenas that have multiple levels and areas of combat. Not only that but the lack of sheer numbers should only be problematic for the casual gamer who just wants to blast things, truly-so. The damage scaling between Hurt Me Plenty and Ultra-Violence is easily felt in the first few imp fireballs. You'll do well to note it takes only one or two fireballs at a 100 health directly on UV to kill you, whereas you can tank those hits fairly consistently for far longer in Hurt Me Plenty. This, coupled with the higher tiers of enemies later on (Hell Knights, Summoners, Revenants and so forth) is important, because a Hell Knight will basically gibe you on impact if you don't have a steady upkeep of armor.

The combat is superb. Quick, fast and brutal. A couple adjustments with runes and you can utilize Glory Kills to their fullest to continually build up your armor and keep your armor stable as you rampage. While the easiest strategy in battle I've made a note of is just to carefully strafe backwards and pick enemies off with your arsenal, I feel players who have fantastic hand-eye coordination and critical thinking will agree with me in saying it is so much more fun to go right at them switching between your weapons to stagger multiple enemies and utilize the full bulk of your mods to cut straight through them. There have been only a couple areas in the later stages at UV that I feel have been hard to do with that mentality (I'm looking at you, Titan's Realm).

And to speak to the validity of the way it looks and feels, the guns might seem a little bit floaty but thats a byproduct of the sheer speed and vertical ascension players are granted throughout the campaign. Not only that but this installation steps back from the ideas of DOOM 3 and takes an approach more familiar to classic gamers, which is to throw blood on everything and tell the player to go punch things. The developers, id, did extremely well in going back and reduxing the artwork and graphical theme to make it far more in-tune with the Ultimate DOOM and DOOM II, adding a grungy-metal teenager phase feeling to the game where you might even feel inspired to take a notepad and start tallying down your kills. From the heavy, metallic pang of your boots thundering across the catwalks in the Foundry to the splashing of boots in blood, this entry in the series makes a notable return to the original concept. Story here takes a backburner, in the end, you can sum it up with the main-character as being the ultimate badass and he's just here to kick ♥♥♥. Any of the side characters or extra work he goes through is just some side-job stuff to his ♥♥♥-kicking festival, population: Hell.

My only real complaint for this game would be limiting the Health and Armor caps through the upgrades of Argent Cells, and thats because the original system wasn't so punishing when you made mistakes. I'd love to put my first few cells into ammo capacity, but I feel like the game demands Armor and Health with how hard the enemies can hit when you make a mistake. Think of it like vigor capping in Dark Souls, so you have more rope to work with when you royally ♥♥♥♥ up.

tl;dr game is fantastic, id did a great job, best-friend is bae.

reviewText:
--- Update ---

I've finished the SP campaign. Clocked in at about 12 hours in length.

I need some time to reflect because I feel like making some pretty bold claims about how this is the best FPS I've played in at least the last decade. No game has made my adrenaline pump this much in a while. Bravo id.

I want more. Please make more. Just like this. More.

Doesn't look like games media has their reviews out yet but I don't expect much from them since they are almost universally terrible at video games, especially PC-centric twitch shooters that require skill. Just trust me on this one. It's great. (edit: called it)

--- Original ---

The single player campaign is really, really great. It's fast, it's frantic, it's metal as hell. I love it. If you're looking for a straightforward action packed twitch shooter, look no further.

I had 0 expectations and didn't even plan to buy this game, but damn, this has been a huge surprise. They dropped the ball with marketing. Raw gameplay footage sells itself (of a good player... not that Polygon crap).

I can't speak for multiplayer. Honestly when I played the beta I thought it was bad (doesn't help that an Overwatch beta was happening at the same time), which really soured me on the whole thing. Maybe I'll try it out later, but the single player alone is worth it.

Performance-wise it runs great on my system (GTX970) mix of high and ultra @ 1440p, mostly 60-80fps with a few dips to the 40s (once again gsync is god-tier). I did have issues getting it to run at the right refresh though, it kept wanting to be 60Hz which broke gsync. Fiddling with windowed mode and fullscreen eventually fixed it, I don't know what I did exactly, but it's been fine since. Would be nice if they just had a refresh rate option - I don't know why they don't considering everything else is there.

reviewText:
DOOM is a visceral, adrenaline pumping romp through Mars, Hell, and back. Although DOOM is a relatively simple game, it is this very simplicity that makes id's achievement so impressive. Everything had to be executed with surgical precision, and I'm happy to report that from a gameplay perspective, this is one of the finest first person shooters ever released. The weapons are satisfying to use, the combat is fast and frenetic, and it is all backed up by a masterful score from Mick Gordon. This is the DOOM legions of fans had been hoping for.

Visually, the game looks nice, though maybe not quite as impressive as Doom 3 looked when it first came out. It is certainly a very pretty game, however, and perhaps more importantly, it runs like a dream. Doom 3 was a game many people built new systems for. DOOM, on the other hand, will likely run smoothly on the system you already have. I have absolutely no complaints about the game's optimization.

The combat in DOOM is absolutely the highlight of the game. Hearing about the skate park" design philosophy behind the combat arenas prerelease
date: I was a little worried that this would make for tedious pacing where you might dread the next time the game decides to lock you in a room
recommended: but it's actually quite the opposite. I found myself anticipating the next "skate park
hoursPlayed:
which it turns out is a surprisingly apt moniker for DOOM's combat arenas. The speed and fluidity with which you move around these arenas almost has a Mirror's Edge-like quality to it. Add in the excellent soundtrack, and it's hard to imagine that anything could be more violently thrilling than these sections.

The maps are large, non-linear, and full of secrets. It is a return to FPS map design many had feared lost. One minor flaw is that due to the nature of a facility like the UAC, things can look a little repetitive, though this is somewhat mitigated by a brilliantly simple system that uses the color green to let you know where to go. They've struck the right balance of making this obvious enough to help, and subtle enough to not be distracting.

The story is absolutely a weak point. While you might say that Doom has never been about story, and I would agree with you, the game itself can’t seem to decide whether its story is important or not. For the most part, it only exists to move the action along, though there are moments of conceit where the exposition seems to take a bit too long and the game forgets that its story is merely a means to an end. There are a lot of concepts that seem interesting, especially if you take the time to read the data logs you find while playing the game, but everything leaves you feeling much like you would if you started watching a TV series halfway through a season. You can follow things, but you can’t shake the feeling that you’re missing something. It feels like the story used to be bigger, but in the interest of pacing, many things were cut. I think they could have stood to cut a bit more. All in all though, this detracts from the experience very little.

Glory kills were something many people were worried about, and caused much consternation in the gaming community. While it played well in trailers, many were skeptical that it could actually work from a gameplay perspective without ruining the pacing by taking you out of the action. In actuality though, glory kills have turned out to be a great addition to the series. When you do enough damage to an enemy, it enters a stagger state, from which it is susceptible to a glory kill, which grants you extra health, armor, and/or ammo, depending on the runes you have equipped. Far from interrupting the flow of combat, it actually greatly enhances it by adding a certain kind of rhythm to the violence. While I think the system was a huge risk, id has proven that an assassination-style melee-kill system in an FPS can work if done correctly. In my mind, they proved all the skeptics wrong.

In fact, between the glory kill system and the multiplayer beta, DOOM garnered a lot of skepticism during the period of its prerelease promotion. The multiplayer mode is bland and uninspired, and it was likely a mistake to make this the general public’s first hands-on experience with the game, as it ended up negatively coloring their perception of the package as a whole. However, DOOM defied expectations and offers one of the best first person shooter campaigns in years. This is a game very much worth playing.

reviewText:
Alrighty then. well what can i say?. This game has to be the best game i have played in 2016 so far.  ID really made this one beautifully.  The combat is best compared to the original doom. it's fast paced and epic!  The music is ♥♥♥♥ing great as well!! it really fits durring the big arena fights you have in the campaign :D!. alright well these are my intro thoughts not time for the Pro's
-Best first person shooter to have come out in 2016 so far. the combat is amazingly smooth and satisfying
- The music..oh my gawd the music is amazing! as i said in my intro, it really fits the game well!  I know its the same composer from the wolfenstien games recently.  Only difference is that he uses a 9 string guitar for doom (2016) \m/
- I have an i5 4460, Gtx 750 ti and 8GB of ddr3 Ram.  This game is well optomized! some parts i do go under 20 but only for a quick second. i get an average about 40 fps with a high of 60 and a low of 24. with ocasional lower than 20 but again, those drops only last a second so it's not that bad.  My settings were mixed but pretty much was in high settings with antialiasing x8.
- Campaign is about 10-16 hours long depending if you love exploring the beautifull maps or just go through and kill demons.  i have 10 hrs for my campaign. but you have the ability to replay a level if you want and there are a ton of secrets to find along with quick little trials for runes that give doom guy special abilities.
-Multiplayer i only played for about an hour or so. it has about 6 multiplayer modes including the ones from the beta warpath and tdm.  There are also more weapons and cosmetic stuff for your character.  The best thing about Doom multiplayer is that is welcomes back the traditional classic arena shooter.  For example like Quake, unreal tournament etc.  It's fast paced, ammo and health pick ups with a welcomed twist.  somewhere around the map a super weapon can spawn in or a demon rune.  if the player picks up the demon rune he or she will become one of four playable demons.  It's a fun and welcomed mechanic in multiplayer.

Now even though the game is amazing. it's not perfect. time for the con's
- through the campaign i had about 3 hard crashes.  Durring fighting the game just stopped and took me back to my desktop screen.  No doom has crashed" window pop up or anything.  the 3rd made my screen go completly black and my desktop screen had to load everything back up.
- Doom ends with a cliffhanger.  I pretty much HATE cliffhangers with a passion. I'm not gona spoil it here. but just know it's a cliffhanger ending.  Although idk if this is a reboot or sequel of the original doom because the original doom also ended with a slight cliffhanger.
- 40$ season pass.  As far as i know the dlc will all be multiplayer. it will include 3 new maps
date: a new demon to play as
recommended:
a new weapon and more cosmetic items.  Seperatly the dlc will be $14.99 which imo is a bit too much.  Maybe some of it will be expansions and or continuations of the story since the cliffhanger ecourages Doom 2 or Doom 6 (idk if this is a sequel or reboot but whatever)

Ending thoughts: Pretty much this is the best shooter to have come out on 2016 so far.  The game is made just to have fun and brutalize demons from hell and i hope it inspires other devs to just make games where people can just have fun.  Sure im a sucker for a great captivating story and or really awesome plot.  But ID just shows you can make a good story with amazing ♥♥♥♥ing gameplay.  Even though i dont like the $40 season pass or the $14.99 dlc's ID software have put their heart and soul in the gaming community before i was born. They give a ♥♥♥♥ about us and gave us an awesome game to keep us enjoyed until their next DOOM.  I am open about purchasing the season pass if it's $10 off. mostly cuz ID and bathesda deserve the support.  They still give a ♥♥♥♥ about the players and give us satisfying content.
GG WP

"

reviewText:
Playing the first DOOM at my older cousin's, was the most thrilling experience ever. I unfortunately got into GTA really quickly, and the feelings that doom gave me never really returned. Now, out of nowhere, I see DOOM pop up under my friends' names on Steam, and I'm immediately intrigued. I did some research, and the game was well reviewed, but I did myself the favor of not watching any gameplay.
After hours of downloading, I open up the game with speakers at max and lights off. I max out the graphics, enter the campaign, and roughly 5 seconds after loading in, I'm blown away. The graphics are absolutely stunning, and no less than 10 seconds into the game, I'm fighting demons. The DOOM feelings from my past flourished, and I went berserk.
Demon blood painted the walls and 20 gauge shells rapidly fled my steaming shotgun. I had experienced a more epic scenario in 1 minute, than I had in any game the past few years.

After rougly 2 hours of singleplayer, I had to try online, since my friend told me it was horrible. I was a tad surprised at his opinion, but realizing he hadn't played the game, I begged his pardon, and sought to prove him wrong. Entering the multiplayer, I realized that it had an armor customization option, very close the the Halo 4 multiplayer system. This had me thrilled, because Halo has been one of my favourite video game franchises.
So, as I load into the game, I'm greeted by a few players, incidentally equipped with microphones, already a nice community. I load into a map, and choose the chain gun (minigun/gatling cannon, whatever floats your boat), and I rev it up. A powersurge fills my body, and I'm ready to slaughter... and so, I do. I mow down enemies, as I get the hang of the simple controls and zero reload. I memorize armor, health, and power-up spawns. I reach max carnage, and accidentally pick up the demon rune. My power has increased, by 4000 percent, and my urge to kill rises. My revenant jet pack pulls me into the air, and my cannons assist me in my genocide. Ending on top 3 players in the first match made me continue on my rampage. My bloodlust had yet to be quelched.


Now that I got that off of my chest, here is an actual review.
It's DOOM, no doubt. Not a strong story line, generic map layout, and tons of gore. Getting glorious kills, by cramming a demon's own foot into its mouth is truly an experience in its own. The game is insanely well optimized, compared to other triple A titles, and runs at +200FPS in multiplayer, and +120FPS in the campaign.
The multiplayer is amazing, hilarious, and very intense. It's very well balanced, as no weapon mods are introduced in online, merely the visual customization of your Praetor suit and weapon arsenal. The only true advantages are skill and hack modules, which you may only activate after death. And if you do get killed by someone with a hack module, then you have the opportunity to activate your own hack. These hacks include everything from locating enemies, to a wider  health pick-up radius.
Once you pass level 50, you earn an Echelon level, and your main level is reset automatically. This doesn't take away any stats, but instead unlocks new challenges, which allow you to earn more experience.

Oh you thought I was done? Think again. Snapmap is here, and it was already introduced in the beta, I believe. Snapmap allows you to create your own DOOM maps by using a blueprint system. It works by choosing one of many room templates, and snapping them into place, fusing them with other snapping points. You may add ambient sounds, music, monsters, and decals in every room, with your heart's desire, until you run out of memory, of course. If you have played Halo, you'll know about forge and it's border of creation, as you were always stuck to one map that you couldn't change, but if you want another room in snapmap... just enter blueprint mode, and spawn a massive room. The rooms vary from Tiny hallways, to massive arenas, which can be filled with explosive barrels, or demons... Again, your choice.
The snapmap community has already introduced several ingenious map designs, ranging from music makers with an actual keyboard and drum sequencer, to a remake of the 2nd level in the first doom.
It's your playground, and the possibilites are endless.

I give DOOM a demon slaying, heart ripping, blood splatting, 10 out of ♥♥♥♥ing 10.

BUY IT

reviewText:
Do you like long walks on the beach, Sipping on pina coladas, and getting caught in the rain? Do you believe in demonic rights? Are you a demon justice warrior? If you said yes to any of these questions then get out.

Do you like ramming you fists in demons and ripping them apart like the manbeast you are? Do you like shooting big guns that make big messes? Do you like to particpate in the lumberjack contest but instead of carving into tree trunks you're carving into demons which escaped the pits of hell? So go ahead, add DOOM to your cart, become a Space Marine and punish demons.

reviewText:
DOOM is back with a vengeance.

Pros:
-Insanely good Single-Player campaign
-Lots of guns that can all be held at the same time (BFG, Rocket launcher, Chainsaw, you name it)
-Almost every weapon has 2 upgrades that can be swapped in and out at any time
-Weapon upgrades and Suit upgrades let you enhance your combat abilities
-Tons of secret areas to find, all hiding armor, collectibles, mega-health, and you can even get certain weapons early on
-High speed combat
-Lots of verticality
-Large enemy variety all with different attacks and abilities
-You can rip a demon's arm off and then smash their head off with said arm
-Lots of hilarious player death animations for when you inevitably get taken down by the forces of Hell
-Good challenge, even on medium difficulty
-The level editor, SnapMap, is really easy to use and user friendly, but is incredibly powerful if used correctly
Cons:
-Multiplayer is kind of eh but it works
-Multiplayer and Snapmap are limited to 2-weapon systems :(
-No current announcement of singleplayer expansion pack(s) (Come on, we all want more!)
-No options for texture quality. Highest quality textures are loaded in reguardless of what settings you have.

I reccomend DOOM for any Single-player FPS fan who wants to rip and tear to their heart's content.

reviewText:
NOTE: This review is a work in progress.



I want to put my first impressions out there so I can alleviate some of the fears I know a lot of the fans have about this game after reading the press releases, watching the early access gameplay videos, and maybe even trying out the Beta.  I've waited a long time for this game, and have high expectations.  So far it's been pretty damn fun and definitely worth a buy right now if you are a long-time fan of shooters and/or Doom.  Fans expecting an amazing multiplayer experience may want to wait for a sale though.  Personally, I bought this game for the single player anyway so I'm a happy camper.

My initial impressions of the single player campaign are very good.  All the key elements are there: fast-paced gameplay, cool and upgradeable weapons, gorgeous graphics, lots of secrets and hidden passages to explore on each level.  The story is minimal, the combat is extremely fun and satisfying, and there lots of easter eggs for the long time fans to discover.  The guns are awesome and killing demons with them has to be on of the most viscerally satisfying experiences I've ever had.  The jury is still out on the new execution system, so far it's been okay but I could definitely have just as much fun without it.  It makes the game easier and I think the devs wanted the game to appeal to a broad audience, not just the old-school PC gamers.

My impression of the multiplayer... is that the devs lost sight of the core elements that made Doom multiplayer enjoyable.  I think the biggest gripe for me are the loadouts."  Basically you have to choose between a designated set of weapons before each match.  This made me feel restricted and overall like the devs didn't intend to make this multiplayer fun for the fans of arena-shooters.  They intended to make it more like other modern shooters
hoursPlayed: etc.  and possibly to cater to console gamers.  I'm not too happy with this as a PC gamer
voteText: but I understand compromises have to be made when you're trying to sell a game on multiple platforms and appeal to a broader audience.\n\nOverall
helpfulPercent: this game is well optimized and it satisfies my craving for a no nonsense
votesHelpful: fast-paced shooter.  I'm looking forward to even more fraggin' fun once I unlock Nightmare and Ultra-Nightmare mode!\n\nDemons beware

reviewText:
I just finished the single player campagin, and even though I really never play single player games or at least get bored after   20 minutues, this kept me in all the way till the end in a single sitting. This is quite possibly the best single player game since hl2, it follows a good design, it focuses mostly on combat, the level design is amazing, graphics are really good and it averages at 100fps on ultra with gtx 970 and amd8350, whic his beyond incredible.

To put it into simple words, this game was made right, no unnecessary stuff that makes you fall asleep, no stupid compliated upgrades, it does have some simple ones, amazing gameplay, stunning visuals, straight to the point.

Only thing I'd say about it that is negative is that it was a little too easy on highest available difficulity.

As far as the multiplayer goes, it is fun, simple, and fast paced but nothing to freak about.

reviewText:
In the six hours I have played to date, DOOM has been a lot of fun, a LOT more fun than other games I have bought recently.
The maps are wondefully intricate without the need for open world, they are not as confined as some reviewers would lead you to believe. Others have issues with the AI ,to keep this short I will simply say I don't (if you are in a hallway or staircase yes the AI will kind of line up.. obviously). The tons of secrets really justify the maps designs. ( if your Gamma is set properly) they can even be creepy. The Glory kills are repetative but a good addition to the game mechanic.

Ultimately DOOM puts you in that DOOM world with the music, the tempo of the game, the fast pace gamplay, the  need to be inquisitive, the crazed demons, DOOM is a well made game, Unlike Rage, Id did DOOM right.

reviewText:
ID have done it, they managed to make a Doom game that will please any old & new Doom fan alike.

I've just finished the story on Ultra violent ( the hardest it will let you start off with )  in around 10 hours and what can I say its kept me constantly playing unlike any recent FPS games I've played. From your first fight to your last Boss its amazingly entertaining and bloody brutal. Every gun is great fun so you generally will end up swapping between them all as you run through the horde of demons that have come to ruin your Martian vacation. The graphics are amazing, even with everything down on medium ( so i can keep it running at 60fps ) the story isn't half bad either. Loads of secrets to find just like a Doom game should have. I'm not going to talk about the multiplayer cause we all know what thats like and i've not touched the snap map to be honest so that will be interesting. All in all if your a fan of FPS's and aren't squeemish buy it...... buy it now
